Sorry for not putting any links; Youtube doesn't like comments with a lot of links in them and might hide them from the public for spam. Please note that some of these studies are also not open access. If you try to find the study you'll only be able to view the abstract (the summary) and the authors, with the publication prompting you to pay money to access the study. I recommend contacting the corresponding author, you can usually find their phone number or email address listed somewhere, and asking them for a free copy of the paper. It's completely legal and scientists don't receive a cut of the profits from publishers anyways. 1. "Beyond the Ivory Tower: The Scientific Consensus on Climate Change" written by Naomi Oreskes and published by Science magazine on January, 2005. 2. "Examing the Scientific Consensus on Climate Change" written by Peter T. Doran and Maggie Kendall Zimmerman and published in Eos, Transactions, American Geophysical Union on June 3rd, 2011. 3. "Expert Credibility in Climate Change" written by William R. L. Anderegg et al. and published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America on June 21st, 2011. 4. "Scientists' Views about Attribution of Global Warming" written by Bart Verheggen et al. and published in Environmental Science and Technology on July 22nd, 2014. 5. "Meterologists' Views About Global Warming: A Survey of American Meteorological Society Professional Members" written by Neil Stenhouse et al. and published in the Bulletin of American Meteorological Society on August 22nd, 2014. 6. "The Climate Change Consensus Extends Beyond Climate Scientists" written by J S Carlton et al. and published in Environmental Research Letters on September 24th, 2015.

According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years. That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago. World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle. The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

“I want to pause here and talk about this notion of consensus, and the rise of what has been called consensus science. I regard consensus science as an extremely pernicious development that ought to be stopped cold in its tracks. Historically, the claim of consensus has been the first refuge of scoundrels; it is a way to avoid debate by claiming that the matter is already settled. Whenever you hear the consensus of scientists agrees on something or other, reach for your wallet, because you're being had.

Let's be clear: the work of science has nothing whatever to do with consensus. Consensus is the business of politics. Science, on the contrary, requires only one investigator who happens to be right, which means that he or she has results that are verifiable by reference to the real world. In science consensus is irrelevant. What is relevant is reproducible results. The greatest scientists in history are great precisely because they broke with the consensus.

There is no such thing as consensus science. If it's consensus, it isn't science. If it's science, it isn't consensus. Period.”
Michael Crichton

@seigeengine You said it: communication is an art, and Derek is extremely good at it. But to give a title such as "Climate change is boring" doesn't send the right message to people whose attention cannot be grasped by reasonable cues. That's my point, and as you aptly said, a good science communicator must use "flashy" tricks to get ideas across. But to qualify a whole topic, and a still controversial one at high levels of decision and power in the USA, and as important as climate change in actuality, as boring? Nope. Too often nowadays, the medium is the message, and here, Derek didn't have the best idea. That's all I'm saying. I am a fan, not a fan boy.

Yeah, tone is complex. Of course it is, but your entire comment seems to slightly miss the point as what you call "cool" is just what's salient to normal people. Climate change may be interesting to a minority, but most people have little attention for things outside their immediate lives, especially when it's negative, and their individual actions can't have any clear or directly observable effect for them. It's hard to get people to care about things even when they can take steps that they can see the results of, like cleaning up their local environments. People already have many negative factors in their lives that are stressful and they can do relatively little about, with no direct result evident for those actions. So climate change is boring, in the sense that it doesn't hold people's attention, not that it isn't important. Flashy demonstrations are so common in science communication because most people don't care otherwise. Sure, other people don't use those methods when communicating issues... but most of them also don't have any real audience. They're preaching to the choir more and communicating to the average person less. That's fine, but it has limits. And I mean, isn't that the real job of communicators in general? To communicate to people who aren't already invested in what's being communicated?

@seigeengine It came off like so? I'm really sorry about it. English isn't my first language and I know it may make my style a bit overreaching or... wanky? Well, as though I'm taking myself too seriously. Environment, ecology and the state of the Earth and how we manage it as a species are of major importance not only for me but for my children, grandchildren and, well, pretty much all my fellow humans. I started thinking seriously about it around 1969, so I think I have a pretty good knowledge of the subject. Back in the days, climate change wasn't even among the predictions scientists were then making about Earth's future. Want a proof? Have you read "The Limits to Growth", published in the early 70s? Sophisticated computer models that tried to figure out for how long we had as a planet given our birth rate, metal and other mineral mining and consumption, fossil fuel reserves, etc. Well, as astonishing and sobering it might seem, there was not a single one prediction about how greenhouse effect producing gases would increase average global temperature and melt the polar caps. Mind boggling! I returned to it not too long ago and indeed, scientists in 1970 weren't able to factor in the CO2 and CH4 contributions to climate. And here we are today, suddenly waking up as a planet and realizing what a mess we gave made. Of course, it doesb't invalidate the other conclusions contained in Limits to Growth, which summarizes the report the group called the Club of Rome sent to the UN. Despite its scientific shortcomings mostly due to the state of climate science at the times, it's extremely valuable reading and anybody who doesn't think climste change is boring should go through it. Not a very long book either, very rational, very logical . It was my "road to Damas" event when I read it around 1962...

"it is not going to stop greenhouse emissions which come mainly from energy usage and transportation"......that is not true. Water vapor is the no. 1 greenhouse gas. Man only produces a fraction of CO2. CO2 becomes less effective as a greenhouse gas as it increases....double the CO2 will not double the greenhouse effect. The climate has been warmer in the past with both more and less CO2. CO2 comes out of solution in the oceans as the oceans warm and the oceans lag the atmosphere in warming. The temperature record has been manipulated to reduce temps in the past and increase more recent temps....hence the "hockey stick" graph. There has been no statistically significant warming over the last 20 years while CO2 has continued to increase. The record hot temp was set over a century ago in Death Valley....the coldest temp was in 2010 in Antarctica.
Putting complete nonsense in ALL CAPS doesn't make it any less nonsensical. The data shows continued rises in average temperature. Denying facts just makes you look moronic.

How will a "carbon tax" reduce emissions? If the tax is exorbitantly high, carbon credits will command a premium value on trading exchanges and trading in these credits will become a major source of profit for the big investment banks. Meanwhile, major portions of our economy will be forced to shut down. Third-world countries will be particularly hard hit, since they would need to escalate their production to achieve any hope of economic independence. You could even have a situation where investment banks that are successful carbon tax traders would acquire energy and manufacturing companies and run them with the carbon credit profit they generate.

If the tax is mot significant, it will just be a minor earnings drag on companies that are forced to acquire additional credits in the marketplace. They will raise prices and decrease wages to maintain their expense margins.

Even if you buy into the necessity of the carbon tax, how does one country stop another country from cheating? You really think Asian countries would seriously comply with any carbon tax scheme?

The short version of this - the Rich Get Richer and the Poor Stay Poor, no matter how the carbon tax is implemented.

Cap and trade is a carbon tax but flipped around and made more esoteric and less effective. A carbon tax works because environmental costs are REAL costs, but those who incur them do not have to pay them. There's a proper economics term for costs like that, but I can't remember it off the top of my head. As long as this is the case, companies have no incentive to optimize for these costs. What a carbon tax does is put the costs back upon those who create them, which enables the market to do what the market is good at: optimize and compete. Not having a carbon tax is anti-capitalist as it is a de facto subsidy.
Cap and trade is a different system from a carbon tax. "major portions of our economy will be forced to shut down" yes that's the idea, the tax is supposed to increase until there is no profit left.

Whoever thinks they can predict what will happen to the earth's temperature is delusional. I do modeling earth systems for a living. Even when modeling much simpler processes there is a very large uncertainty in the outcome. In the particular case of climate modeling (probably the most complex coupled problem) there are numerous effects that we don't have proper understanding of, such as cloud formation or the stability of hydrates, that are critical to prediction. Unfortunately, most disaster scenarios rely on positive feedback by these other more potent effects which we don't properly understand.

How does a carbon tax reduce emissions? it just seems to be a license to pollute with a clear conscience.

From an economic standpoint, it would. If the price of something rises, it's demand will fall. So if coal based energy is carbon taxed, demand for it will reduce. Less coal will be burnt, and so there's lower greenhouse gas emissions. Consequently, the revenue earned because of the tax can be used for carbon sequestering units or Carbon absorbing trees, which reduce CO2 levels even more. I'm not sure how effective a carbon tax would be, but from an economics standpoint, it should work to reduce carbon emissions.

Climate change is not just boring, it is silly. First, the whole narrative depends on a mostly meaningless metric - global average temperature anomaly. Think about that for a minute or two. In any given place on the globe, temperature changes on a cyclical basis over the course of a 24- hour day, from a daily low, typically just before sunrise, to a daily high, typically several hours after noon, then falling slowly overnight to the next day’s low temperature. So, you average out the day’s high and low temperature, a range that might be only a few degrees, but might be as much as 20 degrees F on a given day, to find the average daily temperature for that location. Then you take that average, and average it out with the average daily temperature for every other place on Earth. So what? A completely meaningless metric. Second, there is ZERO persuasive empirical evidence that atmospheric CO2 is the primary driver of warming, or even a material driver of warming. The Earth’s climate has been constantly changing over its entire 4.5 Billion year history, either cooling or warming. Just in the last 12,000 years, a blink of an eye in geological terms, Earth’s climate has gone through several cycles warmer than today, from the Holocene Optimum, about 6,000-4,500 years ago, the Roman Warm Period, and the Medieval Warm Period, ALL warmer by 2-4 degrees C than today, and NONE caused by atmospheric CO2. Climate scientists can’t even identify or quantify the many natural causes of climate change, like solar cycles, changes in solar magnetic activity, changes in ocean currents, etc., yet we are supposed to believe the story that it is all (or even mostly) CO2? Hogwash!

yes climate change is real, but we don't know how much carbon dioxide affected

> yes climate change is real, but we don't know how much carbon dioxide affected Sure we do, it's the majority of it. How can we tell? Well, different mechanisms have different physical properties, as a result they have different fingerprints of where they will warm the quickest and have other fingerprints to test what is the likely primary cause, for example CO2 based warming will: * warm in the troposphere while cooling the upper atmosphere (observed and is relatively unique to CO2 based warming) * Warm the poles (With the exception of the 2 km thick eastern Antarctic ice sheet) quicker than the equator (observed) * Warm at night as much as the day (observed) * Reduce the long wave radiation going out into space (observed) These are the strongest fingerprints in the instrumental record indicating that whatever mechanism has all of these fingerprints combined is the primary cause. These are still being observed during a time that the sun is becoming exceptionally inactive and we're still seeing record temperatures.

Okay, if you think anthropogenic global warming is a fraud, answer me this: Fossil fuels contain a lower concentration of the isotope Carbon 13 than that which exists naturally in the atmosphere. This is because plants have a preference for the lighter carbon isotopes (13C vs 12C), and fossil fuels are derived from ancient plants. We observe that while global temperatures and CO2 levels are increasing, the ratio of 13C/12C in the atmosphere is decreasing, and from this, we can infer that fossil fuels are causing the warming. So, here's my question: If anthropogenic global warming is a hoax, then what is causing the decrease of the concentration of the 13C isotope in the atmosphere? What is responsible for this phenomenon, if not the burning of fossil fuels? And if you can't answer, then I'm naturally going to assume that you're scientifically illiterate, and have no business claiming that AGW is a fraud.

The antarctic land ice is thickening at a rate estimated at 100 billions tons per year net OK that's only a tiny bit but it is in fact thickening. This is easily measured by precise altimeter data. When ice sheets thicken they spread at the margin like a pancake. this spread is not "melting" ice but standard glacial behavior. When the spreading glacial pancake reaches the end of the land mass it pancakes not over land but floats upon sea water. This process continues until the force of ocean currents beneath the ice exceed the sheer force that attaches the glacial ice to land. @mr pit pull Lets take your points one by one: The sea is not globally rising, in some places it's receding, in other places it's advancing, and in still other places it's doing nothing at all. The "average" rates are so small that plate tectonics (the rise, fall and shift of continental land masses) is far more significant. Add to this wind and water erosion wearing at shores and sedimentation adding many miles of new coastline and the picture is muddled. The natural world is always far more complex than simple self-serving theoretical models offered for political purpose. Scientific minds are both questioning and skeptical of presumed knowledge. The religious mind accepts dogma on faith in either priests or scientists. You put your faith in government science while I have none. Why don't you tell me what country you abide in so I can show you data in lieu of misplaced fear and superstition. As for the world "average" temperature changing, I am prepared to accept the fact that it is. I am not prepared to accept that such changes can be accurately assessed and quantified or that any means of doing so are sound. This is particularly significant when it goes unquestioned that world average annual (and monthly) temperature can be assessed to an accuracy of 0.01 degrees C over the last 150 years. This is total nonsense that goes unquestioned by a malleable and stupid press. Also unquestioned is why past temperature records (actual observations) have been manipulated (altered) to make the past appear cooler than the observational record established. In my country (the USA) we comprise a very small portion of the Earth where 70% is covered by sea and another 20% is either uninhabited or has no comprehensive spatial or temporal record of local weather conditions. However the USA has "the" most comprehensive weather data of any country on Earth, even as inadequate as it is for determining its historical "average" temperature. I don't use such a subjective record of determining if climate change is of concern to the USA or even to the larger world but instead use highest and lowest "recorded" temperature records for each of our 50 states and have noted this: 25 of our 50 states set record highs in the decade of the 1930s, that's some 90 years ago. They have never been exceeded since. Over the last 20 years no states have set record highs and over the last 30 years only two states have set record highs. On the other hand, 9 of our states have set record lows over the same 30 years. Clearly my far-less-subjective data shows a country whose average temperatures are in decline. There is a wealth of hard data including growing season length (last frost to first frost) that contradict the political agenda of government (politically funded) climate "science." The USA maintains a USCRN (US Climate Reference Network) funded to establish a pristine geographically distributed network of weather stations that has been operational since 2005 (15 years) The purpose of this network was to establish the fact the global warming is impacting the USA. Here is the output of actual data (not models made of nonsense): https://i.stack.imgur.com/iMZirl.png You tell me, whats the verdict? This is the reason you have never before heard of the USCRN

@mr pit pull Yes 15,000 years ago. Major climate shifts that are of major impact are governed by known changes in the Earth's orbit around the sun which change the amount of our received radiation by as much as 5%. These cycles are called Milankovitch cycles. They are governed by Newtonian kinetics and gravitation. The shortest of these cycles is the precession of the equinoxes that completes one cycle every 26,000 years. This precession currently puts the Northern Hemisphere winters at nearly the precise time the Earth is closest to the sun. 13000 years from now the Northern winter will occur when when the Earth is most distant from the sun thus exacerbating the severity of Northern Winters and bringing on a new Ice age. To be sure this precession has the opposite effect on the Southern Hemisphere which, except for the Antarctic, is largely moderated by the predominance of oceans covering the majority of the Southern Hemisphere. There are two other major Milankovitch cycles describing changes to the declination of the polar axis to the ecliptic and the degree of eccentricity of the Earth's orbit around the sun being tugged into more elongated to more circular orbit by the gravitational influence of Jupiter and Saturn. These are much longer and more variable cycles. The length of time continental glaciers persist after the climate shift that created them is significant, in fact many thousands of years. Except for Greenland and Antarctica the continental glaciers have all but disappeared except in high altitude or high latitude mountain ranges. If all of these mountain range glaciers disappeared (no evidence they are) it would not significantly alter sea level. Both Greenland and Antarctica are gaining more ice each year than lost to melt. About 500 billion tons on average for Greenland and somewhat less for Antarctic which holds some 90% of the worlds glacial ice with Greenland holding nearly 10% with a small fraction of only 1 percent being held on all the world's mountain glaciers. As Antarctic and Greenland ice continues to accumulate to levels that cannot be sustained by their surface areas it is balanced by continuous shedding of ice at their continental margins at the sea. This glacial flow movement can take centuries so there should be no alarm about annual as well as decadal minor variances in total ice inventories. It's all small change on a planetary scale. Recently Greenland set two new records for increases in it's Surface Mass Balance (the 2016-2017 ice season and the 2017-2018 ice season) The 2018-2019 ice season is not complete but it should be close to average. Politicians cannot alter this no matter what they propose to do to us.

+João Dalvi There should be yes. But I doubt it is measureable. Even the largest, dryest deserts are still a part of the global weather system which severely affects their temperature. You'd have to find some measurement from 30 years back, get incredibly lucky to have the exact same weather conditions as that measurement, not just for a day, but for months. And at that point, why not just do what we're already doing: Take the global temperature instead. A much simpler and accurate experiment can be done in the laboratory. @gasdive "No, they don't absorb, in the sense you use it here. They scatter or redirect the light." Hmmm, seems a bit fishy, all the top Climate Scientists say CO2 absorbs IR and that in turn heats the atmosphere and has increased the temp of the lower troposphere resulting in Global Warming, or Climate Chave as it now called since the increase in temps flattened out. I however, agree with you. It does not 'trap' or hold onto the IR, it simply absorbs and re-emits the IR quite quickly. IR has an interesting property that it shares with the entire electromagnetic spectrum, it travels at 300,000,000 meters per second. That is pretty quick. So, when the Earth emits some IR that CO2 absorbs (roughly 8% of the energy the Earth emits) the CO2 absorbs it and re-emits it almost instantly. 50% gets emitted skyward and 50% back towards Earth. I'm with you all on that. So suppose the CO2 absorbs the IR at 1 meter altitude and redirects back to Earth for one whole second. It will have made 150,000,000 trips between the Earth and CO2 molecule at 1 meter. This will never happen, on the second trip it will have a 50/50 chance of being emitted skyward. That happens in 1/150,000,000 seconds. Let's say the IR photon reaches the upper troposphere at 12,000 meters and gets absorbed and in effect gets reflected back and forth over 1 second. It will make 12,500 trips in one second, and any that make it out of the atmosphere will reach the Moon's orbit in a little over a second. Do you see the issue? Light travels really fast so even if the IR photon that CO2 absorbs is absorbed and emitted several thousand times over the course of a second it has thousands of opportunities to escape. Now I'm a little suspect as to how much of the IR that the Earth emits in the bands that CO2 absorbs is actually absorbed as well. There is just over 1 mole of CO2, about 45 grams, per cubic meter of dry air at sea level. Now that is a lot of molecules, but you have to think about the space 1 mole of CO2 takes up in a cubic meter. Very little. The number of moles goes down with humid air and goes down with altitude. Curious, is there less Global Warming in Denver than say Death Valley? There is less CO2. So my point is that given the Speed of Light, and that CO2 does not hold onto energy for very long, has a lower Specific Heat Capacity than N2, O2, H2O vapor, etc, CO2 does not cause Global Warming. The temp rises while the pressure remains relatively the same. PV=nRT So in order for the pressure to remain the same when Temps go up, the volume must also increase in tandem with temp. This is where Convection comes into play. When the volume increases and the pressure remains the same, the density decreases. The Earth's Gravity pulls more strongly on the cooler and more dense air above or around the heated and less dense air-mass and drags it to the surface. "These mechanisms do occur (not the heating the air directly, but the rest of it) but they don't increase the transfer of energy to space, they just move it around on Earth more vigorously." Our atmosphere is often called super thin, etc, but it is quite significant. The troposphere has a mass of 4,000 Trillion tons and has an altitude ranging from 6,000 meters at the poles to 18,000 at the Equator. It transports heat from one place on Earth to another also on Earth. The poles are pointed at an angle to the Sun, so they get less heat from the Sun. They pick up heat from the air (and water) and on average radiate more into space than they get from the sun. In the mid latitudes and the tropics you're pointed toward the sun. There the Sun delivers more energy than the ground radiates away. Heat gets into the air (and water) and is carried away. Because you live there you think of air as carrying heat away. If you lived in the poles you'd think the opposite. Air (and water) brings heat. As far as the Earth as a whole is concerned, it does neither. Just moves it around on the surface. Okay, so H2O, CO2, CH4, and a perhaps a few more compounds absorb a few IR bands and heat up the atmosphere around them. No, they don't absorb, in the sense you use it here. They scatter or redirect the light. It happens pretty much evenly through the atmosphere however if you think about say a swimming pool. You look down into it and you can see the bottom. The light is coming up from there. It starts to get an algal bloom and it gets harder and harder to see the bottom. Eventually you can see the bottom, but it's faint. Then beyond that you can't see the bottom, but you can see some distance down. As the bloom gets thicker and thicker what looks like the bottom of the pool gets closer and closer to the surface. It's not *exactly* like that but that's a good way to think of it. The "surface" as seen from above gets closer and closer to the top of the atmosphere. It's an effect that's very important in a runaway situation. The upper cloud tops become the place that the Earth is radiating light into space instead of the ground. That decouples the ground temperature from the feedback loop. That's what's happened to Venus. If you look down at Venus it looks cool in the IR light but that's because you can only see down to the cloud tops. The surface below that is much hotter. The visible light gets down to the ground, but the IR has a long and difficult journey to get to the cloud tops. @gasdive Okay, so we have a minor disagreement on whether 'greenhouse effect' is okay or not. Black holes are black, they do not emit or reflect light, less you include Hawking radiation, but they are black for practical sake. They are also holes, an example of Runaway gravity of sorts. The Wishbone or Forks look like a wishbone or fork (2 pronged). Greenhouses are fixed structures that prevent convection. The Troposphere where almost all life exists is 80% of a 5,000 trillion ton atmosphere that is a 24/7 convection system. However, I'm not sure this hiccup is something to get hung up on. I just think holding onto the analogy is helping you and other AGW advocates miss some important phenomena that is occurring whilst CO2 is absorbing what can be considered a fairly low frequency/energy and not much of it. I've heard this 30 degrees cooler scenario before, but is was not explained. If you stripped away the atmosphere you have a vacuum so you only have radiation to cool the surface. The daytime temps I would think would be very high and I'd be curious to see how long it would take the surface to cool without the aid of convection. I'm not really sure that the average of -18C means much. Without an atmosphere to absorb much of the heat from the surface during the day, and one to hold onto heat at night, there would be wold extremes, which leads to me a new question. If you removed all the so-called greenhouse gases from our atmosphere and were left with 4,950 trillion tons of N2 and O2, would there be a 'greenhouse effect'?

PART TWO If you just stripped away the atmosphere and left everything the same (by which I mean kept the reflectivity or “albedo” of the earth the same) the average temperature would be about minus 18 degrees C. You can work this out yourself if you want, the maths is doable but it's a bit involved for a Youtube post... https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefan-Boltzmann_law So what happens in reality is this. The light from the Sun passes through the atmosphere almost unhindered. That's why you can look up and see the Sun! Just comes in straight through the atmosphere. Bam, it slams into the Earth at the speed of light and some is reflected (which is why you can see the Earth from space) and some is absorbed. The absorbed light heats the Earth, raising its temperature. So it emits light too, but lower frequency (we call that InfraRed but it's just light we can't see). That light doesn't pass through the air as easily. Light that hits molecules with three atoms is absorbed and then re-emitted in a random direction. “Scattered” is the right term. You can see a similar thing in visible light in a fog. The droplets of water scatter visible light in a similar way (not the same, but very similar in effect) Some of that light gets scattered back to Earth so it never gets away. If you were looking down at the Earth in the InfraRed spectrum you'd still be able to make out the ground, just, but the air would look foggy or hazy. So the ground would start to heat up. More light is arriving from the sun than is able to leave through the atmosphere. As the ground heats up it emits more and more light until it's emitting so much that it shines through the InfraRed haze and equals the amount of light coming in. That's why it's 15 degrees C on average rather than minus 18 degrees C. So, that has a couple of effects. Firstly water is a bit snooty. As much as it can it behaves as though the air simply wasn't there. It maintains a pressure (Vapour Pressure) that's the same as the pressure you'd have in a closed flask that had a puddle of water in it, but you'd pumped out all the air. If you pressurise it to higher than that or cool it, then it turns back into water. You might have experience with compressed air. You'd know that you have to regularly drain the water out. That's the snooty water. It's no greater a percentage of the air in the compressor than it was outside, but you've raised the water vapour pressure higher than it would have been in a closed flask with no air, so it turns back into water. So, the amount of water in the atmosphere is dependent on the temperature. More temperature means more water. Water is one of those molecules in the air that has three atoms (two Hydrogens and an Oxygen). So more water also means it's harder for the light to get out from the ground to space. That sounds like it should just runaway and turn all the water to vapour. It doesn't because we're saved by that 4th power I mentioned. As the temperature goes up the amount of light the earth emits goes up faster than the increase in water vapour. That's good, that means we don't boil the oceans. However in the opposite direction, we're not saved. Near freezing point the water nearly all turns into solid water and the vapour pressure gets very low. If we were able to freeze the world down to minus 18 and then just step back and let it run, it wouldn't warm back up again. There wouldn't be enough water in the air. In fact because snow reflects more light than water or ground, it would reflect more of the sun's light and the temperature would actually fall even further. It all sounds a bit unstable. That's because it is unstable with just water. Water does the heavy lifting as far as keeping us warm, but it's too unstable to do a good job. When the going gets hard it turns into snow. So what keeps it stable enough for life? CO2. It's another 3 atom molecule. It's a slightly different shape and size to water so it scatters a different frequency of light (still InfraRed). It doesn't freeze out of the atmosphere (well, not on Earth anyway, it does on Mars). It keeps the Earth warm enough that there is liquid water on the surface and that means there's enough water vapour to keep us warm. It acts as a sort of master control for the whole system. Now if you increase the amount of CO2 it scatters more light which makes it warmer. Because it's warmer the vapour pressure of water goes up, which scatters more light. Again it sounds like we're headed for disaster but the 4th power steps in again and saves us (just, there's actually not all that much in it, I can write more on that if you like, but the consensus is that it's unlikely to boil off the oceans, not out of the question, but unlikely). That was a big gulp. Questions?

I'll make this two posts, READ THIS ONE FIRST. Well to start backwards, I think "Greenhouse" is ok. Everyone knows what we're talking about. A "Black Hole" is neither black nor a hole. Words change meaning all the time. In Italian, the bit that holds the front wheel of a bicycle is a "Wishbone", in English it's "Fork". In reality it's neither a fork nor a wishbone, but people know what you mean. That's how languages work. It is a sort of emissivity/absorption effect. Energy arrives on Earth as light from the sun, from just one direction (the sun's direction). It leaves in all directions. If the amount of heat in the planet stays the same then the amount of energy arriving equals the amount of energy leaving exactly. (Heat isn't temperature BTW, I mean *HEAT*, I don't mean temperature, more on that later) Everything emits light. You, me, the sun, the earth. The frequency of the light depends on the temperature. That's a quantum mechanical effect and I said I'd get a bit hand wavy at that point. Don't worry, AGW was discovered before quantum mechanics. You can just take that as a fact rather than trying to derive it from quantum theory. Hot things emit more photons and those photons carry more energy. That way you end up with a fourth power. Double the temperature and the power (power is energy per unit time) goes up not twice, but 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 times more. 3 times the temperature 3 x 3 x 3 x 3 times more. So the practical upshot is that the earth is heated only on one side. It intercepts light from the sun in a circle that has the area of a circle with diameter the same as the diameter of the earth. (makes sense...) It emits light over an area that's a sphere with diameter of the earth. 4 times bigger. So the earth is like a big frequency converter. It takes the high frequency light from the sun on one side and sends it out into space in all directions at a lower frequency (because it's colder than the sun) There are other sources of heat, radioactive decay, tidal warping (which is driven by orbital energy from the moon) and the energy of dust hitting the atmosphere (shooting stars). These sources of energy are completely insignificant and can be ignored. Now if that was the end of the story the surface temperature needed to re-emit the same amount of energy that arrives from the sun is about 30 degrees lower than the current average temperature.  TO BE CONTINUED IN THE NEXT POST.

Ever since the whole global-warming fracas began, the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) has been fudging and faking evidence and statistics in order to give the illusion that there was proof of human-caused global warming.

This is well known, though unmentioned by our monolithic true-believer media, whose science coverage has become a mere church choir in the religion of eco-puritanism.

The IPCC have performed illegitimate and unjustified statistical manipulations; they have reworded reports after scientists signed off on them, and without their knowledge.

These are the kinds of things that you only do when you know that the evidence does not make your case. Nobody steals an election they've actually won.

Through all of this, they have insisted that human-caused global warming is a fact, and that anyone who resists it is in the same category as creationists and holocaust-deniers.

This namecalling is another confession that they haven't got the data to make their case. If you have the data, you don't have to call names. The science speaks for itself.

One reason they have been able to get away with this is the lack of data to contradict them. That is, the data we have had up to now did not say what they claim it said -- but it didn't say anything else, either.

That's because everything was based on computer models, and computer models are only as good as the data that is fed into them. The people running the simulations were all True Believers, and so they always came up with "results" that mirrored the biased data they had been fed.

But finally there is real data to feed into the computers. In a Dec. 18th Wall Street Journal essay, Matt Ridley reports on a conversation with Nic Lewis, one of the educated people keeping tabs on the global warming science issues for those of us who don't have access to the latest reports.

If it weren't for people like Lewis, we laypeople would have no choice but to believe the deceptions of True Believers like the IPCC. Lewis is part of the reason we know about the previous lies and manipulations by the IPCC, but no one denies that the deceptions took place.

Now, however, because Lewis is an honest observer, he reports that real data shows that there is a genuine statistically probable effect from atmospheric carbon emissions.

What genuine scientists, faithfully reporting their actual findings, now report is that the mechanisms claimed to cause global warming may in fact contribute to a rise in temperature -- but they do so at a rate FAR, FAR LOWER than that assumed by the True Believers.

We are finally getting a pretty good idea of the actual effects of carbon dioxide emissions. Comparing global temperatures over the past 100-150 years with the fluctuations in carbon dioxide emissions from human activities gives us -- at last -- a reasonable basis for estimating how sensitive global climate is to changes in carbon dioxide levels.

Keep in mind that carbon dioxide is far from being the major greenhouse gas. Methane is far more important, and the most important, water vapor, has such unpredictable effects that it is left out of all the models.

That's because water vapor, besides being a greenhouse gas, also forms clouds, which by their high reflectivity, bounce sunlight out of the atmosphere without converting it to heat. Storms also funnel heat from near the surface up to the higher atmosphere.

We have no way of predicting or modeling how much the albedo and storm effects balance with the greenhouse effect, nor even to what degree global warming would increase cloud cover.

As Ridley says in his article, "As one Nobel Prize-winning physicist with a senior role in combating climate change admitted to me the other day: 'We don't even know the sign' of water vapor's effect -- in other words, whether it speeds up or slows down a warming of the atmosphere."

Says Ridley, "Climate models are known to poorly simulate clouds, and given clouds' very strong effect on the climate system -- some types cooling the Earth either by shading it or by transporting heat up and cold down in thunderstorms, and others warming the Earth by blocking outgoing radiation -- it remains highly plausible that there is no net positive feedback from water vapor."

This matters a great deal -- the global warming alarmists' warnings absolutely depend on the idea that carbon dioxide's warming, if real, will then be greatly amplified by water vapor increases. But this remains entirely a matter of faith. For all we know, increased water vapor may be the ecosystem's natural way of damping down the effects of global warming -- whether that warming is astronomical or human caused.

We can now calculate with some reliability just what a doubling of the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere would do to global climate. "Given what we know now," said Ridley, "there is almost no way that the feared large temperature rise is going to happen."

Ridley quotes Lewis as saying that, assuming a doubling of CO2 -- the IPCC's worst-case scenario -- and even assuming "another 30% rise from other greenhouse gases by 2100, we are likely to experience a further rise of no more than" one degree Celsius.

Says Ridley, "A cumulative change of less than 2O C by the end of this century will do no net harm. It will actually do net good -- that much the IPCC scientists have already agreed upon in the last IPCC report. Rainfall will increase slightly, growing seasons will lengthen, Greenland's ice cap will melt only very slowly."

Historical evidence shows that global temperatures have been warmer than they are now, following natural cycles alone, in historical times. There seems to be a regular warming-and-cooling cycle, with cooling represented by the Little Ice Age of 1350 to 1850. In 1000 a.d., global climate was warmer than it is now.

The same cycle seems to have corresponded with the collapse of agriculture and population during the cooling phase in the late Roman Empire and through the Dark Ages -- a plague-ridden era like the Little Ice Age.

The historical evidence suggests that eras of global warming are natural, that they are beneficial, that they can best be called "good weather."

When you add to this the fact that all of human history has taken place in a ten thousand year lull in the great Ice Age that has dominated the last million years of Earth's climate history, and I, for one, wish that we could control and warm the climate through mere carbon dioxide emissions -- because when the major astronomical cycles bring back the Ice Age, our descendants will very much wish for a means of causing global warming on a vast scale.

Meanwhile, keep in mind that there is nothing unnatural about the carbon dioxide we release into the atmosphere. All the carbon in the coal and oil and natural gas that we dig or pump up from under the surface was once atmospheric carbon dioxide.

Carbon dioxide is fertilizer for all plant life. For millions of years, the coastal jungles of the dinosaur era sequestered natural atmospheric carbon dioxide and kept it out of circulation.

In effect, we have starved for CO2 for millions of years because all those plants selfishly drank up all the atmospheric carbon they could and then thoughtlessly died without returning it to the atmosphere.

We're only putting it back where it started.

And every serious climate scientist has to admit this fact: Whatever else our carbon dioxide emissions might be doing, they are definitely fertilizing forests and grasslands all around the world. Where humans are involved, that means orchards and grainfields.

If we really did reduce our CO2 emissions, it would cause a worldwide decrease in crop yields. That's a fact, not a computer model.

The real limiting factor should be this: The supply of oil and coal is finite. It was larger than the alarmists of the 1970s and 1980s supposed, but that doesn't mean that we will never run out. It is quite possible that in a mere two centuries of fossil fuel consumption, we will use up the entire supply of accessible sequestered carbon.

That, not groundless fears of global warming, is the reason we need to find other means of generating energy. Instead of worrying about carbon emissions, we need to search desperately for a means of powering our transportation and heating and cooling our habitations that does not depend on a resource that, once it runs out, is gone forever.

My fear is that because of all the lies and deceptions, all the oppression of dissent and nastiness of the global warming alarmists, the general public, once free of those delusions and lies, will think that all warnings and dangers are false.

In other words, we have been through three decades of massive wolf-crying about a nonexistent wolf, so that people won't believe in the need to deal with the real wolf of depleting resources.

We have a responsibility to future generations to leave them with the resources necessary to sustain a modern society. It is a sin to burn it all up when we don't have to. CO2 is a non-issue and always has been -- only the eco-puritans took it seriously and then foisted it on laypeople who trusted in "science."

The net effect of their falsehoods will be a loss of trust in real science, and that's a crime. Because there are dangers to the environment, and serious consequence from burning up resources that can never be renewed. And thanks to the global warming clowns, I fear that nobody will pay attention.

There is a disproportionate biomass of humans on the earth, and our brains make us much more energy intensive than most other organisms. Surely, if cows were to blame, then people would be too? But we're not. Because cows eat grass. All the carbon in that grass was taken from the air. So even when we eat a steak and release that carbon in our breath, there is no net change in atmospheric CO2. So how are cows to blame? Well, cows actually release a lot of methane, a more potent greenhouse gas than CO2. If this is how you count it, the cow population has an exorbitant effect on emissions. But methane decays into CO2 in the upper atmosphere - finally releasing CO2 the grass sequestered - so its effect is limited as the atmosphere returns to its pre-cow state. This means the only effect that cows have on global warming is sustaining a small amount of methane in the upper atmosphere. Surely can't have nearly as much effect as the Gigatonnes of CO2 released by industry every year?

@nathan schommer Don';t, but cutting back on how much meat you eat gets you proportional benefits. So if you're a typical Westerner and eat meat 2-3 times a day, cutting meat back to once a day, eating smaller portions (no giant slabs of steak every night, if you want them, they represent a couple days worth of meat) can reduce your meat footprint by 50-67%. After that you could work to incorporating non-meat sources of protein and so on into your diet, maybe only eating meat every other day. Bam, no you've reduced your meat intake by 75-90%, and you're still eating meat several times a week. I love meat, but I don't need it every meal of every day, and I've grown bored after a childhood of meat slabs every night. In fact, I tend to enjoy dishes with smaller pieces of meat mixed in, like tiny strips of meat cooked up and mixed into a stirfry, or in a stew. Got a steak? Cut it up, and you have enough meat for several meals of stir fry. There's a good middle ground between eating all the meat and eating none of it. Don't fall victim to the "all or nothing" notion that prevents people from taking any progressive action.

The above video contains a classic example of conflation which is regularly peddled on this topic:

"The vast majority of climate scientists agree that climate change is happening .. and that humans are playing a significant role .. and vested interests will lose if a price is placed on carbon ..."
 
Firstly ... YES, there is overwhelming evidence the climate changes. It always has and always will. It would be EXTREMELY ODD if the vast majority of climate scientists didn't recognise this fundamental property of the climate.

Secondly ... YES, human activities can influence climate. Including urbanisation, deforestation, reforestation, agriculture, irrigation, water abstraction and others.  In addition, to this "significant" is vague.

BUT, you then slip-in references to carbon to plant an idea that there is consensus on CO2 emissions.

In retail, this is called a bait-and-switch scam (advertise one thing, but try to sell another). 

So where is it getting you.  Is the public queueing at your shop door?  NO THEY ARE NOT.   So you wonder why your shop has no customers and the only answer you can come up with is imaginary demons of vested interests. 

Please stop and take a look at yourself. How long will it take before you realise this is not working. The world is turning its back on you, and it is nothing more than you deserve.

You asked: "of .. 97% of scientists that formed the consensus that MMCO2 is the Major contributor what % actually said that?" The straight answer is: not many. The consensus argument often appears, but it involves a sleight of hand. Consider the following: 1. CO2 is a greenhouse gas. 2. Data shows that pCO2 is increasing and we know man emits CO2. 3. Man has an impact on the climate. 4. We have to reduce CO2 to save the planet from catastrophic warming. The first 3 points are basic uncontentious issues. Few (possibly no) scientists would disagree with any of these. For example, agriculture and urbanisation are reasons to consider a human influence on the climate. Consensus surveys concentrate on the first three points.  Surveys never directly test point 4. However when it comes to discussing the consensus, point 4 is usually conflated with the others. An example is about 2.41 in the video. A range of temperature rises are mentioned (1.4 to 2.6 degC with a 90% confidence interval). It is commonly recognised that the lower range is not a problem. So he is right to say the scientists are offering carefully worded predictions, but scientists are NOT having an issue with communicating this to the public. It is the activists in Big Green that have a problem convincing the public of their POV. About 2.00 the presenter mentions consensus (grounded in points 1-3), and then seamlessly moves onto talking about "carbon". No effort is made to say "scientists agree that human CO2 emissions will cause a climate catastrophe" (or words to that effect) Bear in mind that the video is sponsored by the Climate Reality Project (as declared at the end) - or "Al Gore and his friends" to borrow the presenter's words.

@ginckgo Well, yes, SCIENTISTS are. It is very potent, granted. However, most people don't seem to be. They seem to be all about CO2, which isn't the only problem. I'm not saying humans haven't caused global warming/climate change (whatever); I'm saying they aren't causing it as much as everyone predicts. Not to be an ass, but you spelled "milankovitch" wrong, I believe. Just for reference

First, look up "Milankovic Cycles" - you'll notice how three factors in Earth's orbit accurately predict when Glacial/Interglacial cycles happen. Then look up "CO2 Feedback" - you'll find out that the slight change in insolation from the orbital cycles is not enough by itself to change the climate as much as it did. Now back to Milankovic: you'll notice how the Holocene Interglacial is unique in that the orbital cycles are aligned such that the interglacial conditions will continue for tens of thousands more years (unlike previous interglacial which lasted less than 10 thousand) Now back to the CO2: humans are on track to double the CO2 content in the atmosphere from pre-inductrial levels, which is universally agreed (even by skeptics) to cause warming. How much? the consensus is that by 2100 it will be about 3 degrees C. And please don't mention the 'pause': we are currently in the quietest sun in over a century, plus all other natural factors should be driving a cooling; yet the world has had the hottest 10 years since record in the past 15 years. Wait for the the next massive step up in temps once the natural forcings change polarity again. Oh, and scientists are VERY worried about methane (just because you own personal news sources don't report that fact, doesn't mean they don't) - both agricultural and permafrost melt.

Just another thing to point out- these predictions are based on trend lines. Trend lines change. If you tried to draw a trend line to show how tall an average human would be at 30 years old, but only had the data until that human was 17 or so (the end of puberty), then you could predict that that human would grow to be 30 feet tall. We don't know all the data. We cannot make predictions about climate change because there isn't enough data.

@1965ace Researchers studying global warming have often been confounded by the differences between observed increases in surface-level temperatures and unchanging low-atmosphere temperatures. Because of this discrepancy, some have argued that global warming is unproven, suggesting instead that true warming should show uniformly elevated temperatures from the surface through the atmosphere. Researchers have proposed a theory that changes in cloud cover could help explain the puzzling phenomenon, but none-until now-have come up with an argument that could account for the varying heat profiles. Share This Email to a friend Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Google+ Print this page WASHINGTON - Researchers studying global warming have often been confounded by the differences between observed increases in surface-level temperatures and unchanging low-atmosphere temperatures. Because of this discrepancy, some have argued that global warming is unproven, suggesting instead that true warming should show uniformly elevated temperatures from the surface through the atmosphere. Researchers have proposed a theory that changes in cloud cover could help explain the puzzling phenomenon, but none-until now-have come up with an argument that could account for the varying heat profiles. Related Articles Attribution of recent climate change Global warming Greenhouse effect Sulfur hexafluoride Temperature record of the past 1000 years Climate change mitigation A study in the July 2002 issue of Journal of Geophysical Research-Space Physics, published by the American Geophysical Union, proposes for the first time that interstellar cosmic rays could be the missing link between the discordant temperatures observed during the last two decades (since recorded satellite records began in 1979). The report, by Fangqun Yu of the State University of New York-Albany, proposes that the rays, tiny charged particles that bombard all planets with varying frequency depending on solar wind intensity, may have height-dependent effects on our planet's cloudiness. Previous research has proposed a link between cosmic rays and cloud cover, has not suggested the altitude dependence of the current study. "A systematic change in global cloud cover will change the atmospheric heating profile," Yu said. "In other words, the cosmic ray-induced global cloud changes could be the long-sought mechanism connecting solar and climate variability." The hypothesis, if confirmed, could also shed light on the Sun's role in global warming. The amount of cosmic rays reaching Earth depends on solar winds, which vary in strength by space-weather conditions. Yu points out that indications of Earth's warming have coincided with decreased cosmic ray intensity during the 20th century. @1965ace A good example of getting your science third hand through biased media. Scientists have been improving their models of what's happening, but they have always understood that there are dozens of factors that contribute, like urban heat island effect, land use, vulcanism, insolation, etc. None of these are news to climate scientists, but the deniers keep on insisting it is only they that have discovered these factors. @Ravioli Hog CO2 doesn't have anything to do with the ozone hole: Explanation: Incoming sunlight makes the earth hotter. The more sunlight gets reflected the less heat gets in. Now everything that is hot radiates electromagnetic waves, the hotter the higher the frequency. The earth mostly radiates infrared waves and this is the outgoing radiation. (The sun is hotter -> higher frequencys) So you have incoming heat in the high frequency spectrum. And outgoing heat in the low frequency spectrum. So there is a balance. Now CO2 absorbs outgoing low frequency radiation that normaly gets through without a problem. If this radiation gets blocked by the CO2 the heat stays in. That is the greenhouse effect. If the same amount comes in but less goes out the heat increases. And you can actually prove that CO2 absorbs low freqency electromagnetic waves. And it is proven. It is a little simplified (I left out radiation windows) but it will do. Does it matter? - 1-2°C maybe doesn't sound like much but it is the average! Climate change also means that temperature differences become more extreme. Why? Because at the equator more radiation is incoming - so less outgoing radiation makes a bigger difference there. While the difference is smaller in colder areas. Extremer temperatures are bad alone. - But higher temperature differences also cause winds (which are basically heat exchanger) to get stronger. Say hello, to stronger hurricans americans! - And the change of the climate disrupts a lot of balanced water/air circuits. There are some reasonable theorys that the gulfstream might be stopped because of that. (I won't explain that because I am not an expert and I may explain something wrong. You just think it could be insulting to let people know that they are catastrophists.

@gufpott Why oh why does every discussion on science feel the same, same tactics, same language, same fallacies.... Be it evolution, vaccines, plate tectonics, you name it. Yes, we are both 'outsiders' to a very complex field of science, that is very multidisciplinary. And that is exactly why trusting the scientists over your own personal beliefs is the way to go. Are there any other 'controversial' science topics (such as from my list above) that you also think you have figured it out better than the scientists, and that they are all wrong and hiding the truth? Because exactly the same accusations happen in those fields. "Denier" is perfectly factual in this situation, because the fact of the matter is that you deny the mainstream science view (you also deny the scientific method and the honesty of the scientists). Creationists are also science deniers. Vaccine opponents are also science deniers. Expanding Earthers are also science deniers (for the most part anyway). Poisoning the well is only a fallacy (an informal one at that) is it is purely used to denigrate the opponent and make their position look weak. Calling you a science denier because you deny the science is not that. Ah, the current favourite of the climate deniers: a comparison with Lysenko. Rather ironic really, considering it would be more appropriate the other way round.  An  individual who rejects the mainstream science, gets the support of a politician who is trying to maintain a clearly failing old system (any one today in the pockets of fossil fuels), suppresses actual science (look at what has happened in places like Canada and Australia to climate scientists who dare say that AGW is real), and eventually causes disaster. As for the term "Climacatastrophology", I don't have a problem with the word as such, but rather with the subtext you put on it by how you use it to be an insult. As exemplified by the fact that you think that the ending "ology" is specific to astrology, while it simply means "the study of..."

@ginckgo Climate Sensitivity is controversial, and the main controversy is speculated feedback process supposed to amplify sensitivity.  Without these, CS would be around 1 degC/doubling. But that wouldn't support the prophesy of catastrophe. We are all "outsiders" on so many issues, but we are entitled to have a view to help us protect ourselves against wrong-doing. You do it and so do I. So let's not have the "outsider" nonsense. You poisoned your own debate when you used the word "denier". You cannot explain what I am supposed to be denying. If you sense that somebody doesn't immediately agree with your ideology, you prefer to denounce them rather than find out what they have to say. It is intellectual  laziness and cowardice. Lysenko did the same. He preferred to denounce geneticists as "fly lovers and people haters" to shelter his junk ideology from scrutiny and the scientific method. On "Climacatastrophology" .... "Clima" = climate.  More specifically, the Enhanced Greenhouse Effect.  Not recent weather or any other conflation of issues. "catastro" = catastrophe and doomsaying. Not vague notions of climate change or other distractions.  "astr ... ology" = astrology.  People who produce prophecies and have a poor track record of prediction. Their record cannot be distinguished from random chance. If you find Climastrolphoogy to be  hurtful or offensive, which part of it do you think causes you the most pain?  I'd like to know which of the component parts relates to you.

@gufpott A climate sensitivity of less than 1C per CO2 doubling is well below any mainstream estimate, so very controversial. The majority put the lower end at 1.5C, while the upper estimate hovers around 3C. I know that there are various 'outsiders' who think they have calculated the latest fatal flaw in the GHG theory, but inevitably it turns out they have missed some crucial aspect, largely due to the fact that they are working outside of their field of expertise - climate science is multidisciplinary by definition. I'm pretty sure Santer et al found that found the supporting data for the models, but deniers have misrepresented (or misunderstood) the whole thing and propagated the opposite conclusion to the actual research. Finally, don't you think it ironic that you accuse me of an ad hominem (BTW, calling someone a science denier is not a fallacy if they actually deny the science), while at the same time throwing about the term "Climacatastrophology"? Add to that a nice dose of poisoning the well with "Lysenkoism" (again ironic that you say "junk science was propped up by attacking and denouncing opponents, rather than examining the evidence", when scientists have suffered exactly this for decades now from the deniers)

@ginckgo Even I agree that there could be some difference in temperature due to increasing pCO2.  Declaring that there is some consensus on this is a completely redundant point. I'm not aware anybody challenges the greenhouse effect.  I have seen interesting discussions the detailed physics of absorbtion specrtra and thermalisation which explore the processes of "sharing" temperature change with other gas molecules (whose emissions spectra are not in the IR bands). And I have seen comparisons using the gas laws. But nothing which particularly challenges the greenhouse effect. Returning to the omens of Climacatastrophology, Climate Sensitivity is a central issue.  This focuses on the incremental effect of increasing pCO2.  Beer's Law tells us that the slope of Climate Sensitivity should reduce for increasing pCO2, and a logarithmic response is expected.  Starting from pre-industrial pCO2, Beer's Law suggests Climate Sensitivity should be quite small. Perhaps less than 1 degC/doubling pCO2. This isn't particularly controversial and I would be surprised if you wanted to debate this. But Climacatastropohology cannot exist with low Climate Sensitivity. A much higher value is needed to develop arguments of future catastrophe.  Speculative arguments of amplification are introduced, but these are controversial (even the IPCC acknowledges them as uncertain). Amplification is not supported by data. Clive Best looked at NASA's NVAP data and concluded there was no evidence of recent increase in atmospheric water vapour. Polar ice albedo change was supposed to increase net warming. But global ice cover anomaly is about +1 million square kilometres and is evidence of a compensating feedback which constrains Climate Sensitivity, rather than amplifies it. Climate Sensitivity could easily be small  and the longer the "Pause" continues, the more likely the evidence will support low Climate Sensitivity.  It couldn't be any other way if there has been no temperature rise for 15 years, just when pCO2 reaches higher values than recent history. If further evidence was required, climate modelling by Santer et al anticipated a tropospheric hotspot pattern for the Enhanced Greenhouse Effect. This  including arguments about amplification.  He went looking for it (specifically the "vertical amplification" = temperature aloft in the tropics should be higher than at the surface) and reported that it wasn't observed.  According to the scientific method, this is called falsification by data. And it doesn't look like anybody is likely to change Santer's conclusions anytime soon. There hasn't been any surface warming for 15 years and there hasn't been any warming aloft in the predicted hotspot zone. Without the supporting evidence of the predicted hotspot pattern of the Enhanced Greenhouse Effect, NONE of the recent warming can be attributed to the Enhanced Greenhouse Effect.  This is a dead parrot. So what is all the fuss about?  Why have we been hearing the wailings of the Climacatastrophologers about "x-years-to-save-this-and-that" for years now? That's why I compared it to homeopathy and theology.  I agree that there is no scientific merit in either of these because the central premise of each cannot be supported by evidence and data. The same is true of Climacatstrophology predictions of catastrophic temperature rise, amplification of Climate Sensitivity, loss of polar ice, and the hotspot (amongst other things).  I cannot think of a single prediction from Climacatastrophology which has been shown to be correct. And why resort to ad-hominem attack? Is the word "denier" something you need to use to help try to justify yourself?  Search for "Lysenkoism" to read about a case where junk science was propped up by attacking and denouncing opponents, rather than examining the evidence (there is a decent wiki on it).

@gufpott Yes, the real debate in climate science is about how much global temps will rise for a doubling of CO2. But there IS a consensus that they will rise, and do so significantly, a minimum of 1 or 2C. Yet many deniers tell us that there will be no rise, because apparently the greenhouse gas theory is bogus. Do you agree with the latter?!? There have been several 'pauses' over time (most recently the 50s and 60s), nobody is surprised that the temperature doesn't rise smoothly, and unless it actually starts cooling significantly, this 'pause' is not the problem it's being made out to be. Of course scientists are going to look for possible explanations for the 'pause', rather then instantly throwing their hands up and saying "oh well, guess we were wrong". No theory would ever survive that attitude. As long as the explanations do not break other science there is no problem in modifying a theory. It's happened numerous times with Evolution, and has strengthened it, while at the same time creationists accuse scientists that they are desperately propping up a failing theory even though it hadn't predicted a particular bit of data. Sound familiar? What an idiotic attempt at "turning around the question": I base my view on homeopathy on science that has been published, showing it does not and cannot work, while the practitioners are involved in biased self-deception. My acceptance of climate science is exactly the same. How come you have an insight into climate science that the practicing scientists don't? Or do you believe in the lunatic fringe conspiracy theories?!?

@ginckgo OKaaaay.  On the prediction of CO2-induced climate change, there is nothing like scientific consensus on matters such as Climate Sensitivity (very many recent papers). And past predictions of rising temperature are now being seriously challenged by "the Pause", and the predicted tropospheric hotspot was never observed. There are numerous ideas coming forth to try to find new physical processes to reconcile past predictions of rising temperature with the Pause (such as "the ocean ate my global warming"). However, these new attempts to embellish the supposedly infallible climate  models just help to demonstrate that past predictions were wrong and the model are fallible after all. It is an odd kind of consensus with all of the above going on.  But hey, you are entitled to your view. Therefore, to reflect your own question back:  how come you have an insight into the alleged fatal flaws of theology and homeopathy that thousands of practitioners have overlooked? It's not that I personally accept either theology or homeopathy (so don't go there), but you seem to expect others to respect your right to lay opinion on any range of matters, while you do not respect other opinions. You are not going to convince many with that kind of attitude.

I think the part that should interest you is: WHY do you disagree with the scientific consensus on this particular topic? Do you ridicule those that disagree with the scientific consensus on Evolution? On the Big Bang? On Plate Tectonics? On Germ Theory? How come you personally have an insight into the alleged fatal flaws of climate change theory that thousands of practicing scientists have overlooked?

Climate change is a huge issue, but making a carbon tax is NOT the best answer by a long shot.  There is already a plan that can be put into action for less money than Al Gore personally spends on AWARENESS alone, that can completely negate our carbon emissions.  One of the biggest problems coming at the problem from the angle that you need to stop carbon emissions, is that it can ruin economies.  The idea is called "Project Garden Hose the the Sky"- No joke.  It has been written about is books like Freakonomics.  It's a REAL solution that is CHEAP and EFFECTIVE.  The thing about regulations like carbon taxes is that it winds up causing some serious economic problems.  Think for one second about those billionaires in the mansions for a minute, and realize that their money wouldn't begin to cover how much it would cost to stop or nearly stop all human CO2 production. 
    There is also other really big ideas (found in a TED talk I watched recently) about how desertification is making a huge contribution to negative climate change.  It was once thought for quite a long time, in fact, that herd animals would, by the nature of them walking on grasslands, destroy the grass.  So people went out and killed thousands of elephants and the like just to realize the problem was getting even worse.  The desertification of grasslands was speeding up where they were doing this.  The solution was just the opposite of what that original common sense told them.  The herd animals somehow create and expand this grassland. The solution was to have the people's farm animals rotate where they would graze frequently (essentially) so now it's possible that the Sahara desert might not even be a desert after some decades (or something like that- go watch the video for yourself! It's truly fascinating!).
    I really hope that people start to realize that a carbon tax isn't the best answer, nor the only answer out there.  And that it actually might be quite a bad one.  Keep in mind that most of these laws and ideas like the carbon tax come from politicians that are using the law to get votes NOT because it's necessarily a GOOD idea.

I agree with the (Freeman) Dysonian view on the topic. There are other vastly more pressing environmental concerns and the models are just too unpredictable to make any real conclusion on what the world will look like in 50 years due to greenhouse gas emissions. The catastrophizing of the situation by many "scientists" is very alarming to me, and much more so than the ignorance of the public. Why? Because it is malignantly dishonest. The truth is somewhere in the middle, yes humans are affecting the global temperature of the world, and yes it will have some negative (and also positive, look up the legitimate scientific studies by climatologists) effects. Overall I believe the net effect will be negative, but it is certainly not the "armageddon" that this video and others try to make it out to be. That is just a baseless prediction with no empirical reasoning behind it, just a faith in models that aren't very soundproof. The basis of science is empiricism. And you must not only look at this issue from a scientific perspective, but also a cost-benefit analysis perspective. For many, the cost of greenhouse emissions does not exceed either the short term nor long term benefits.
