HEY DEREK! Not sure if somebody has answered your question about why Australia repealed it's carbon tax.

The new Prime Minister of Australia, Tony Abbot (I say new, but he was elected about a year ago) was opposed to the "Carbon Tax" when past Prime Minister Julia Gillard first proposed it since she had originally said that she wouldn't, Abbot considered it a breach of the trust of the Australian people, and used to it prop up his attack-dog tactics that resulted in him winning the election. Abbot made a big fuss about how much the carbon price would affect families and regular people day to day life, claiming that annual expenses would increase everywhere, even down to the weekly groceries. He called it the "The big new tax" or something like that, and made it his key election promise that he would remove the carbon tax if he was elected to office.
That is how it happened in the public's eye, but the reasons behind repealing the carbon price was not the attempt to make good on Julia Gillard's promise she made 5 years ago, but it's because Australia's biggest exports are Iron Ore and Coal. Both are heavily polluting industries that were hit fairly hard by the carbon tax, The mining industry in Western Australia was the major factor in keeping Australia from going into recession along with the rest of the world in the GFC (the then-government's "stimulus package" also played a role). Essentially, due to the global economy still being shaky, and Australia having a less-than-perfect economy currently, Tony Abbot didn't want to do anything that would hold back our biggest industries.

GREAT video!!!  However...  I think you seriously downplay the benefits of recycling too much.  Remember everything is cumulative, and that is something every person has direct influence over.

PLASTIC!  2.7% of the total U.S. petroleum consumption (191 million barrels) AND 1.7% of the total U.S. natural gas consumption (412 billion cubic feet) is used to manufacture plastic.  On top of that, 1.7% of the total U.S. electricity consumption (65 billion kilowatt-hours) is used to manufacture plastic—in turn it take 70.85 billion pounds of coal, or 65 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, or 5.2 billion gallons of petroleum to generate that electricity.  I understand percentagewise it is small, but it adds up.  In 2009, almost 30 million tons of plastics were generated in the United States, and only 2.12 million tons were recovered (only 7.1%).  Every pound of recycled plastic used in place of virgin material reduces energy use in plastic production by 84% and greenhouse gas emissions by 71%.  Bottom line, recycling plastic does reduce fossil fuel consumption, and there is a lot of room for improvement.

PAPER!  The U.S. produced 78.5 million tons of paper in 2012 (at a cost of 3 or 4 million trees).  The pulp and paper industry remains a major driver of forest destruction and is the third greatest industrial greenhouse gas emitter.  Producing recycled paper takes 40% less energy than producing paper from virgin wood pulp.  Recycled paper production creates 74 percent less air pollution and 35 percent less water pollution than virgin paper production.  Bottom line, recycling paper does help.

ALUMINUM!  In 2009, 3.4 million tons of aluminum were generated which produced 9.8 billion pounds of carbon dioxide (a greenhouse gas) and 275.4 million pounds of air pollutants.  The amount of energy saved just from recycling cans in 2010 is equal to the energy equivalent of 17 million barrels of crude oil, or nearly two days of all U.S. oil imports.  Bottom line, recycling aluminum does help.

@JohnGreer You don't seem to get how science works. Yes, scientists may stand to lose something, and this can influence research. But in general, scientists stand to gain the most whenever they can disprove established theories or find strong evidence for new hypothesis.

Bias is of course unwelcome regardless of direction, but you are wrong to imply that science has any vested interest in climate change being a serious problem. There is no shortage of serious problems in the world! Besides, it is much harder to make stuff up in the world of science than the world of business, because your peers always stand to gain from finding fault with your method or analysis - in sharp contrast to the business world where being positive is often more important than being competent!

An awful lot of scientists are very knowledgable and intelligent people who could have chosen easier and better paid work if they wanted to. So whether they are driven by noble motives, a huge ego and a desire to save the world, plain-vanilla curiosity, or something completely different, there is less reason to suspect this lot of a profit motive than the world of business - which is after all quite openly about little else than generating profit.

@Tim Jarrell First, not all taxes on business are passed on to the consumer.  If you've taken microeconomics and you actually paid attention in class, then it depends on the price elasticity of demand of the product along with competition that will determine whether a tax is absorbed the consumer, the producer, or shared.Secondly, it's absolutely fine if a carbon tax is passed on to the consumer because it's ultimately the consumer who is causing damage to the environment with their purchase.  Paper that is produced by illegally dumping toxic waste into the river is going to be cheaper than paper that is produced by respecting the environment.  In the second case you pay the full cost of producing that paper.  In the first case, it's cheaper because you passed on that cost to whomever uses that river that has been polluted.

@a10ProductionsHD Yes, Veritasium can, at about 1:00, "To recap [global warming]. We are burning fossil fuels, releasing carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, which traps slightly more thermal energy, causing the overall temperature of the planet to rise."The people in the video are confusing this with ozone depletion, which was caused by man made gases (CFC's and HCFC's) which react with and destroy the ozone layer. This would be a bad thing because without the ozone layer to absorb it, the sun's UV light would kill life on the Earth's surface. This problem was at least halted by international agreement to ban these substances. Yay, we can cooperate to solve environmental threats!This is a fairly common confusion. They are completely separate issues, but both involve emissions of gases and something to do with sunlight and people tend to vague out at that point.The bit about recycling probably wasn't the best considered wording. Recycling does to some extent reduce CO2 emissions by reducing the energy spent producing new materials. But it's not the first thing you think of for reducing CO2. The first port of call is reducing energy usage by increasing efficiency and just plain old not wasting it.The last bit of interview was about "reputable sources" disagreeing about whether global warming is a problem. The reality is that almost all relevant experts agree that global warming is a problem and that it is at least mostly caused by us. The apparent disagreement people see, is coming from vested interests that stand to lose out if we cut fossil fuel use. A companies first duty is to maximise profits for its shareholders, if the fossil fuel industry was not doing everything in their power to delay action on climate change, then they would not be doing their job. That is the system we have.

Yes, dear god, science IS run as a consensus!  I'm seeing a lot of arguments saying "just because a bunch of scientists all agree doesn't make it true."  Actually that's the definition of science.  We test something and say "well that's not good enough.  You go test it."  And then another scientist tests it, and another, and another.  If everyone comes up with the same result we come to a consensus--i.e. we all agree!  All it takes is one scientific test to prove it wrong.  Time and again we have proven Newton was right, and Einstein was right, and now, we're agreeing global warming is human caused, and it's a problem!  Don't let your fear throw you into denial.  It's like everyone's crying, "But what if we make the world a better place for nothing!?"

The real answer is Electricity. Did you know that Edison had an electric car in 1901? Did you also know that people were converting combustion car engines to use hydrogen in the 1970s? The technology exists...but no one bought into it because it wasn't cost effective. Now...we're running out of oil....so we need an energy race to find the thing that will replace our energy needs. 
How do we do this? We motivate people to coming up with more ideas...cheaper ideas. The cheaper it is, the more people will buy into it. -And that's a great thing. As you see, electricity is the most abundant energy source in the universe. Solar Flares that come into contact with the Earth's outer atmosphere wreak havoc on communications satellites, analog phone lines, radio communications, etc. Why? Because it is an electrical phenomena. "When air or gas is ionized, plasma forms with conductive properties similar to those of metals. Plasma is the most abundant form of matter in the Universe, because most stars are in a plasma state." ..."Ionization is the process by which an atom or a molecule acquires a negative or positive charge by gaining or losing electrons to form ions."
There you have it. The most abundant form of matter in the universe is essentially ionized gas. Gas with a positive or negative electrical charge.
Now, if we are to advance as a civilization and a species, the next phase in our evolution is energy mastery and efficiency. If we can utilize all of the energy that gets used, and re-use it, then we will cease to have any energy woes. Clean energy exists all around us....but we only came upon this energy revolution AFTER Global Warming/Climate Change was presented to us as a real threat.

What I am happy about, is that this has brought about a race that is just as important, if not more so, than our race to the Moon in the 60s.

Did global warming end the ice age? Think about this, in 1952 scientists stumbled into what has become one of history’s most famous examples of jumping to conclusions. They declared that ice cream was causing polio. YES, I SAID ICE CREAM! The experts noticed an interesting correlation. The yearly rates of polio infections seemed to rise and fall with the consumption of ice cream. The excess sugar they proclaimed, was the cause. Take a deep breath: Believe it or not, scientists are not always right.

And after 120 years of research into the matter, did they still think that? Uhh, no... This is how Feynman says Science works: First you guess. Then you calculate the consequences if the guess is right. Then you check with nature. If nature is different your guess is wrong. This is how Climate Denial works: First you wish for how the world should be. Then you ignore everything around you. Then you comment on the internet. You're never wrong.

@randomlettersqzkebkw "i never said ONLY the sun" My apologies for my misinterpretation... but the sun IS the *major* forcing function. CO2's contribution is a secondary effect of how much solar radiation makes it to the earth's surface. (earth heats up, emits long-wave radiation, CO2 captures that and re-radiates a percentage back to the earth.  More CO2 means more re-radiation, even though the sun's input is declining.) "yes, the earth IS cooling. Govt figures/numbers, not mine." Please provide a reference to such "Govt figures/numbers". Well the sun "could be driving the change" but it isn't. For the sun to be driving the change it would have had to put out more energy than it had been. To do that it would have to get hotter or bigger (or both). Well to get hotter it would have had to shrink (that's how stars work) and the shrinking out weighs the hotter, so that's not what could have happened if it's going to put out the needed extra energy. To get bigger, well it would have got cooler, but being bigger it would put out more energy (again, that's just how stars work). Thing is that we know how big the Sun is and we know how big it's been in history to a high accuracy. By sheer co-incidence the sun and moon look about the same size as viewed from earth. If the Sun was a different size now to centuries ago, that would change the way eclipses look. They haven't changed. The sun didn't do it.

If the Salem witch-burners were alive today, they would be climate change "scientists." It's the same social dynamic in operation. Whether witch-burners know that there are, in fact, no witches, and purposely deceive others or merely deceive themselves into sincerely believing that witches exist because it is in their self-interest for them to exist and then unknowingly deceive others, it makes no difference to those subjected to their claims of authority, who get burned either way. What undermines the credibility of your video is your pretense that those who disagree with or question the claims of climate-change-doomsayers are only the uninformed "man on the street" interviewees that you presented. Why not interview instead the leading dissenters in the scientific community itself? Did you follow at all the climate-change data-fixing scandal that broke in the UK several years ago? Your argument that the truth of your claim is confirmed by the fact that your mob is presently bigger in size than its opposition is the sort of gang-think so typical in politics, yet inimical to scientific advancement, as the history of science attests. Every great scientific advance begins with a minority dissenting from the hidebound (but often politically favored) views of the majority, which then must be overcome for knowledge to increase. Your claims would be more convincing if you honestly presented the case against man-made climate change made in the scientific community and took them on head-on instead of pretending that the argument is between the scientific community on the one side and the ignorant and unwashed on the other. This debate is within science and it is the arguments of other scientists that you must vanquish to be credible, not straw men. I will disagree slightly on the point about recycling. Recycling could actually have an impact on CO2 emissions if the energy required to recycle a product and bring it back to market is less than the energy required to produce it from it's extracted raw materials.

Also, I think any actually public policy should be carefully considered. the climate models used to predict future climate changes are just that - they are models. They have had issues predicting the last 15 years; imagine what errors might exist in numbers that predict to the next 100. They should be taken with a grain of salt. Additionally, while humans are a contributor, we are relatively small player in the global carbon cycle; our ability to impact the environment - for better or for worse - does have limits.

Derek, I generally like your videos a lot, but there are a lot of problems with this one.

First, the scientific "consensus" has been severely misrepresented. So, what do 97% of climate scientists agree on, exactly? Two assertions:
1. Temperatures have generally risen over the past 200 years
2. Human activity is a significant factor in changing mean global temperatures.

Conspicuously absent from this is how big of a role humans played, and how this will continue in the future. That's right, it is not true that 97% of climate scientists agree that a carbon tax is a good idea (but more on that later).

Second, the climate predictions you see publicized are based on computer models that ignore crucial features of climate dynamics, such as cloud cover and the role of chemistry and biology. These models are only validated from their ability to predict present data from past data, which is obvious because they were designed to reproduce the historical data in the first place. They are not validated to predict future data, not by a long shot. That's why you often hear numbers for climate sensitivity (the rise in temperature given a doubling of CO2 concentration -- it's logarithmic) that are, quite frankly, absurd. 10 degrees Celsius? Please. No evidence whatsoever suggests that, apart from what you get from a model -- the historical, observed climate sensitivity is closer to 1 degree. "But climate is dominated by positive feedback loops", I hear you say. Well, if it were, we would already be at those higher temperatures, wouldn't we? Natural fluctuations would've been enough to kick the system over to its fixed point. At the very least, fluctuations of similar amplitude as the predictions should have been observed; climate may not be as hectic as weather, but it is still chaotic in the precise definition of the term. 

Third, even assuming that it's true, asking people "what are you doing about climate change" is disingenuous because there's nothing that the average person CAN do. Any action has to be taken at the policy-making level. Walking to work and taking shorter showers is going to do diddly squat about it.

Fourth, there are vested interests in both sides of this issue. If you think that Al Gore is doing advocacy for this out of the goodness of his heart you should be ashamed of your naiveté. There's a lot of money to be made in this, and you can see shills in both sides, just as you can see honest people in both sides. Attack the arguments, not the person making them.

Fifth, those who stand to lose if a price is put on carbon are essentially all of us. What do you think, that oil companies are going to reduce their profit margins? Of course they're not, they're going to pass the increased costs to the consumer. All consumer products will suddenly become more expensive because of the now higher transportation overhead. The people who are impacted the most are of course the poor: the person who needs to buy fuel to keep warm in the winter (FYI, you might want to look at how many people have been dying of cold for that reason in the UK). The people who global warming advocates claim will be the most affected by climate change are also the ones most affected by climate change mitigation policies. The evil businessman in a suit? He'll manage. He always does.

Sixth, climate change is not like Armageddon. Even if the direst predictions are confirmed. That's emotionally charged language, which I realize is somewhat the point of your video, but it's also extremely misleading. It sounds like you're saying that the Earth will become like Venus, which nobody believes, not even you.

Seventh, if their direst predictions aren't realized, that is, if global warming continues with a climate sensitivity similar to the historical 1 kelvin, we're looking at an improved biosphere, where the good effects outweigh the bad. Seriously, it's on the last IPCC report.

Eighth, I believe it's been made clear by now but it pays to reiterate why the carbon tax has been repealed. Policy makers realized it's bad for the economy. And remember, when it's bad for the economy, it's not bad for the mustache twirling businessman, it's bad for the average Joe. Here's a crazy thought: climate change disproportionately affects the poor, right? So instead of trying to mitigate climate change which will allegedly be Armageddon wrought upon us by all the technologies we depend on, how about we... reduce poverty? Oh, too radical, huh.

I think that's it. Sponsored by your advice on your second channel -- "Be hated", which I completely agree with. Signed, a physics graduate student who damn well wishes he were paid by the oil industry to post these things on the Internet because then he wouldn't be as poor.

I think much of the problem is general ignorance of the scientific method. Another confounding problem is people seem to think the popularity of, or ability to express an opinion carries some weight.  Many peoples views are also highly emotionally charged & motivated.
I am a criminologist/forensic psychologist & I see this constantly in the gun debate. One side says it's obvious or it's common sense & say "Look at Britain." They never reference a study that isolates the variable & makes a before & after comparison. They go on "common sense" or assume correlation means causation. 
The other side does essentially the same thing. They present "evidence" that isn't scientifically valid and they use emotionally driven argunents. Both sides have their minds made up. Because of that and because of a generally poor understanding of scientific method they will look at some painfully obviously flawed "study" from the NRA or Brady Campaign & use that to reinforce their beliefs.
One of my co-workers very eloquently said "It's like watching monkeys throw S@#% at each other while they try to debate special relativity." 
I think the climate situation suffers from the same general ignorance of science in the population overall as well as people holding emotionally driven beliefs. 
I went to school for 10 years & surrounded myself with other people that valued knowledge & formed opinions based on scientific evidence & studies. A social or "soft" science has more room for opinions but those opinions are still very much evidence based.  After I graduated I worked with highly educated people & my patients were generally criminals. I was seeing the two extremes. The highly educated & the inmate population in my state that has an average education level below the 8th grade. 
Anyways, for a long time, I didn't have lots of interaction with the "average" person. My peer group was social scientists & college types. I ended up drastically overestimating the scientific literacy of the general population. 
I think you are doing the same thing I did. You are teaching physics to students eager to learn & your peer group is other highly educated people that live by the scientific method. You overestimated the scientific literacy of the general population. 
I think that is why it's so hard to make progress on climate issues. Much of the population just doesn't understand. They don't realize a scientifically based stance on an issue is 1,000 times more valid than a stance based on popularity or emotion or a non-causative correlation.

I am not a scientist but I try to keep myself informed of this issue.  From what I understand the science is NOT established and that there are reputable scientists throughout the world who are agnostic about (a) whether climate change is occurring and (b) whether humans are causing it.  It is NOT just big business with large vested interests that are opposing the scientific "consensus" that you say is so overwhelmingly uniform.  Will you not agree that the decade of the 1930s was the hottest decade in recorded history?  And will you also not agree that the past 10 years has been part of a cooling trend?  

The reality is that there are huge number of data points which must be included to accurately measure whether climate change is occurring.  Will you not also agree that it is absolutely impossible to get accurate measurements for most of the surface of the earth?

I just find it not credible to say that scientists "know" that climate change is occurring.  They may believe it to be occurring based on available evidence, but it really a long stretch from there to say that the scientific world uniformly knows it to be occurring.

Hi Paul, thanks for your comments. You raise some interesting questions. The 1930s was a hot decade in the US but it wasn't so globally. In fact thirteen of the fourteen hottest years on record occurred this century. So no the 1930s were not particularly hot and the last 10 years are definitely not part of a cooling trend. There are other indicators like arctic sea ice melting and land ice melting in Greenland and Antarctica, plus ocean temperature rises that confirm the planet is still warming. Getting accurate data about the planet is not easy. But satellites make it a lot easier. When you find that the satellite data agrees with the ground-based data, and the sea level rise and temperature increases fit with predictions for an atmosphere with more CO2, all the signals point to a warming Earth that we have caused. Hence why 97% of climate scientists agree that human-caused global warming is occurring. This is not to say that they "know" it is happening, but the evidence is clear enough that few scientists disagree.

I promised myself that I wouldn't come back on here and keep this up but I'm back. No the 1930's wasn't hottest. No there hasn't been a cooling trend in the last 10 years. These are the lies that Dereck was talking about. The denial camp just makes things up. Whatever it wants. There's no need to wait to collect more data points to "see if it's real". There's no need for more than two data points to tell you everything you *must* know. How much energy is going in and how much is coming out. If there is more energy going in than coming out then the planet is heating up. That's *all* that's *needed*. We've made that measurement and the world is between 0.6 and 0.85 Watts out of balance. That's how much more heat energy is coming in than going out. The controversy is where the effects will be felt first, will they be irreversible and "run away" if we push the energy balance too far. The basic climate change idea is so simple you can check it yourself. Look up black body radiation. Work out for yourself what the temperature of the world would be without the greenhouse gases that are already in the atmosphere. Then think about what happens if you double, triple or quadruple one of them. (Hint: when you work out the temperature of the Earth as it is now, but without GHG, you should get a figure somewhat below zero C for the current albedo of the Earth. Then you should realise that it would be covered in ice. Re run the figures for an all white planet with an albedo of 0.9. You should get a figure between minus 60 C and minus 40 C. (depending on assumptions you make) The current CO2 is holding us 60-70 C higher than we would be without it. Then tell me that CO2 doesn't matter or that there are no tipping points or that we can double the level of CO2 without worrying) edit: converted from "stream of consciousness into something vaguely readable.

@Jacob Golden There was no science supporting global cooling. I was studying ecology back then. If you looked at the orbital mechanics of the earth then we were due another ice age, starting to hit around now and getting stronger over the next few thousand years. That signal is completely swamped by the green house gas emissions. That was recognised even then. The only thing global cooling that we were talking about back then was "it should be cooling very slowly, but it's warming very fast". Which was considered evidence for warming before we went into space and made the actual measurements that showed it. Going into space didn't just end the flat earth idea, because we looked and could see it was round. To an *equal* extent it ended the idea that the earth was cooling. We looked at it from space, measured the heat coming out and the heat going in. More heat is going in (0.6 - 0.8 Watts per square meter) than is coming out. That's it. It's heating up. There's no debate, we went and looked. It really is no more up for debate than "is the world flat or round". We looked and settled that question.

@2veritasium And forty years ago there was data and evidence to support the claim of global cooling. @TNT Far from being ignored, they're studied. The deniers just say "the models ignore [insert almost anything] and without that they aren't valid" but then a moment on google and you can see it's a lie (or as it's charitably described in this video "made up". Looks like they add about 1 degree C in the areas where they're densest. From the IPCC: "Computations of radiative forcing by contrails have been done for fixed atmospheric temperatures in the North Atlantic flight corridor (Fortuin et al., 1995). Normalized to 100% contrail cover (as provided by 1-D models), these computations found a net forcing in the range of -30 to +60 W m-2 in summer and 10 to 60 W m-2 in winter. The negative forcing values apply to clouds that are much thicker than typical contrails. A radiative convective model used to simulate the climatic conditions of a mid-European region (Strauss et al., 1997) found a radiative flux change of almost 30 W m-2 at the tropopause for 100% contrail cover with 0.55-�m optical depth of 0.28, and a surface temperature increase on the order of 0.05 K for a 0.5% increase in current contrail cloud cover. With a 2-D radiative convective model, a 1 K increase was found in surface temperature over most of the Northern Hemisphere for an additional cirrus cover of 5% (Liou et al., 1990). The potential effects of contrails on global climate were simulated with a GCM that introduced additional cirrus cover with the same optical properties as natural cirrus in air traffic regions with large fuel consumption (Ponater et al., 1996). The induced temperature change was more than 1 K at the Earth's surface in Northern mid-latitudes for 5% additional cirrus cloud cover in the main traffic regions."

Let me ask you this. If there wasn't climate change before humans or our long distant cousins, why is there fossil evidence of tropical and even desert plants embedded with layers of Scottish rock and why is there further plant evidence of plants that thrive in the cold as far south as North Africa?
What about the scientific samples of ice taken from both the Arctic and Antarctic that show CO and CO2 and many other green house gases being well above the concentrations of today. Where have the (sometimes sudden) fluctuations within concentrations come from?
Yes there is a human influence on our Earth's climate, but scientists who support the natural cycle theory (again both human and natural climate change are still only theories) state that our influence in the past 150 years and the 150 years is estimated to be in the region of 0.000005%!

There is also the convection of air currents to consider. Our O-Zone and green house gases allow the warming of the planet that is not facing the sun. Ice reflects heat back towards space and our layer of gases, which in turn, reflect that heat back. Water is a conductor of heat, once there is not enough ice or snow (white) to reflect that heat, water absorbs it instead. The convection of heat is lost from the air, causing a cooling effect, which over time will cause global temperatures to begin to cool. Over the course of the Earth's history there have been periods of immense cooling and warming. Ice has been proven to be a rare phenomenon on Earth.

And before a lot of people say that people who don't believe in human made climate change are sceptics; that is almost never the case. The rest of society recognise that climate change is happening, but it is a natural cycle that our planet goes through.
There is no harm in recycling and reducing CO2 and other emissions because that can help improve global air quality.

The heat exchange between the inside of the Earth and space is not really limited by the temperature of the surface. Even if you were right that making the surface hotter would slow heat from below, the heat loss from below is currently only 0.087 W per square meter. We're currently out of balance by 0.6-0.8 Watts per square meter (depending on the sun's 11 year cycle.) So even if making the surface 2 degrees warmer would stop all the flow of heat from the core to the surface (which it wouldn't because the core is at about 7000 degrees), then stopping all that flow of heat would change the balance very little. It would go from 0.6-0.8 down to 0.51-0.71 Watts per square meter.

People don't understand climate change because people have a weak grasp of English, and here's why:

When people hear about "global warming slowing down" they think it means "global cooling" and therefore nothing to worry about.  Yet, it doesn't matter if global warming is slowing down, the net result is still global warming.  This is something that has to be explained in terms that people can understand simply, and this is the best example I can think of currently:

If you're driving towards a cliff, will slowing down the car stop you from driving off the cliff?  The answer of course is no.  It doesn't matter how slow your car is moving forward, you're going to go off that cliff eventually.  You need to stop the car, and ideally put it in reverse and move away from the cliff. 

Course when it comes to the science the cliff is few decades away, and many scientists saying it's too late to stop the car; while we have quite a number of people who say the cliff doesn't exist at all.

"Businesses with a vested interest"? That's quite a genetic fallacy you have there... If having a business with a stake in the outcome of the debate is enough to disqualify one's opinion, then what of those advancing carbon regulations who have invested in ventures that will make them wealthy if those carbon regulations come to fruition (e.g., carbon exchanges)? Sounds like a business with a vested interest to me... are they then wrong? No. Just as those opposing carbon regulations are not wrong just because the have a vested interest in the status quo.
Agreed!

Also, "vast majority of climate scientists" is an overstatement relying on abuse of statistics (the 97% number, right?). If you read that study more carefully, you'll see that of the 12,000 articles about climate change whose abstracts were selected for the sample, only about a third took a position on AGW. Of that one-third, 97% claimed AGW was the cause of climate change; 3% said it wasn't. Seems like a consensus, but only if we focus solely on that one-third. Looking at all climate scientists, however, the real scientific "consensus" is actually with the other two-thirds who have taken no position on AGW at all.

Climate gate is a fabrication. After trawling through thousands of private emails of researchers who are supposedly making up results for the vast fortunes that can be had from grant money [giggle], they found someone say they'd found a trick to get the results. I'm sorry to burst your conspiracy bubble but "trick" means "clever shortcut to process data quickly to obtain the correct results faster and with less work". Feynman won a Nobel prize for working out a trick that allowed him to get the correct result very quickly. "Trick" does not mean "a clever way to fake results". If you *really* want to think for yourself, it's not hard. Here's a good start. Look up the Albedo of water and rock. Work out the average temperature of something that's spherical and 3/4 water, 1/4 rock. If you've done it right it should be around zero C or a few tens of degrees below. Then realise that the water wouldn't be water at that temperature, it would be ice and the ice and the rock would be covered in snow. Do the calculation again for a spherical object covered in snow. You should get somewhere between minus 60 and minus 40 degrees. Why is the world not stable at that temperature and covered with ice and snow? You'll have to think about that yourself. Then think about your assertion that climate science is NOT well established. Please do let us know how you get on.

I think one of the big problems is that no one is giving us clear instructions as to what we're supposed to be doing.  We're told to recycle, but that's about it.  When we're told that greenhouse gases are being produced by big business, our reaction is, "well, I don't own a big business."  The other big contributor (so we're told) is cars, but no one tells us what to do to solve this, other than just being "aware" that it's bad.  We obviously can't stop driving, at least not unless everyone moves our workplaces, stores and apartment buildings into a single geographical area....  or starts letting us ride horses on the streets again.  Electric cars are still new and most of us can't afford new cars, and hybrids aren't really a solution, because they still require gasoline.  We're often told that the governments need to do something, but none of us feels like we have any influence over the government.  (If we did, we'd be shutting down domestic spying programs, ending wars, lowering taxes, and legalizing drugs and prostitution.)

So at the end of the day, the big message we keep getting sounds like:  "You should worry about this big thing all the time, that you can't actually fix."
If we lived in a reasonable society, the scientific community wouldn't have to convince the general public of anything - they would be able to enact legislation based on scientific facts.

It is generally know that there was an ice age, I believe that it is less known that there were also times when climate was warmer (vikings were having agriculture on greenland, which is mostly ice now, and so on), so it would be nice to have comparison of what can happen to us with those historical fluctuations. That would give clearer view of how much mankind added to global warming (if that can be estimated).

Furthermore, I feel the need to express my disappointment with the fact that people seem to connect anti-global-warming changes only with renewable energy sources. I'd say that easiest solution to stop dumping large amount of CO2 to atmosphere would be to employ more nuclear power plants: they are generally quite safe (Fukushima was badly placed and old, Chernobyl was fatal human mistake, not technical problem in first place), they generate no CO2 and they generate less radioactivity that coal power plants. Also they are several orders of magnitude more powerfull than renewable power sources as far as I know (with possible exception of really huge water dams, but those can't be built anywhere…). @Skycoca That sounds like a very mature way to handle things - block out all voices that disagree with your opinion. Scientists don't talk of things being "proven" because it's too strong a word. There can be evidence for certain hypotheses and evidence against hypotheses, but ultimately it comes down to how much of each types exist. Scientists weigh up this data and, when there is enough evidence, they come to a consensus, as climate scientists have now. This doesn't necessarily mean they are right, but it certainly is suggestive. Regarding the sun, its impact on our climate is not in doubt. The cyclical changes in Earth's orbit have led to past changes in the way solar radiation impacts the Earth and on the resulting climate. We have good observations of the sun now and for the last few hundred years and nothing in these observations justifies the level of warming observed.

I sure rising sea levels and arable land will become an issue, but I think an upcoming (and more dangerous) issue for us is a lack of potable water. The Ogallala Aquifer, one of the largest in the world and located in the U.S., is slowly drying up. This aquifer supplies at least 27% of irrigated land, and would severely harm both the U.S. population and it's economy.

While I want to see solutions to Climate Change, I think we should also be investing our efforts into more efficient Desalination plants; as salt-water is not something we can use for much of our necessary utilities and needs. While it may be expensive, it is worth the cost in the long run. Given how valuable such a resource is, a lack of water could spark military and economic conflicts in the future.

I believe that many of the rational deniers don't believe in climate change because they're sick of the ridiculous fictional doomsday scenarios, such as the notion of the LHC creating an earth-eating black-hole.

Additionally, the topic is one close to the hearts of emotional thinkers so emotive language is used, this feels like manipulation to the logical thinkers, which implies that their argument is a lie.

Understandably, this all leads to conformation bias, among other fallacies. Even the most rational of us are vulnerable to them; they're flaws in human psychology. In lieu of having a framework that alleviates them (such as the scientific method), we can try to stay aware of them.

Without such consideration, we strive to prove our preconceptions and will usually think we're succeeding because our 'proof' is based on misconceptions or incomplete information.

The one thing a rational thinker should be proud of, is the ability to overcome common fallacies and have the capacity to change their mind.

First, it's not an agenda, it's science. Even though manmade CO2 emissions are small (35 GT) relative to the global circulation of CO2 (~780 GT), it upsets a balance between sources and sinks leading to a measurable increase in atmospheric CO2 (we add a net 15 GT or so of CO2 to the atmosphere annually). That's why the level of CO2 which had stayed below 300ppm for 800,000 years has now risen to 400 ppm. The climate had been fairly stable for the last 1000 years at a level of 280ppm so humans are responsible for a rise of about 40% in the level of CO2. Most scientists agree that a doubling of CO2 alone results in about 1C of warming. However we know there are positive feedbacks, like as the temperature warms, the water vapour in the atmosphere increases. So it's generally accepted that a doubling in CO2 results in a 2-3C temp rise if you include the amplifying effects of water vapour. So no, it is not true that man causes no more than 0.28% of temperature change. The factors are complicated and if you don't want to understand them you can easily say 'this can't be true, we're not causing global warming,' but I'm kindly asking you to reconsider.

I don't deny climate change, because I've actually done some (5 or so hours) of research, and only someone who ignores most of the material on climate change can call themselves a denier. I do however have a few problems and questions with regards to proposals to cut green house gas emissions in order to protect the environment:
1. Why is cutting carbon emissions the number one priority? Even if we cut 100% of our carbon emissions starting from today, CO2 would remain above 350 ppm till 2070 or 2080. If global warming is the main part of climate change, there are far cheaper and more effective ways of artificially reducing global temperatures, so why is all the fuss about CO2?

2. Why are we assuming that climate change a bad thing? Many species will actually benefit from climate change; ie, animals that enjoy warmer climates, almost all plants (since plants eat CO2 they actually grow faster the more carbon is in the atmosphere) and I do believe humans would also benefit (not from health, but economically we would be better off with a slightly warmer environment)

Until I can be convinced that climate change is bad for humans AND cutting CO2 emissions is the most effective way to protect the environment, I will oppose any government legislation which intends to cut CO2 emissions.

Hi Trepur349, I understand your concerns and have to say that I too have my doubts on the solution side of climate change. Our world is simply too complex to say with 100% certainty that any given solution will work or not, especially on this scale. On the problem side however, I am thoroughly convinced of the existence and I will give you a few reasons why. I try to list them somewhat chronologically. 1. Climate change causes more weather extremes. Climate change does not necessarily mean that it will get warmer all year around. Minor fluctuations in temperature can have massive impact on the severity of short term weather events. A good example would be hurricane Katrina. After moving over Florida, Katrina continued her path over the Gulf of Mexico, the warmer than usual water actually increased the power of Katrina to a catastrophic 'category 5' hurricane. Not only will warmer water increase severity of hurricanes, it will also increase frequency. This is a trend we already see happing for several decades. 2. Extinction. We are currently experiencing the 6th mass extinction event the earth has ever seen (as far as archeological research tells us). The complexity of climate change brings along more change than only temperature or weather extremes. Higher temperatures, however, will allow for insects like mosquitos and usually tropical viruses to flourish further away from the equator towards the poles. 3. Sea level. Historically speaking it has been interesting for people to settle near bodies of water, as it made trade easier. Currently hundreds of millions of people live close to coast lines. Areas that are inhabitable with the predicted sea level rise. If this trend of climate change continues, mass migrations will follow, with a lot of social disruption as an effect. You can already see what kind of impact a massive influx of immigrants has on some western nations in Europe. I think these are the most urgent and important issues regarding climate change. I would rather have our leaders and the people take action on plans that only have a probability of working out positively than just sitting here in inaction, just anxiously waiting for it all to blow over.

@Pedro Moura That sounds nice, but I think that's definitely a long term gradual game. Totally not what I'm talking about, and while I do support use of natural gas as a peaker, I don't support relying on it for baseload, and you can't get around the fact that while it is cleaner, it's not clean. Far from it. Again, as I said, it doesn't matter how much more efficient you make something if you need to keep doing it more and more over time. The advantages of natural gas being cleaner are erased as you use more and more of it to meet growing power demands. And you can use the word invest all you want, it doesn't actually add anything to the discussion. Also, dat run-on sentence. Carbon capture is nice, but it can only really be done at source, and it doesn't solve the storage problem. Carbon capture from the general atmosphere is a pretty dumb idea in general. Nature only manages it because of huge excesses of energy, and at extremely low efficiency. Using captured CO2 to do this conceptually closes the loop, but in actuality is hilariously silly. In order to take the CO2 and water and re-make the fuel you, at 100% efficiency, need to put in the same amount of energy you'd get out of the fuel (basic chemistry will tell you this). In reality, no process is 100% efficient. So even if you used the power the plant generated to convert the CO2 and water back into fuel, you still would need to have another generator somewhere supplying the power to compensate for the inefficiency in the conversion process. So, in reality, converting the CO2 back into fuel would cost more energy than burning the original fuel would have released. And this is all ignoring that power generators are far from 100% efficient themselves. At every step, energy is lost. In reality you might, at best, require three power plants to turn the CO2 produced by one power plant back into fuel. All of which isn't even a short-term solution to the problem of elevated greenhouse gas levels. Lowering emissions won't get rid of the symptoms of higher GHG levels we're going to experience over the coming decades and century. Don't get me wrong, I don't think geoengineering is a good solution, I just think it might be the best one we have for the time being. Take the space-mirror example though. You make one bad assumption here, it seems to me. You assume that it needs to reflect the light, or even stay intact. All it needs to do is block a bit of light from hitting the earth. Even if it breaks up over time, we only need it to be up there for a matter of decades to a century. After that, it's actually better if it disappears, as we won't need it as greenhouse gas levels return to more reasonable levels, and if we retained zero or a small amount of emissions, after a couple centuries, the spacemirrors would actually be cooling the earth with GHG levels returned to pre-industrial (although that's not a goal I care about, it is something we'll eventually reach as we lower emissions significantly, and wait a couple centuries).

@Pedro Moura They're expensive, sure, but more expensive (in the short term) than building huge numbers of new power plants while decommissioning old ones before their natural end-of-life date? The cost of moving more vehicles to electric? Better practices in other industries, etc.? I expect that will cost more in the short term but less in the long term. That's why I said these solutions are like a patch on the problem. Maybe they're cheaper to address the symptoms of the problem for a few years, but how do the costs work out over 20 years? 50? 100? Adapting to changes that replace fossil fuel power with other power may cost more in the short-term, but they actually solve the problem, rather than merely treating the symptoms. And let's be realistic, this is the heart of how we'll cut emissions, especially when you consider that power consumption is growing fairly rapidly. You may make a process 5% more efficient, but that doesn't make a difference if you increase production 5% over the same time period. There's also only so efficient things can be made, and even at no new emissions, the damage we've done is going to have serious long-reaching implications. That's why I think what we really need is a combination. We need to use short-term measures, perhaps like trepur's suggestion of spraying chemicals to reflect some incoming light, to lower energy incoming while we reduce emissions. That way we eliminate the problem itself, and also treat the symptoms of the problem that will continue to persist even after emissions drop.

@seigeengine See my earlier posts in this stream. A primary area of confusion is trying to visualize an atmosphere as a greenhouse. They are not the same thing and are actually quite the opposite. Atmospheres covering variable landscapes that get heated for an average 12 hours and cooled for an average 12 hours do not in any way behave like a 'greenhouse'. Greenhouses work by preventing convection, atmospheres encourage convection. If you heat a region of air no matter whether by conduction, radiation, or so-called 'trapped' radiation that region will expand, become less dense, and be pushed skyward by gravity dragging cooler more dense beneath it. So if you 'trap' radiation, then you are simply increasing the convection rate keeping the incoming and outgoing radiation in equilibrium. Heating a region of air unevenly with other regions creates convection If you observe the atmosphere as what it is (an elastic fluid that stretches and advects), especially the Troposphere that sees temp diferentials of 65 to 80 C between the Tropopause and Surface, then you can get a better idea of how difficult it is to 'trap' energy when there are regions close to it that are cooler. It decfreases from average 15C to -56C. Our 'thin' light atmosphere appears 'thin' from outspace, but from the surface it is quite massive heavy, over 10,000 kilograms per square meter. 5,000 Trillion metric tons, of which ~900 Billion is CO2. That is my justification to be skeptical. The issue is not climate change, the issue is Anthropogenic Climate Change. Now say you just stumbled on to this, ask yourself, Does the atmosphere behave like a 'greenhouse'? If so, how does it prevent Convection? If your theory holds water again, then you ask someone you trust (A Peer) to test the theory. By test he meant 'tries to actually falsify the theory'. @***** I think it is reasonable to expect the sea levels to reach a similar level. CO2 levels were around 280 parts per 1,000,000 at the last interglacial. So why the alarm? From an earlier post to Veritasium explaining my issues with the consensus. 1. The GreenHouse Effect. Would you agree that you need a 'greenhouse' to get a 'greenhouse effect'? Why call it something that it is not? Greenhouses 'trap' heat by preventing Convection, but they still radiate as well all know. If you can somehow reduce the emissivity of the Earth's surface or lower troposphere, does that not increase the temp, thereby increasing the rate of Convection? What would stop Convection from cooling the surface and lower troposphere if the poorly named 'greenhouse gases' trapped more energy in that region? The average temp decreases from 15C to -56C from the surface to the Tropopause. That cooling is primarily the result of Convection, not Radiation. 2. The Elasticity of the Earth's Atmosphere. The Earth's atmosphere is elastic. The altitude of the Tropopause averages around 6,000 meters at the poles and 18,000 meters at the Equator. Imagine that the tropopause was fixed at 6,000 meters. The pressure would increase, and with increased pressure you get increased temps. Since the volume of the atmosphere is variable and expands with increased energy, the temp is reduced by increasing volume. A physics professor of mine explained 'temperature' as 'energy pressure'. This makes sense when looking at radiative rates and specific heat. 3. Milankovitch Cycle. The Milankovtich Cycle(s) correlate very well with the Glacial and Interglacial periods. It appears that the interglacial periods last around 25,000 to 30,000 years, the last glacial period ended around 12,000 to 14,000 years ago. Would we not expect to be nearing or at the height of the current glacial minimum? The sea levels were nearly 10 meters higher at the last glacial minimum without the additional CO2 levels. 4. N2 and O2. N2 and O2 make up 99% of the mass of our atmosphere and while they do not absorb or emit Infrared in the same spectrum as CO2, they do absorb and emit radiation. Both N2 and O2 have higher Specific Heat than CO2 both at constant pressure and constant volume as well. These gases are emitting huge amounts of energy both towards the surface and away. Far more than CO2 can possibly be responsible for. Much of the confusion that surrounds 'AGW' is caused by 'scientists' using the misnamed "Greenhouse Effect' to describe a phenomena. Here's how it was set to work in Australia: 1. Carbon tax increases the cost of anything with significant carbon emissions (electricity, industrial production etc) 2. People buy less of this stuff because it's more expensive - they look for ways to reduce electricity use (turning off lights, changing lightbulbs, putting in better insulation, biking rather than driving etc,) 3. Business people invest in technologies and energy sources that emit less carbon because they are now economically more affordable. 4. The government refunds the increased expenditure due to the tax to the poorer households so they're not worse off, but leaves the Ferrari drivers to cover their own costs. This is an idea endorse by almost all of the big fossil fuel companies. For example on BP's website it states: "We also believe that putting a price on carbon – one that treats all carbon equally, whether it comes out of a smokestack or a car exhaust – will make energy efficiency and conservation more attractive to businesses and individuals and lower-carbon energy sources more cost competitive. A global carbon price should be the long-term goal, but regional and national approaches are a good first step, provided temporary financial relief is given to sectors that are exposed to international competition."

Derek, you stated that the CO2 "traps" slightly more thermal energy, making it sound like an insulating blanket.  But, isn't it more the case that CO2 "absorbs" more thermal energy than the other elements in the atmosphere?

You also made it seem as though the carbon tax is the only solution and without it, CO2 can only increase.  Hasn't the per-capita and per-vehicle CO2 emissions been decreasing in 1st world countries, including Australia?  California alone is a significant force in the U.S. effort, forcing car manufacturers to sell a certain percentage of electric vehicles.  Perhaps Japan's CO2 emissions have gone up as a result of their overreaction to the Fukashima disaster, but most other 1st world countries still have a rational attitude toward nuclear.  Residential and commercial solar installations are being installed at an explosive rate in 1st world countries where the sun permits even a meager ROI.  Investment and research into all sorts of energy storage and alternatives to fossil fuels is enormous.  Willingness to suffer the ugliness and danger of giant wind turbines and tidal generators is tipping heavily.  Consumer demand for "clean" and "green" has never been higher and is increasing.

One huge problem is the politics.  It was nearly unanimous among the U.S. Congress and President Obama that more installations of nuclear power were needed, but then he added "as part of a comprehensive energy policy".  "Comprehensive" is the most certain deal killer in politics today as it means to deal with so much in one fell swoop that it also ensures that it has plenty for all sides to raise serious objections.

Then of course, a tax is a political tool.  Will the tax on carbon be spent offsetting the effects of carbon, or will it go into the general budget where it will battled over and used to fund unrelated projects?  Will California spend its carbon tax revenue mitigating and preventing carbon related damage, or will it build expensive trains and funding welfare programs?

@Veritasium Having all the big fossil fuel companies on board makes me even more suspicious.  They're certainly not masochistic advocates of of more taxes on themselves, so what is their angle?  Obviously they're going to pass on their greater expenses to the consumer, but it still seems counter-intuitive to a profit motive. Your explanation of the Aussie tax setup is easily interpreted as "wealth redistribution" and so it makes it easier to protest.  The government is taxing one group for Reason X (ostensibly for producing carbon emissions) to give that money to a different group for Reason Y (for being poor).  Reason Y can not be "to return to working families what they would have had to pay to cover the carbon tax", because everyone who uses carbon emitting energy has to cover that tax, not just low income or "working families".  I noticed that you followed a political ploy of changing the qualifier from "low income" to the even more ambiguous, "working families".  Working families use carbon emitting energy too, but the Aussie carbon tax would actually reward that class of people for doing so.  Do "working family" carbon emissions do less harm per person or per ton than those from other families?

@JJLatBIM Most economists acknowledge a price on carbon is the simplest way to reduce emissions. It allows market forces to work to find the best alternatives. All the big fossil fuel companies are on board. And the way the Aussie tax was setup was not to redistribute wealth, just to return to working families what they would have had to pay to cover the carbon tax.

@Veritasium Thanks for the response.  Is there a different effect of CO2 at different altitudes?  Could low altitude CO2 that has absorbed IR radiation then has greater ability to transfer that energy into the oceans? I'm suspicious of BP's endorsement.  The quote makes me think they are simply setting up an argument to support corporate welfare to offset the greater hardship they will face compared to competitors not saddled with carbon taxes. I'm not saying a carbon tax is a bad idea, just that it's not the only idea. Regarding Australia's diverting of carbon tax revenue to low income families, that's a political decision that causes rifts.  Everyone who uses energy is disadvantaged by increases in energy costs, so giving carbon tax revenue to low income families is just another way to "redistribute wealth".  As a means of balancing the true cost of carbon emissions, carbon taxes seem reasonable, but not necessarily as just another revenue source.

@David Yeah the thing with climate change is that most plant life today is quite well adapted to our low CO2, low temperatures biomes. I'm not sure about heat stress, but I know that the effects of climate change on the hydrological cycle is something that worry plant scientists. The hydrological cycle will probably intensify and compared to their ancestors, modern plants are not used to either being flooded like crazy or dryed up for extended periods of time for the most part. So even though more CO2 is beneficial for plant life (and although modern plants CAN thrive in our not-so-long-ago very low CO2 atmosphere), climate change might not be. There were warmer climates and more CO2 in the atmosphere in the past (about 6x more in the Mezozoic), but it's all about the speed of change, not the numbers.

I'd like to minorly correct something that you mentioned. Human respiration is indeed dependent on CO2 levels and not oxygen levels as most people think, but it's not CO2 levels in the air; it's CO2 levels in the blood. As our cells respire, it increases the CO2 levels in the blood, which causes the blood to become more acidic (in the same way the ocean is becoming more acidic nowadays) and it's this changing pH that causes us to respire. I also don't see how increasing CO2 levels in the air could improve human respiration. If anything it would worsen is as the percentage of oxygen in the air would decrease and we'd have to breathe more quickly to take in the same amount of oxygen; this is exactly why you get out of breath at high altitude even if you're not doing something strenuous, because there's less oxygen.

@Outside Observer That's interesting. So rising CO2 is good for the plants, but the extra heat caused by the rising CO2 surely cannot be. I imagine that plants can adapt better to CO2 levels than temperature change in much the same way that animals do.

@Veritasium He's right on something though; most plants crave more CO2 than there was before the industrial revolution, in fact all the C4 metabolic pathway of photosynthesis is an evolutionary adaptation to low carbon levels. But then again, carbon sequestration didn't occur in a few decades and we're only talking about one very specific element of the system, so saying that plants will benefit from climate change is a bit silly at this point.

@Rudy Brown Yeah, Rudy's right. The icecap is 3000 metres thick, precipitation on Greenland is under half a metre per year. Even if there were no glaciers pulling water out (which there are) you'd be looking at 6000 years of freezing temperatures being needed to build up an icecap that thick. Like many of the denial red herrings, they don't stand up to even a few seconds of critical thinking. The whole denial case depends on making decisions that determine the fates of billions of people and all the life that shares our planet, without spending 3 seconds thinking first. It seems to work well with emotionally based decision making. (Sadly) What the Greenland cap does tell us, other than the obvious, that it's old, is that temperature has changed as much as 5 degrees in just one season. Ice cores give us a clear temperature and rainfall record for the area going back thousands of years. The climate is a chaotic system that can and has jumped suddenly to a new stable point. Anyone who's played with chaotic systems will tell you that giving them a solid shove can have unpredictable results. It may go a long way in the direction you shove, it may hardly move at all or it may go a long way in the *opposite* direction to the one you shove it. While in the short term, massive warming is certain, it's not impossible that we could trigger a mega ice age 1000 years in the future or a jump to a new stable and much hotter system. There's no record of any shoves in any direction in the last few 10s of thousands of years that are as strong as the one we're giving it now. Yet it has jumped suddenly to different temperatures. This is not a system you should fiddle with lightly.

The Vostok Ice Cores disprove CO2 as the biggest driving factor in global climate. Similarly, global temperature has DECREASED over the past 15 years, not INCREASED. And there are projections that the "global warming pause" may continue for another 10 years.

So why is climate change boring? Because it's not valid science. Yes, human CO2 emissions contribute to global greenhouse gas effects, but not in a driving manner. Solar activity and other environmental feedbacks override the greenhouse gas effects of CO2, which is why the Vostok Ice Cores show Ice Ages beginning during periods of MAXIMUM CO2 concentrations, and why global warming has "paused" over the past 15 years despite increases in atmospheric CO2.

And 400ppm of CO2 in the atmosphere is not harmful to humans, plants or animals. Harmful effects don't begin until you get to around 10000ppm. The highest CO2 concentration in the history of the earth was around 7000ppm.

Pollution is a much more pressing issue for the environment than CO2 emissions. And the "consensus" about climate change is false, perpetrated by people with a "vested interest" in being funded for more research using BILLIONS in taxpayer money.

While I acknowledge the reality of climate change, and I am also baffled by the ignorance displayed in the comments, I am skeptical about the solution proposed in the video.  As a student of history, I have yet to find a single innovation that came about by means of government force.  The only innovations I have ever come to find have been those of free scientific inquiry.  (And of course, the words "free" and "scientific" should certainly seem redundant!)  Climate change is a frightening reality.  There is no (intelligent) debate over that.  But I fail to see how any government (or coalition of governments, such as the UN) could solve this problem.  Sure, it could levy carbon taxes, as mentioned in the video, but how does this bring humanity closer to green energy?  What part does this multi-national masterminding have to play in the realm of scientific achievement?  True scientific achievement is never forced; it is only the product of free minds, and this of course includes achievements in the fields of alternative energy.

Malthusianism permeates our culture and it has very likely corrupted the minds of a great many scientists, building in them particular biases where bias in general is inevitable. This does not mean that they are incapable of doing good scientific work on the subject, but it does mean there is an especial need for an exchange between those who support the given theory and those who oppose it - those who have one bias and those who have the other. In today's culture there is a clear and obvious tendency to ignore or brush aside the objections of those who have a non-Malthusian bias. It is the widening political rift between left and right seeping into science and inhibiting healthy discussion. If each side of the scientific debate is isolated in a bubble then the scientific consensus is very likely arbitrary and non-indicative. There is no rational basis for a lay person to either cut his current energy usage by 90% or start paying 300% more for alternative energy sources, as this supposed catastrophe demands. If everyone did that our economy would go straight down the toilet and our quality of life would directly follow. Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.

Mathusian predictions have been staved off by switching from muscle power for farming, to machine power. Something that couldn't really have been foreseen at the time. However that sort of farming is now dependent on a steady supply of fossil energy. For most farming between 10 and 100 times more energy is put in via fossil fuels than is taken out, via food. Even if CO2 wasn't opaque to IR light, there's a finite amount of fossil fuel. We either switch to renewable energy, or we hit the mathusian catastrophe somewhere down the track (at this rate they all run out in about 50-100 years) Actually it turns out that moving the tax away from taxing work and into taxing energy, far from causing the economy to go down the toilet, makes it stronger. Putting spending money in the hands of the workers and insentivising more work makes the economy work better. Which is kinda what you'd expect if you thought about it for more than 3 seconds. After all, if taxing something makes people avoid it, which would you rather people avoid: working, or running the A/C on high? The Australian experience was that far from flushing the economy down the toilet, moving tax away from income tax and on to carbon tax caused the economy to grow 13% faster than the predicted rate.

@gasdive I do like intelligent, rational discussion. Again, you dismiss "other factors", not by deliberately discounting them, but instead by forgetting about them. We have a Grand Solar Maximum currently on deck, since 1900 - according to here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_maximum - what if that changes? I'm well aware of the *Milankovitch* cycles - though they seem a little slow to account for most of our "recent" temperature variation, so I'll skip them here. How about another factor: Ice cap size. I found articles on the antarctic ice cap reaching record size. Does that not cool the planet? Could that not overwhelm the effect of CO2? Some articles suggest that it is caused by global warming - but if it's an enduring effect, global warming could trigger an ice age! Net effect is the item of interest - not temperature relative to the counterfactual world that doesn't have our CO2. The bucket analogy is excessively simple. Let's extend it with 2 changes: the dripping tap is actually dripping onto the lip of the bucket, and the bucket is sitting on a spinning top. Maybe if the water level goes up the bucket will spin more slowly, which will reduce the leak rate. But the wobble induced might result in the water dripping out of the bucket, lowering the water level. Additionally, angular momentum is being lost, so the wobble might be inevitable whether the hole is blocked or not. You absolutely can no longer predict in this example whether the water level will go up or down, or even what the impact of partially blocking the hole will be. And this system is still absolutely trivial compared with the global climate. Your discussion of dramatic temperature changes is certainly scary. You've convinced me that there is a pressing need for research and modelling - and supercomputing capable of performing that modelling. But the concept of "We have to do something" when you have *no idea* what course of action will bring what result has never held water with me. Finally, your discussions of energy in vs energy out are intriguing - is there any data available for those who are not in the "scientific elite"? You'll have to excuse me if I don't trust the conclusions - the recent deliberate and documented data tampering scandal left me a little wary.

@Martin Jenkins Martin, You wouldn't know this but you're actually the first one I've ever spoken to in the, well lets call it “denialist” camp that's actually had any even vague attempt at a reasoned argument. I'm not sure if I can cope! Ok, you're perfectly correct that I've missed out a lot. I was attempting to give the bare bones of the subject, pretty much as it was first discovered 100 years ago. The bare bones establish conclusively that adding CO2 will increase the temperature of the planet. There's zero doubt about that any more than there would be zero doubt about the leaky bucket metaphor. Point 1, Incoming energy is it constant. (is the tap dripping at a constant rate). You're quite correct, it's not constant. There are at least 4 variabilities however none of them remove the basis of GW any more than a variability in the tap dripping means that the level of the water in the bucket isn't affected by the size of the leak. If you make the leak smaller (close the IR window) then the water level will be higher than it would otherwise have been. Orbital mechanics. The distance to the star, the orientation of the Earth to the star, the orientation of the ellipse and the oblateness of the ellipse. They get lumped together and called Malkovich cycles. They're all understood. If that was what was causing the temperature to rise we'd know about it. Actually the temperature should be falling very very slowly. 11 year solar cycles. The brightness of the star varies by an amount that adds up to about 0.25 Wm^-2 over each 11 year cycle. Reasonably well understood, or if not understood then at very least can be expected to recur regularly. Even when they're at their lowest, there is measurably more energy coming in than is leaking out. 0.58 Wm^-2 more energy was coming into the system in 2005-2010 (the last solar minimum) than was leaking out. Longer period solar cycles. Not yet actually observed but surmised to have been responsible for the medieval warm period. No sign of that happening at present. No stellar model really predicts them. Stellar evolution. The sun gets brighter as time goes on. (the tap drips faster). This actually means that previous high CO2 events aren't a completely reliable guide to what's happening now. Just because we got hot but there was no runaway then doesn't mean that we can be sure it won't happen today. We are absolutely sure it will runaway at some point but that point is currently about a billion years in the future (assuming we can't/don't trigger it early). Ok, so for point 1, you're right that the energy input is variable, but that doesn't change the basics of GW. Point 2 I'm not saying that CO2 is the only factor. I explicitly said that the other factors make calculating the final temperature outcome for a specific CO2 level difficult to impossible. I devoted more than half the post to that exact idea. If CO2 was the only factor, then we could simply plug the figures in and pop out the answer. It actually turns out that if we burn everything it's like turning the sun up by about 2.5%. It's completely trivial to work it out. You're wrong to say “Until we can model the climate with some accuracy, we won't know if the world is warming or cooling,” We can model if it's heating or cooling quite easily without knowing the details of the system. Going back to the bucket again. By knowing that the water level in the bucket is stable, knowing that the tap is dripping and knowing that it hasn't reached the lip of the bucket then you can say for sure that it's leaking and you can say for sure that blocking up the leak will make the water level go up. There's no doubt about that. It doesn't depend in any way on the shape of the bucket, the size of the bucket, the size of the leak, the current level of the water, the speed of the drips, or any other factor. In fact we can tell how fast water is accumulating in the bucket with just two figures, how much water is going in and how much water is coming out. That tells you everything you need to model water accumulation. Similarly, by measuring the energy arriving and energy leaving you can work out how much energy is accumulating on earth. That's been done. It turns out there's 3x10^14 W more coming in than leaving. This doesn't mean we know where that energy will end up or what the final temperature will be. That's important too and subject to on going research, however just to repeat, working out if it's warming, cooling or stable is completely trivial. It's warming. You ask the question: “Tell me, did a bunch of forest fires end the ice age?” Well actually, the worst ice age in history, was ended, not by forest fires, but by volcanoes, however the same principle applies. I think it also demonstrates how significant those positive feedbacks can be. Now I was careful to keep it to the well understood effects of CO2. It seems this has backfired somewhat in that you got the idea I didn't know about the other effects. So lets just explore this particular instance of positive feedback. Cast your mind back 600 million years. You'll see most long term climate graphs stop 550 million years ago and the reason seems to be that if you included the time before that the Y axis would be so compressed that you couldn't see any temperature variation at all after 550 million years ago. 600 million years ago the average temperature was about 50 degrees below. The world was completely frozen from pole to pole. There was no open ocean at all and the continent (the only one) was completely covered in ice. The conditions at the equator were about the same as we have on the Antarctic dome now. No precipitation at all. No visible life. Bleak white as far as the eye can see. Gradually volcanic action built up CO2 in the atmosphere. We're not completely certain what level it reached but it slowly warmed the planet and about 550 million years ago some ocean appeared. That darker ocean absorbed more heat than the white ice around it. That melted more ice and increased the amount of dark water that increased the amount of heat captured and so on. In a period too short for us to have identified how long it actually was, it looks instant in the geological record, the temperature jumped to plus 20 C. That positive feedback increased the temperature by near on 70 degrees C in a period too short for us to determine. So I gave the bare minimum of temperature change that will result from increasing the CO2. However the Earth has demonstrated that it can warm suddenly and by 70 degrees if pushed hard enough. It's not impossible that we could make another similar jump to a new stable temperature that's not compatible with life. When I gave the best case scenario that was the CO2 alone with no feedbacks like the ocean one. The worst case scenario is the one where the feedbacks work together. CO2 increases the amount of water vapour in the atmosphere (we've already observed this, it's about 5% higher than it was). Water vapour is a strong green house gas, so it increases the temperature at the surface. That feeds back for a while until the tundra melts. When it melts it releases 50 billion tonnes of Methane in under a year. That blocks a different part of the IR spectrum to the water and CO2, pretty much stopping up the leak completely. Enormous quantities of water evaporate into the atmosphere. Much of it makes it's way into the stratosphere. At that point it stops being the temperature of the surface that sets the amount of IR being emitted. It's the temperature of these very very high clouds. Light passes through them, the IR doesn't escape. The oceans evaporate, the surface pressure rises to 300 bar, dark still oxygen free and about 400 degrees C. That's what people call “alarmist” but there's a non zero chance of that being the outcome. The amount of solar radiation needed to produce that is as far as we can tell almost exactly the same as the current level of solar radiation. So to sum up I think I've demonstrated that it's not that complex to figure out if the Earth is going to heat up or not. We're sure that it is heating up and we know why. The minimum effect would come if there were no positive feedbacks, which is close to a zero probability, particularly as we've already seen evidence of positive feedback. The minimum effect will be to make the tropics uninhabitable. Much of the tropics are already close to the maximum temperature that humans can survive. The worst effect means everything dies.
