@gasdive You're missing a bunch of premises: 1) Energy arriving via visible light is largely constant 2) CO2 is the only changing factor in our energy balance 3) Our burning of fossil fuels is the major factor changing the CO2 balance #3 seems likely. #1 is incorrect, but can *maybe* be worked around. #2 is clearly absurd. Like totally absurd, I don't even understand how you could miss it. But it is an absolute requirement for your line of reasoning. Did you know human civilization is visible from space? How about the factor that the *colour* of the planet has changed? Oh, doesn't affect visible light... oh wait, sure it does. You know, solar panels are pretty reflective, a lot like ice caps. I could find factors all day, both natural and man made. Tell me, did a bunch of forest fires end the ice age? Then there was the Younger Dryas, when the fires went out, but humans with campfires warmed the planet up again... Come on. How come CO2 is the only factor now? Until we can model the climate with some accuracy, we won't know if the world is warming or cooling, and we won't know how to influence it. That's Science, followed by Engineering. I recall the doomsday predictions of global cooling when I was a kid, and I understand they're coming back into fashion. The fact is that our modelling is *still* inadequate. Now let's step outside the science of the matter and look at the engineering. Governments can't stop the CO2 output. The largest emitter is... China. 3rd is India. Bestaluck convincing them to let their people starve. On the other hand, is it possible to cool the planet down with atmospheric engineering? Apparently dust does the job rather well, and is naturally self-eliminating. It would likely be cheaper than cutting all that CO2 emission out - if necessary. What about warming the planet up? Well... that's actually harder. A blanket might keep you warm, but it won't do such a good job for objects without their own heat. Our core isn't a huge player in our energy balance, so we would need a tricky greenhouse blanket to try to keep the planet warm. Maybe we could put enough methane out there... maybe.

@Martin Jenkins I'm interested by your statement that your opinion can be changed by Science. Since the basic idea of global warming is over 100 years old and (nearly) completely classical rather than quantum, I'm sure you can follow it in a reasoned scientific argument. Ok, here goes. Here are the facts. Not theory, not opinion, just facts that anyone can verify (with a little equipment). 1) Temperature is a measure of the energy in a system 2) Energy arrives on Earth mostly as visible light 3) Energy leaves as Infra Red light (IR) and the amount is proportional to the 4th power of the absolute temperature (that's the only quantum part, the 4th power. The rest is classical) 4) If the amount of energy arriving is more than the amount leaving, the energy level (and temperature which is a measure of energy) goes up 5) CO2 is opaque to some IR. 6) We have released a lot of CO2 into the atmosphere, lots is still there. If you put those facts together then the basis of global warming can be no more scientifically contentious than the idea that if you put a leaky bucket under a dripping tap the level of water in the bucket will rise until the amount leaking out equals the amount coming in. If you partially block the leak the water level will rise. If you block up the leak completely, the water level will rise until it finds another way out, like over the lip of the bucket. To extend that metaphor, the "lip of the bucket" is the point where the surface temperature gets so high that the frequency of the IR light moves up into the visible. That's the situation on Venus where the rocks glow dull red. Ok so from that I think we can safely say that global warming is beyond a shadow of doubt. It is happening. The next thing is how much difference does increasing CO2 from 250 ppm to .... some other amount really make. Well that would be a reasonably simple calculation except for the fact that when you raise or lower the temperature of something as messy as the Earth (despite the fact that it actually *is* a spherical object in a vacuum) it changes it's reflectivity and it changes the composition of the atmosphere. That's where the science, though reasonably well nailed down, is open to some interpretation. Still, the amount of CO2 that would be released by "business as usual" is easily enough to cause catastrophic climate change *by itself*. It would make pretty much the entire tropical area uninhabitable. So that's about half the world population either die or move to your country (if you're outside the tropics). Remember that's the *best case* assuming that there are no positive feedbacks when you say, melt all the ice and turn it into black rock and dark ocean, release the methane stored in the tundra, release the methane stored as hydrates on the sea floor, increase the amount of water vapour in the atmosphere which is itself a strong IR blocker, that works at different frequencies to CO2, vastly extending the "blocking" effect. There are also negative feedback loops. Low cloud will limit the effect, but don't forget you can only get more low cloud if it's already hotter and if there's more water vapour (which pretty much means you only get this effect *after* the GW takes effect). If you include all the positive feedback loops and look at the worst case, it gets hot enough to sterilise the planet. Everything dies. Nailing down exactly where the reality lies is the only controversy left. Business as usual will result in something on that spectrum between best case (half the world's population moves elsewhere) and worst case (everything on the planet dies) So there you go. A well reasoned, fact based scientific argument. There's no theory, no contention, no wiggle room. It doesn't depend on looking at any data, you can do the experiments to confirm it in your kitchen if it's reasonably well equipped. We burn everything and the best case is half the world's population has to move or die. Worst case everything dies. Now are you convinced by the science? Can you take that to your right wing buddies and convince them?

Hi Martin, thanks for your thoughtful comments. Science is about consensus. When Einstein proposed his theory of relativity, there was no evidence and people thought he was nuts. Then over time the evidence started to mount and eventually scientists came to a consensus that the theory was a good one. Similar things happen with most theories like evolution or the big bang theory. You're right, the system is complex and so there is still a lot of uncertainty around future forecasts. Over time we will refine our models as we learn more about all the interacting bits and pieces. So far the observations have been in line with predictions: http://static.skepticalscience.com/pics/ProjvsObs.png I'd be happy to discuss the science of climate change but that was not my goal with this video because I thought this audience was already well aware of the science. There are plenty of good resources out there like NASA's page on it. I'm still trying to decide if it's worth me spending time making a video on the science of climate change instead of making a video about a different area of science.

P.S. The data I work with is financial data, so self-delusion over non-existent patterns is a daily risk - a risk in mainstream science that professional scientists deal with rather badly: http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21588069-scientific-research-has-changed-world-now-it-needs-change-itself-how-science-goes-wrong Displaying real science and showing how even professional scientists fail at science would reinforce the public's trust in science (at the expense of blind faith is scientists, which is not a good thing anyway).

One comment though. Science of global warming is well established, but the solution is not obvious. Physiscs can explain how it happens and what will be the consequences, but it can not solve it by itself. There are economic, sociological and technological challenges in this topic.

Carbon tax would work only if it was imposed globally. If it is imposed locally, companies just move their production to places where there is no such tax and continue to generate CO2. And there is no political entity that could impose global carbon tax.
Renewable technologies are potentially best solution, but they need large investments while they expensive, to let economies of scale kick in. So early adopters will pay most and gain least. Nobody wants to be early adopter, and most people wait for others to act, so that they could join when the prices fall.
Nuclear power could be a solution, but in reality we would need breeder reactors to satisfy our energy needs. And breeder reactors create huge risk of nuclear proliferation, so there are major concerns to their mass production.
Geoengeneering could also be a solution, but there is no way to test it safety. We have only one Earth and it is not very rational to experiment on it.

So athough there are many possible solutions, each has its drawbacks. That is why it is far from being obvious. We have a problem and we need to do something - but science can only get us that far. From this point politics must take over - and this is where things begin to complicate.

@Veritasium I apologize if I came across overly critical.  That was not my intent.  I love your channel (it's why I'm subbed) and I love it when I can share your (and other channel's) videos to my small network of people that might have a chance to see the good information you guys provide.  I guess something about this one in particular just sort of rubbed me the wrong way or something.  It's all good, honestly, you do consistently awesome work, and I appreciate it a ton.

@FlesHBoX Have you watched my previous videos? A lot of them focus on common misconceptions, which I uncover by talking to people on the street. I want to make sure I'm addressing the things people are really thinking, not what I imagine they know. For this audience, I expected the basics of climate change to be old hat. @Veritasium I respectfully disagree.  Focusing the entire first quarter of the video to pointing out just how ignorant people are sets the tone for the rest of the video as lamenting people not understanding the science.  One could even argue that the specific tactic you use is inherently dishonest.  I mean, honestly, how much footage were you unable to use because the people you interviewed actually DID know what it meant?  I'm not saying you actually did this, but this type of presentation opens this argument up and allows the opposition to invalidate your statements. You then go on to call out the opposition to "making up stories" instead of presenting facts that are "boring" and use the film Armageddon as an example of what climate change is like, except that Armageddon is but one example of disaster film.  Many films have been made (and we are regularly inundated with terrible films whenever the topic becomes a hot point and Hollywood sees an opportunity to make money) portraying climate change with "made up stories".  Both sides are just as guilty of that.  The difference is that when you have a made up story that happens to be in line with the science, it begins to invalidate the science as just more hollywood fluff. I guess my point ultimately was that when we are dealing with something as critically important as this particular topic, we need to be careful to avoid the traps of pointless bickering, calling names, and pointing fingers.  Maybe a more appropriate video to fit the title "climate change is boring" would be to show examples how how it isn't so that those of us who don't have the benefit of one million subscribers can share your good information. I understand that ultimately, this video was meant to promote the event and encourage participation, but at least follow YT best practices and include some kind of information in the description.  Links to your videos, or other channels who provide some of the information so that maybe we can start reducing the number of people who don't know, and make the next iteration of "ask the people" a little more difficult for you :)  That's all I'm saying. I love your channel and watch every new video faithfully because you have an excellent way of providing real facts and information in a way that is specifically NOT boring.  I guess I just expected more of that with this video.

This is a tough sell. Exaggerating the threat, even by a little, or sensationalizing it can back fire. For example, when I was in school in Miami, one of my science teachers routinely brought up the subject of the green house effect. She predicted things such as Miami Beach would disappear in 10 years; salt water intrusion would destroy the everglades in 10 years, the Brazilian rain forest would disappear in 10 years due to logging, and many, many other such predictions and I believed it all. 20 years later I feel as if I was lied to with exaggerated and maybe false statements, so now I instinctively turn skeptical about those topics because of that one science teacher. 

The focus should be in educating the public and not engaging in a back and forth battle of loud media hooks, daily doomsday predictions from Michio Kaku, liar liar pants on fire retort from skeptics, etc. I want to know what I can do around my personal bubble, my habits, my carbon foot print. 99.99% of us will not grab a picket sign and start yelling at people, but no entity has successfully communicated to us what we can realistically do.

Incidentally, the only reason recycling is become the norm is because it is now a viable profitable business. The solution to climate change is one that is profitable, rather than costly, and that will be the real long term solution.

I can't believe the comments on this video. I see countless prediction-quotes from the past that hasn't come true, lack-of-evidence-and-scientific-consensus claims and worst of all, people who say this is a political issue that doesn't belong on a science channel.

The assertion that this is a political issue is ridiculous. "What can and should be done about it" might be political, but the scientific data is not up for political debate any more than how to perform open heart surgery is. If you want your input on the matter to be heard, you'll have to know heart surgery first.

Regarding the evidence, It might be nice and simple to watch a documentary or read a news article, but if you really want to be sure that you're informed properly, read the scientific literature. If that's too much to ask (which would be understandable for anyone not in the field themselves), talk to actual experts in the field. Climate scientists! Not politicians, advocates, meteorologists or any other kind of scientists, but actual experts on the climate. 

Predictions that hasn't come true boils down to the same issue. They come from alarmists and advocacy groups on the other side of the spectrum. Blowing speculative worst case scenarios out of proportion isn't any more scientific than denying the data, even in the name of raising awareness.

@Veritasium I have been slowly coming around to the fact of man induced climate change (Climate Change would occur regardless of whether or not we are here). 

The problem is that I feel like people are more often than not fed confusing and convoluted information from both 'sides' of the argument. We have the extremist environmentalists who see Human prosperity on the earth as despicable and completely unsustainable, and also the extremist conservatives who simply don't want to admit there is even a problem.

So the question remains, how do we get the cold hard facts to the public rather than the inflated and over exaggerated opinions of the politically, monetarily and self righteously motivated? Lets quit exaggerating the reality of the situation where some claim we will be under water in 20 years time, and also quit ignoring the fact we are contributing to the globes climate change.

And I guess my real question for you is, why the hell do we not encourage the use of Nuclear Power? It is our most efficient, environmentally friendly and practical source of energy in this day and age. It emits less ambient radiation than coal power plants, requires less energy to construct than solar and wind farms and has a significantly smaller footprint than the equivalent solar or wind farm (which more often than not are detrimental to local fauna and flora).

It really seems like Nuclear Power is to the Greenies that Climate Change is to the Conservatives. There is simply no willingness to have an open mind about how we can tackle the problem, from either side. And that is what truly concerns me. We will get nowhere if there is not compromise, and simply arguing two completely unrealistic opinions and demands will only result in no action, which is what we can't afford to have.

NUCLEAR is the clear cut answer, at this point in time. And it shits me to tears that we have this unfounded fear of the greatest energy source available in this day and age.

Climate change is boring because it is not caused by humans, and so there is nothing we can do to stop it.  Furthermore, the science behind it is inaccurate at best, and fear-mongering at worst.

The sea level is rising, but the rate at which it is rising is not accelerating.  That rate (7in/century) has been holding steady since 1850, while our CO2 emission has been increasing exponentially.
The warming that we are seeing now is tiny compared to the huge swings that have occurred in the past.  The whole modern warming trend is in the noise floor of historic temperatures.
94.1% of surface temperature stations have inaccuracies of >1˚C, while scientists use them to make predictions of fractions of degrees.  Furthermore, inaccuracies tend upward, indicating warming.
The "science" is not established.  As recently as the 1970's, meteorologists "unanimously agreed" that we were entering a new ice age.  And if the "science" was established, then why did 31,000 scientists (including 9000 with PhDs) sign a petition denying it.
No climate change model has EVER accurately predicted future warming patterns.

@Conservative USSA Well the observables confirm it. We know where the extra CO2 comes from. We've observed the size of the holes in the ground and the balance sheets of industry. That matches the increase that we've observed by measuring the CO2 and comparing it with previous measurements or with old stored air. That's an observed fact not a theory. We put the extra CO2 there. The other observable fact is that water vapour and CO2 stops some of the IR leaving the earth. That's a fact that was first observed over a hundred years ago. You can check this yourself in your kitchen with a little bit of equipment. Or you can check it with a pencil and paper, but that's extremely hard. Doable but *very very* hard. Over a hundred years ago we also observed that the temperature of the Earth is about 33 degrees higher than it would be for a body of that albedo at this distance from the sun. You can check the maths yourself, it's not hard. So the globe is warmed compared to what it "should" be. That's another observable fact. You can check this by walking outside and seeing if you freeze to death in just a few minutes. The theory (not fact now, this is theory) is that global warming caused by CO2 and water vapour (which currently stands at 33 degrees warmer than normal) will be increased if you increase the amount of CO2 and water vapour. This is based on "symmetry". The expectation that if it worked for the first 33 degrees of warming, then the same mechanism will continue higher or lower values. The way to check that is to look at planets that have higher or lower values for GHG. We look at Mars, which has some CO2 but no water and we find that it agrees very well with predictions. It's very cold, so the theory is supported rather than refuted by the evidence. We look at Venus with *lots and lots* of CO2 and we find the same thing. It's temperature is in line with predictions. It's very hot and the theory is supported rather than refuted. Indeed every test of the theory so far supports it. There are *no* observations that disprove the theory. None at all. Sorry to burst your bubble there. So, now that you know the facts we can expect your opinion to change right? That's what science is. First you guess (you guessed that AGW doesn't exist), then you make a prediction based on that guess (you guessed that evidence would be found that refutes AGW) then you check with reality (you've checked now) and if the prediction doesn't match reality then the guess was wrong. (Your prediction doesn't match). It doesn't matter how much you like the guess, how vested you are in the guess being right, how many people with letters after their name agree with the guess, if it doesn't match reality, it's wrong. Recognising that, you'll now change your opinion, or if you don't then you need to face up to the fact that you are the sort of person who will hold a belief despite knowing it to be false. That's not that unusual, but it's often hard to get your head around that you are delusional. Part of the problem of being able to delude yourself into believing things you know to be wrong is that it's not a big step from there to believing that you're not delusional. The tool that you use to fix that problem is in fact the same tool that's broken in the first place. I'm interested to see if you change your mind or just get angry and start repeating things you know to be false. (or just ignore me instead as too uncomfortable to deal with)

@Conservative USSA Proof?  There are lots of ways to "prove" it. One is to assume that the number of volcanoes belching today is roughly the same that have been belching over the past 800,000 years.  Their CO2 is trapped in the various ice cores that have been drilled in Greenland and the Antarctic.   The atmospheric CO2 has been relatively steady over that period, and hadn't exceeded 300ppm during that entire record. Since 1750, we humans have been burning a fairly well-documented amount of fossil fuels.  The increase of CO2 in the atmosphere is reflecting that consumption fairly linearly (the ocean has been absorbing about half of the added human output, and that can be measured by the increased acidity (or "decreased basic") of the seawater.).

Solar cycles aren't phases. The moon has phases, it varies from about 1% to 100% brightness over a month. Solar cycles vary the amount of energy reaching us over an 11 year cycle. It varies by about 0.25 w/m^2 during that cycle. That's 99.98% to 100% over eleven years. (nothing like the dramatic change that comes from phases). The energy imbalance measured during the very bottom of that cycle in 2010 was still 0.58 watts more energy was coming from the sun than able to leave via IR light. So no, the effects of the cycles (that you call phases) on the climate are completely swamped by the CO2. I've been following this for over 25 years. The only predictions that I've seen that were "wrong" turned out to be on the conservative side. It has turned out to be somewhat worse than most predictions advised us and the effects are happening earlier than expected. The environment turned out to be somewhat more sensitive than expected.

Hmm, 96% confidence region is quite powerful is statistics, but in sciences like physics or economics it is only as valid as the underlying assumptions. For example, when the 2008 economic crisis occurred, experts quantified the event to fall outside of the 5-sigma interval with respect to some parameters of importance. AKA the underlying statistical model was simply wrong, because such improbable events do not happen by chance
In short, high confidence of an observable does not prove a theory. High confidence of an observable proves that you have observed what you think you have observed given that the theory is right

Here's how it works and it's so simple that remembering how it works makes all the doubters look like idiots (because they are). Below I list some *facts*. These are not opinions, they're not up for debate. 1) temperature is a measure of the amount of energy in a system. 2) if energy in equals energy out, the temperature stays the same 3) if energy in is more than energy out the temperature goes up 4) the Earth gets energy in from the sun mostly as visible light, that makes it warm 5) warm things emit energy in the form of infrared light and the warmer they are the more energy they emit. 6) the Earth has heated up until the amount of infrared energy leaving equalled the amount of energy arriving as visible light 7) CO2 blocks infrared light From those facts you can see that if you let energy in as visible light and stop it leaving as infrared, the temperature will go up until it's warm enough that the amount of energy leaving as infrared again equals the amount arriving as visible light. It really is that simple.

Ok, too much misinformation in one post to correct all of it. So just the major points. Volcanoes recycle carbon that has fallen to the sea floor and been subducted. It's not new carbon, it's just a very long period carbon cycle. It's exactly equal (in the long term) to the amount of carbon being removed by subduction. Volcanoes add nothing to the amount of carbon in the system. Consensus is a strawman argument. There's plenty of actual science that shows human caused global warming happens. It's based on facts. You can have your own opinion but not your own facts. These are the facts. These are not opinions, they're not up for debate. 1) temperature is a measure of the amount of energy in a system. 2) if energy in equals energy out, the temperature stays the same 3) if energy in is more than energy out the temperature goes up 4) the Earth gets energy in from the sun mostly as visible light, that makes it warm 5) warm things emit energy in the form of infrared light and the warmer they are the more energy they emit. 6) the Earth has heated up until the amount of infrared energy leaving equalled the amount of energy arriving as visible light 7) CO2 blocks infrared light From those facts you can see that if you let energy in as visible light and stop it leaving as infrared, the temperature will go up until it's warm enough that the amount of energy leaving as infrared again equals the amount arriving as visible light. It really is that simple.﻿ The North American fossil fuel industry alone makes 1/4 of a *trillion* dollars per year by digging up carbon and burning it. If you think that they're happy to "find a[nother] way to make money" you're an idiot. They will and do fight tooth and nail to protect an income that's larger than most country's GDP Science doesn't work by taking opinion polls and giving the results that the public wants. Doing that is scientific suicide. To do that would require fabricating results. When that was discovered, and it would be, the scientists involved would lose everything. Their job, any chance of another job, any grants. It would be the end of them. Though the fossil fuel lobby often cites this flow of grant money as the reason scientists fabricate results, the reality is the *exact* opposite. Fabricating results would end the flow of grant money, completely and forever. Evolution (by natural selection) has nothing to do with global temperatures. Planetary climate is *not* self correcting and *doesn't* tend toward a habitable environment for humans to enjoy. The climate is a chaotic system that has many strange attractors. (sorry, stable points where it will sit for long periods if dropped there). Venus is an easy example of a different strange attractor for a very similar planet. 3 billion years ago the amount of sunlight Venus received was about the same as Earth gets now. There was no "self-correction" that held it to a state similar to Earth's now. CO2 built up and the temperature rose unchecked until the emission of infrared matched the absorption of visible light. That's at a temperature hot enough to melt lead.

@Cheyenne Layton We are not concerned about melting sea ice (well, we are, but because it increases the amount of sunlight absorbed by the oceans if it goes away, not because it causes sea level rise. We are concerned with land ice. This is ice over land, such as parts of the Arctic and Antarctic, and most notably Greenland. When that ice melts, it runs down rivers into the ocean, where it really does increase the sea level, because before melting it wasn't taking up space in the ocean before. Also, I agree, "the sea will cover most of the arable land" is garbage. Because it's not what the predictions say for the short term. They say that in the next 100 years, permanent and more frequent temporary flooding will impact all coastal areas. Areas like Bangladesh and Eastern India with all their arable land right near sea level will be dramatically impacted, but the US's arable land will be almost completely unaffected. However, all the cities around the world that are right on the coasts will end up with huge problems with flooding, and they'll have to spend far more money than they probably have in order to protect themselves from almost constant damage.  Because of the measured sea level rises in the last while, Manhattan used to have a 1% chance of flooding every year in the 1850's, but now has a 25% chance of flooding every year. This percentage is not a prediction, this is based on measured data. So it's very much a real thing that way. There are small variations year to year that mean even though the overall trend of temperatures is clearly that it is getting hotter and hotter all the time, it doesn't meant that you necessarily get each year warmer than the previous one. It's called noise.

One of the dumbest things humans regularly seem to do is gain an opinion on a complex topic by considering lots of arguments from multiple sides of the debate, without learning enough to be an expert on the topic. It doesn't matter if I had been a leading professor in multiple fields in my life: I still would be a layperson for most subjects that I would encounter. We as human individuals are so limited in terms of what we can do or learn, but we are surrounded by a huge network of individuals that collectively know a TONNE. Instead of trying to tap into that vast bank of knowledge by considering areas of scholarly consensus and evaluating any potential biases, most people try to make an informed decision on what they consider to be the main arguments for each and every topic that they interact with. It is very fulfilling and rewarding to learn more about physics, history, economics, politics, etc., and in doing so we can more rapidly find (and better consider) any related scholarly consensus. But if we decide that our opinions on complex topics should mainly rely on our genuine understanding of each of those topics, then we ostracise ourselves from the modern world: A caveman lost in the library of modern enlightenment.

I'd agree if this was a complex topic. However it isn't complex. Energy arrives on Earth as visible light, passing through the atmosphere almost undiminished. The ground warms up above absolute zero as a result. It then emits IR. When the amount of energy leaving the planet as IR equals the amount arriving as visible the temperature stops rising. If you block the IR from leaving (which CO2 does) then the temperature will go up. While "Up" is simple, and certain, how much it will go up is a bit complex if you want an exact amount. The current amount of CO2 and water vapour keeps it 33 degrees higher than it would otherwise be. We've nearly doubled the CO2 and that's also increased the water vapour by about 5%. Naively you'd have to think another 10-20% more than the current 33 degrees. So 3-6 C. However higher temperature means more water vapour. More water vapour might mean more clouds. Low clouds reflect more incoming light while also emitting IR, while high clouds (like Venus) don't emit much IR while allowing some visible light through, effectively decoupling the surface from the negative feedback (of higher surface temperatures meaning more IR emissions). That allows the surface to heat up without any particular blocking point until the emissions reach the visible spectrum. (that's us all dead then) But, do we need an "exact amount"? No, we need to know if it will be enough to make life unpleasant, or impossible. Well It's already made life unpleasant for a lot of people and we're not even half way there. So "Unpleasant" is a certainty. Making life impossible is on the cards but that's a complex question. Is that a question we need answered? Should we take action on just "Unpleasant"? Those are complex questions that can't be answered by climate scientists. Will we long term kill 1-7 billion people to preserve the medium term profitability of corporations? Some say that's a good idea, some don't.

@John .Fielder The bonds between the carbon and oxygen atoms can become excited by infrared radiation (causing them to wiggle rapidly back and forth). Then other air molecules knock into the CO2 and the energy is transferred to them making them move faster. The air is now warmer and the CO2 has relaxed. Then the CO2 absorbs another IR photon and the process repeats. Try this out: @Climate%20Change/swf/videos/CollisionalHeating.swf
@Veritasium Yeah, that's what we were told in lectures. But what I don't get is how CO2 traps IR radiation. What's the mechanism for that?

@John .Fielder Hi John, CO2 traps infrared radiation. Sunlight hits the Earth, which absorbs it and re-radiates it into space as infrared radiation. For a long time the amount of energy being absorbed by the Earth was equal to the amount of energy radiated into space so the temperature of the Earth was constant. Now due to significantly higher levels of CO2 in the atmosphere, more infrared radiation is trapped on Earth so we are absorbing more energy than we are radiating into space, hence the temperature is increasing.

Unfortunately this is another video of incomplete information. The majority of carbon dioxide is released by nature. Human activity is responsible for about 3%. The story is that this extra 3% is upsetting the delicate balance. If that were true then the atmosphere would be very sensitive to changes in the carbon dioxide content and a runaway condition could and would be expected to be possible. 

The climate does not care where the carbon dioxide comes from it simply reacts to it. The oceans are one of the great storage mediums of carbon dioxide. Cold water can hold more carbon dioxide in solution than warm water can. When it gets warmer the oceans release more of this gas but this gas is then trapped by trees and other vegetation. There are many other traps and sinks also at work. There has to be because we have not seen run away climate in the past. Again I must restate the climate does not care where the carbon dioxide comes from.

It can be argued that many other factors cause warming on a scale needed to affect the climate but the release of carbon dioxide has always happened after the warming in the past. Yes, carbon dioxide is a minor green house gas but it also seems to trigger activity which actually leads to cooling once the concentrations reach a certain level.

We do not fully understand how this happens as yet but one of the ways suggested is that because the climate is already warmer when the extra carbon dioxide is released from the oceans that this spurs greater plant growth and with the longer growing seasons this eventually changes the reflectivity index enough to trigger gradual cooling. Again this might only be the result and not the driving force.

The main reason for climate change is the total energy input to the system is not constant. Like many things in nature very small changes at the input side can have large changes at the out put. This is why I think that human activity has surely affected the climate but carbon dioxide output is not the major drivers of human influence. Particulants change the amount of energy that gets to the surface. Cities, roads, agriculture have all contributed but how much is under debate. 

Reasonable methods must be used to reduce contaminants released into the atmosphere but remember nature will still dwarf our activities. Volcanic eruptions spew millions upon millions of tons of contaminants. Under sea vents, eruptions and other massive geological events dwarf our contributions and are not constant but happen at seemingly unpredictable intervals and yet the climate has survived and remained habitable.

@Timothy Bushra Ok, I'll give it a go. Yes, if CO2 goes up, some plants grow faster and take up more CO2. That CO2 doesn't leave the biosphere. When the plant dies and either rots or burns, the CO2 goes back into the air. So plant life can form a sort of "buffer" storing some of the carbon for a few years but it doesn't solve the problem. There are actually much larger buffers than plants. Most of the Carbon that we've emitted has been absorbed by the ocean, making it more acid. If we emit carbon until serious problems start, we won't fix them by just stopping emissions because that carbon dissolved in the ocean (and to a much smaller extent in plants) will come back out. We won't have to just deal with the carbon that's in the atmosphere, but also the carbon in these other buffers.

Al Gore is an irrelevant hack if you ask me. He is neither a climate scientist nor does he represent the science in any way. Regarding that Daily Mail article, it makes me sad. It makes me sad that people actually just read the headline, and assume that they are being accurate and telling the truth, and that they don't do a basic google search to find out more about what's actually going on. The actual figures (http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/) show the real pattern. That 2012 was the record low year, hugely below anything ever seen before and well below the expected melt due to the ongoing pattern of ice extent getting less each year. Saying that 2014 has more ice than 2012 does not mean that the overall pattern is wrong -- it means that there was an unusual event, and the overall pattern hasn't yet 'caught up' to causing more melting than that unusual event did. But the overall pattern does not seem to be broken -- sea ice extent numbers are continuing to decrease across the larger timescales (eg the 5 year average). This is like when people complain about getting cold temperatures for a day, and use it to disprove global warming -- the weather of a single day in a single place has almost nothing to do with climate patterns. The small events average out into trends. We don't care about how hot it was last tuesday, we care about what the 20-year trend in temperatures have been, and what will happen if that continues. We don't care about how much ice there was in 2012, we care about the overall trend in sea ice loss, and what will happen if that trend continues. The article is making a mountain out of a molehill. Annual arctic sea ice extent in 2014 is lower than almost any time in history, it's the 4th lowest arctic sea extent ever. A single data point does not make or break a trend. But the Daily Mail article is trying to pretend that it does.

Just some comments: China and India combined produce about 30% of the world's CO2. The US alone produces 20% -- add in Canada and Europe, and that about gets you up to the 30% level. But note that the per-capita CO2 emissions of China and particularly India are tiny compared to the US. Also note that China and India are the world leaders in overall investments for renewable and low-carbon energy projects, and are very aggressively taking steps to phase out coal as much as possible. Coal is currently 70% of energy supplied in China, and they're planning on getting that down to 40% by 2020. In fact, by 2017, the amount of annual CO2 China will have reduced over 1996 levels will be three times the amount the EU has accomplished since then. So they are most definitely doing their part.

I'd have to disagree with you completely on this one. The act of recycling is reusing materials such as plastic and paper so they do not have to be re-manufactured. So by recycling old material, you are cutting out costs used to make material from scratch. Paper, for example, would require hiring workers to chop down trees, using energy to transport those trees to a manufacturing faculty, where then even MORE energy would be used to process that lumber into the paper we see everyday. Hey, you explained how most people don't know how to reduce global warming, but you never taught what does. Granted, I'm sure the majority of your viewers are informed, I still think it would be good of you to make one clarifying the common misconceptions and showing best practices to reduce carbon footprints.

Here are some things I do/have done to reduce my carbon footprint:
- I have change my driving style; I drive slower, but with more constant speed and try to keep engine on low revs. In the end, I keep getting in same time as I use to when I was going "pedal-to-the-metal". As result, I spend 20-30% less fuels with same car for same trip from home to work each day.
- thermal insulation of my house; great way to reduce heating/cooling expenses and emissions of gases as result of that heating (in case of cooling, consumption of electricity)
- I got couple cheap solar panels to charge couple batteries during day, and they are used to power my garden and driveway lighting during night; it looks cool and it's free
- changed all bulbs to LED bulbs; got same quality of light as with tungsten bulbs, without mercury that's in halogen bulbs or headache inducing blinking. And LED bulbs use just 10% of energy needed for same light given by tungsten bulbs. Extra benefit: way lower electricity expenses.

Over all, none of those things ware extremely expensive (ok, thermal insulation of entire house was, but in long run it was not, and if you take a loan for it, most of that loan will be covered by savings you will have on heating and cooling), and most of those things even made me save bunch of money.

Things I plan to do:
- solar heating for hot water
- move my office closer to my home, so that I can go to work by foot or with bike.
- replace some old devices in my house with ones that use less electricity (A+ class)

"The hole in the ozone layer is a problem, but it's not a major cause of climate change"

The major cause seems to be the scientists that have put false numbers into the models in their mad dash to get grant money based on their predictions of 'gloom and doom'.

The predictions you are talking about (flooding, extinctions) are predictions they made for 100 years or more down the line, not for the last 20 years. No one said this was a short-term concern. If you thought that, you misunderstood what was being said. The predictions I was mentioning were the per-decade average increases in temperature and how they match up almost exactly with the IPCC predictions. If those increases continue for another 2 or 3 decades, that's when the more dramatic effects will start to be observed. The increase in flooding however is already happening-- due to the increase in sea level so far, the annual risk of Manhattan being flooded went from less than 1% per year in the 1860s to 20-25% per year now (http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014GL059574/abstract). As this trend continues elsewhere, it will require a huge infrastructure investment, representing a significant portion of the economy and GDP, to prevent continual losses from these more common high-water flooding events caused by sea level rise. So in actuality, even though the scientists weren't predicting widespread flooding so soon, we're already seeing concrete proof that it's beginning to happen, and that the only explanation for it is the increase in sea level. The statistic about Antarctica you heard is misquoted. Antarctica is gaining seasonal SEA ice, that much is true. But it is losing LAND ice much faster than it ever has. Seasonal sea ice comes and goes every year, and doesn't affect sea levels when it melts or freezes, so it's actually of little concern in terms of flooding or climate patterns. What's of greater concern is that the land ice that takes many thousands of years to form is disappearing quicker than ever. In fact, the huge amount of fresh water runoff that goes into the ocean around Antartica due to the melting is what's responsible for the increase in sea ice! The fresh water dilutes the salt water, which raises the freezing level slightly and makes it easier for sea ice to form. Lots more info here: http://www.skepticalscience.com/antarctica-gaining-ice-intermediate.htm Not to mention that other than Antarctic Sea Ice, every other source of ice (Greenland, Arctic Land Ice, Arctic Sea Ice, Glaciers, Antarctic Land Ice) is melting faster than ever before. The 97% consensus figure is based on an assessment of 12,450 journal-published peer-reviewed papers by climate scientists. It's actually 98.1% if you tally it by number of scientists (out of 10,188 scientists). See theconsensusproject.org for details. It has been repeated by several other organizations and analysis as well and they all find approximately 97-98% as the consensus amount. I hadn't heard about the NASA/NOAA thing, so looked it up. This article explains it thoroughly: http://www.geotimes.org/aug07/article.html?id=WebExtra081607_2.html It's sensationalist to claim it was "manipulating data", they were applying a correction for an error that was caught. They fixed a mistake. It's not a big deal. In fact, the correction had the effect of reducing the temperatures since 2000, so it served to slightly reduce the amount of warming they were reporting. (And yet the amount they're reporting even after the correction is still way too much to be explained by non-human sources of CO2).

No, their predictions haven't.  We aren't flooded, the animals aren't extinct, and the ice in the Antarctic is growing, not shrinking.   There is not 97% consensus, there is close to 97% in VERY small surveys that are not even representative of the scientific community.  And NASA and NOAA have been caught manipulating temperature data.

Their predictions have very closely matched what's happened. We've been having this argument for over 20 years now. Back in 1995 the IPCC predicted a rate of warming of 0.14C/decade. It's actually been warming at a rate of 0.15C/decade. So their "doom and gloom" predictions actually slightly underestimated the warming, and none of their predictions have been out of line (eg outside of confidence intervals) with what has ended up happening in the intervening years. There's not really such thing as a scientific fact. The Higgs Boson existing is not a scientific fact. It is merely proven to certain high degree of confidence.  The same is true of man-made global warming. It can never be a scientific fact. It can only be proven to a certain degree of confidence. The question then becomes, if it is a continuous scale between "unproven" and "completely certain" at what point do you accept it as true, what's your cutoff? Do you accept it as "true" or "proven" or "scientific fact" if there's a 50% chance it's true? 90%? 99%? 99.999%?  Going back to this situation, here's the basis for the claim: if they run a computer model of the climate going back the last 20 years, and include the human contribution to CO2, you end up very closely to what we ended up observing over that last time period. But if you exclude the CO2 emissions of humans, you end up with basically zero temperature increase, which is not what we observe. But both the models and observations have probabilities and confidence intervals and uncertainties associated with them, so it's not a matter of right or wrong. More accurately: the numbers say that when you run the models without the known CO2 emissions from humans (eg if you assume Humans don't cause climate change), then there is only a 1% chance that you end up with the temperature and CO2 increases that we've observed. Or to put it another way: the only possible way to explain the increases in CO2 and temperature that we've seen in the last 20 years is that it was caused by human CO2 emissions, and that we're about 99% confident about that statement. Or to put it in another context: If 99/100 doctors told you that you'd die in the next 5 years if you didn't start a treatment, but 1 doctor said you'd be fine, what would you do?

@Veritasium First off, thank you for taking the time to respond to me. I greatly respect how you are being so communicative with your subscribers.  What troubles me about your response to changing people's minds is that even when talking to people in person, you realized many people have no idea how climate change works, and met people who doubt its existence. You said in the video "So what I've learned is, people don't know how climate change works and don't know what to do about it."  Also, you've done videos on way more understood and simpler topics, such as where trees get there mass, where the sun gets its energy, and how insulation works on a piece of ice. It would be greatly informative to the public if you made an entertaining and understandable video on climate change. It could be particularly useful in America, where as of 2014, only 65% of the public believe global warming is happening/will happen within their lifetimes (Gallup poll on Global Warming, 2014).  On policy, major fossil fuel companies don't represent all interests at play when considering the carbon tax, and any tax will be contentious to the public. In fact, energy companies tend to pass on their expenses to the consumer through price increases, which the consumer will pay for due to the inelastic demand on electricity and fossil fuels.  This leads me to my first contention: a carbon tax would be a burden on the public, and therefore on the economy as a whole. Making CO2-emitting energy artificially more expensive drives up the costs of living for everyone, and negatively effects both the consumption and the production of goods in the economy. The carbon tax is also effectively a regressive tax, meaning that poorer individuals are more effected by the increase in energy cost when compared to richer individuals. Other negative effects of the carbon tax includes the fact that there will be administrative costs, which reduces the efficiency of the tax. There is a possibility of tax evasion, where firms hide their carbon emissions as a result of the higher taxes. Production may shift to other countries with lower or no carbon tax. And lastly, the negative externality of CO2 is very difficult to measure, and would make it very hard to determine the correct tax percentage. Instead of supporting a policy which includes all of these negative, unintended consequences, why not support solutions with less drawbacks? Instead of burdening the public with more taxes, how about we give tax credits to those that reduce their carbon emissions. Instead of hurting the economy to try to help drive research and develop of alternative energy sources, we could make R&D prizes to promote innovation. Instead of limiting the energy market to reduce pollution, we could expand the energy market by removing regulatory barriers for deploying new energy production technologies. These are cost effective solutions to reduce CO2 emissions that will also provide the pathway to a permanent solution of alternative clean technology, all without burdening the public through excessive taxation.   In reality, the free market is already coming up with fantastic, new technologies that will replace pollution with cleaner, more efficient energy sources. The more consumers demand cleaner technology, the more producers will attempt to fulfill that demand. More efficient solar panels, better windmills, expansion of nuclear energy, research in fusion and thorium nuclear technologies, hydro power, and geothermal energy are all on the rise, even if the government did nothing about it. I have an optimistic view of the future, because I believe that human ingenuity and innovation will greatly decrease anthropogenic climate change, before it turns into a global disaster.  Thank you again if you find the time to read this comment. I know that it's very long, but it is necessary to get all my points across.

@Joel J Our respiration cycle does not increase or decrease the net amount of carbon in the system a significant amount over the timescales we're concerned with . It just cycles it. The problem with burning fossil fuels is not that it produces carbon, per se, but that it is reintroducing carbon that has not been in the cycle for millions of years. The last time that carbon was in the air was when the things that produced those fossil fuels, millions of years long dead plants and animals, were alive. And not just that, but that it reintroduces it at a rate many times greater than the rate at which carbon gets naturally sequestered in the Earth. To recap, by burning fossil fuels we're putting carbon dioxide back into the system much faster than the Earth's natural processes can sequester it. This is why, for example, burning biofuels isn't so bad, as the carbon put back into the atmosphere by burning them was taken out of the atmosphere a very short time ago, when the plant that supplied the biofuel was growing. So, the net co2 gain is zero if the biofuel is produced without using energy from a carbon producing source.

I think there are two big issues that need to be addressed:

1. The idea of a 97% consensus of all climate scientists--what is the source of this? Such a consensus isn't required for something to be true, and using bad data isn't a good way to defend science. Maybe there's good data on 97% of all climate scientists agreeing on some aspect of climate change (more on that below), but I'd be wary of repeating the 97% statistic given the nature of the sources I've seen. And I'm especially wary of this given that it doesn't matter for establishing the truth. Is there a real, solid source for this 97%?

2. What exactly is the consensus about? This is much more important than the above point. And there's great value in making this more clear.

Is it a consensus that CO2 has a logarithmic decreasing warming effect as more is added to the atmosphere?

Is it a consensus that the CO2-cased warming is amplified to a certain degree by other factors (and specifically how much)?

Is it a consensus that the degree of change in the climate is both beyond our current ability to adapt and will outpace our ability to adapt technologically--and lead to a net decrease in living quality?

Whatever it is, I think it needs to be something more clear and specific than what I'm writing here. I mean these as just an indication of the type of options, but it needs to be something that is clear, specific, falsifiable...scientific. Otherwise, it's really framed as a non-scientific issue. And that can't be good for the cause of science.
If you want to know the consensus, read the IPCC report.  They are very, very clear about it.

I am fairly agnostic about climate change, but to say that the science is well established simply means that an idea is ingrained into the psyche of the scientific community, but just because the majority of people within that community agree, that doesn't make it correct.  Scientists are no more immune from allowing their vested interests to cloud their judgement than anyone else, especially as there is a 'toe the line or else' mentality within certain sections of the scientific community.  Would this be the first time there was a general consensus on a scientific theory that was later shown to be false?
 
The problem with any kind of absolute certainty is that it is always made by human beings, who, by the very limitations the human experience places on them, can never know anything for certain.  All they have, like the rest of us, is information which is filtered through their egos that becomes 'truth' based on their own experiences, interpretation of data, biases etc. I would always be wary of anyone who claims to know anything for certain, because it shows a complete lack of understanding of how the limitations of the 5 sense human experience makes that physically impossible.

Oh, and you *couldn't* be more wrong about scientists. The path to fame and (meagre) fortune for a scientist is to disagree with the consensus. If a scientist somewhere found proof that CO2 doesn't absorb IR light it would be such an enormous "paradigm changing" result that their career would be assured. Far from being "fired" they'd never have to do another lick of work again and every institution would clamour to have them on their staff.

We don't know for sure whether temperatures will just keep rising, but that is a possibility.  Obviously if it occurred it would be disastrous.   If the industrial revolution never happened, yes, the planet would warm, but it would do so on the same natural timeframe as has happened in previous cycles, which took tens of thousands of years.  The claim by climate scientists is not that the world is going to be hotter than it ever was (although that's possible) but that temperatures are going to start rising at rates that have serious repercussions for the earth's ecosystem - and the humans who inhabit it.

@Andrew M Accelerated sea level rise has never been supported by the data and predictions in that area have failed to match reality. Warmer climate may increase available farm land and CO2 has been shown to accelerate plant growth.

Yes, humans survived a warmer climate in the past, but there were a few hundred million people on the planet in the middle ages, and there are 7 billion of us now, living in places we didn't live then, and relying primarily on agriculture for food.  The main threat is not the absolute temperature but the rate at which it is going to increase.  If ocean levels rise a few feet over 1000 years, no big deal, you can relocate all of New York City if you need to, gradually over many generations.  A few feet over 50 years has a tremendous impact on enormous numbers of people in low lying areas around the globe.  If a region becomes inhospitable for farming over a period of 1000 years, no big deal.  If it happens very quickly, that's a bigger problem. Many factors affect global temperatures on a geologic time scale, but the emission of CO2 is the major factor on a human time scale.  It's true that one day a factor like the eccentricity of earth's orbit might help offset the effect of CO2, but that's thousands of years away, and in the meantime, over the next 100 years or 200 years, humans are going to encounter problems as the climate changes.
So what are the obvious solutions?

Climate change, (and particularly, the alarmist approach to "educate" people about it,), is not only boring, but also it's real impacts are very questionable, in the light of last decade's global temp rise data (happens much MUCH slower, then even the most conservative warming models predicted, and for much lower increases of CO2 than in reality, also the positive outcomes of global warming seem to outweigh the negative - but of course, it is taboo to even mention that).

Most importantly, carbon taxes are retarded, costly and terribly inefficient way of trying to solve important global humanitarian problems (of which, global warming shouldn't be even on the top of the list) .

I suggest to check out "cool it" and "sceptical environmentalist", by Bjorn Lomborg, and keep an open mind.

Lastly, I don't remember when the scientific method has changed from "the verifiable, repeatable truth is (...)", and into "the majority consensus is (...) ". According to this completely idiotic approach, we would still teach that the earth is flat, and is the centre of the universe - because in Galileo's time "the majority of scientists (in fact, ALL of them) have had TOTALLY agreed, it is the case".

Science is not about voting, it is about evidence and objective truth. @Veritasium  Not really a good analogy.  Cancer is very well understood and has been accurately observed and recorded in a bajillion occurrances.  Climate has been observed for a minute fraction of the time it has existed and it has been misdiagnosed at least once by a significant number of climate scientists in the last 30 years.  Even Mann at the IPCC said that we should expect a global cooling trend just some 30 years ago along with a gaggle of other scientists who were warning us about the impending man made ice age.  Also, We can watch cancer progress and can rather accurately predict what the situation will be in the future without treatment.  World CO2 output has increased dramatically in the last 12-15 years, but temperature hasn't followed.  The correlation isn't very solid.  This is exactly like ten doctors saying that you have cancer and all of them are at least partially wrong.  I understand that this doesn't mean that human CO2 output isn't a part of global warming, but it strongly implies that blaming global warming on human activity is premature.

You're right, a consensus does not make something a fact, but it is highly suggestive. If ten doctors independently diagnosed you with cancer, it doesn't mean they are all correct, but I'd bet they are. In this debate, there are scientists studying the data for their whole lives and trying to give reasonable recommendations, and then there are 7 of the 8 richest companies in the world that trade in fossil fuels. If someone has a vested interest, I'm betting it's more likely the oil companies than the scientists.

Another way to say it is that volcanoes pump out about 0.3 gigatons of CO2 per year.   Human activities pump out about 34 gigatons of CO2 per year (2012).. Volcanoes are at present exactly in balance with CO2 absorption. Over the long term CO2 is removed from the atmosphere falling on the ocean floor. It's then subducted and returned via volcanic action. Just a very long period carbon cycle. So the CO2 added to the system by Volcanoes is zero. Humans have added approximately 350 gigatonnes.
http://www.skepticalscience.com/volcanoes-and-global-warming.htm

It's not hard to find, just compare the output of CO2 from fossil fuels by humans (35.1 billion tonnes in 2013) and the output from volcanoes (about 0.32 billion tonnes http://volcanoes.usgs.gov/hazards/gas/climate.php). Man-made global warming is real, and you skeptics are just going to have to accept it. It's really simple, if you think about it. In order to maintain our current way of life, we produce ridiculous amounts of CO2 into the atmosphere. It only takes a few seconds to look up the amount of CO2 that the average human produces. The emissions are byproducts of our energy production, farming practices, and cattle raising And it's exacerbated by the elimination of forests that would otherwise absorb some of the emitted CO2.

We know enough to know through geological studies that when CO2 levels increase, it leads directly to an increase in Earth's temperatures.

Yes, the Earth goes through these cycles throughout its history, and whether we were here or not, the Earth would eventually go through another climate shift. The problem is: we ARE here now, and we're a major contributing factor to the problem. If you recall from earth's history, climate shifts have devastating effects on the plants and animals living at that time. Personally, I would prefer to not go through a mass-extinction event at this precise time.

I totally agree with your sentiment.  Last year, I ran a social media campaign and petition to stop a gas pipeline from going through my local forest.  I made a channel (keepthefrackout) and posted a few videos, but everyone told me they were boring.  And to be honest, they were boring.  It is hard to make this stuff interesting.  Once i started talking about the corruption i faced at the local, state, and federal levels, then people tuned in and became interested.

Though anthropogenic climate change leading to global warming is well established, the solutions to the energy problem are not yet in place. Of course, if the whole world agrees that we shall change our entire economic model and ensure equitable growth while also ensuring minimal environmental costs, then it would work. I feel like the previous comment "97%" of scientists agree is similar to the claim Crest made that it was dentist's most recommended brand.  It's great for advertising but is it really the truth?  You see, for Crest, they surveyed only a select amount of dentists in a small area (namely the northeastern United States, and used that as their facts.  Carbon Dioxide is a natural exhalation by every aerobic animal out there, and it is the most necessary atmospheric gas required by plants.  IF global warming were homogenic, then how has this natural cycle occurred in the past and how does it differ?  IF global warming were real, then who are we to say that it's bad?  Because it affects overpopulated liberal coastal cities that by their very nature emit more CO2 than other areas?  It is true that the number of plants and animals actually increases at warmer temperatures.  Who are we to play God and say "the time before the industrial revolution was the absolute perfect time and temperatures shall never rise nor fall."  If you say anthropogenic Global Warming is real without thinking logically about it, and if you say since it's anthropogenic it must be bad, aren't you really just a watered-down Westboro Baptist Church member?  When has science said "without a doubt xxx exists?"  Never.  Science only disproves, not proves.  If scientists stop questioning, then maybe they should just come out and say it.  This "science" behind global warming is a farce, particularly when papers come out (or try to) disagreeing with the majority and they are shunned by big evil climate change "scientists."

So why does CO2 hold more heat? Well just like anything else, molecules can soak up heat, and CO2 (Carbon Dioxide) can absorb a lot of heat, which is released and re-radiated in all directions, rather than being reflected by the Earths surface out to space. This is very simplified but this is what is going on.

Earth has a natural greenhouse effect which keeps our temperatures in a nice comfortable zone. However when you pump in more Greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane (comes from animals along with CO2) then the heat capacity of the atmosphere increases, so it can hold on to more heat than it could before, and this is what is the problem of Climate Change. The sources of these greenhouse gases are humans, human activities (cars, factories, power plants etc) as well as the increase in beef production across the planet (specifically developing nations whose people are turning more to beef for food). This increases methane production globally, and again we end up with more greenhouse gases.

Doing something about it is difficult, and many countries don't want to because it's hard to do, and most solutions require either a new tax, or some form of price to be placed on Carbon, and no one wants prices to rise, so it's unpopular for governments. However some governments take the matter seriously and are proactive, such as Germany.

So what can you do? Driver a smaller car, go hybrid, or drive less. Turn off lights that aren't being used, turn down the heat a bit, and many other things.

As for recycling, recycling does have an impact on climate change, because all those goods that can be recycled, don't need to have energy injected into production of those items, they can just be transformed, so it's much cheaper to make.

I hope that clears up some of the confusion. Just a note, this is all very simplified, so don't go on at me that I missed this or that.

Arguments against climate change seem to come down into four categories.

1. It's natural anyway and ice ages have already happened/ we are a small contribution
We have been a large contribution in the last 100 years, much larger than any other source. Whether it is through transportation or the meat industry, we are increasing the rate of climate change exponentially. This is an indisputable fact. Delaying this would bring us many more years without global floods, destroyed cities etc. Simply because there are other sources or it has happened before does nothing to suggest we are not the current major cause.

2. Scientists are in a conspiracy
If scientists fake a result once, and are found out, they will be rejected from the scientific community. With this in mind, they have to do non partial, non biased studies. It is much harder to fake a trend in data points then it is to fake a statement, such as what politicians do.

3. Misunderstanding the meaning of scientific consensus. 
Scientific consensus is when lots of pier reviewed, non partial studies point to the same result, NOT when a few scientists think something so it must be right.

4. Literally misunderstanding studies
Any objection to these generally comes from simply not looking at all the studies which prove those three points.

It's undeniable that humans are causing more global warming, it's also undeniable that we have strong natural changes as well, the earth goes through fairly regular ice ages completely independently of human interaction.

What really matters is the degree to which humans contribute to the natural cycles, this is where the evidence is less established. @***** Sorry for wall of text, but I assure you this is nothing but a level-headed reply: The Heat Island effect argument you mention has been thoroughly debunked. We have a fleet of 20+ climate-specific satellites circling the globe, which can infer the temperature of the air at various levels, and the surface, and the ocean, from space, 24/7/365, around the world. The technology is similar to those laser temperature gauges you can buy for $20 at your local hardware store, though on a highly sophisticated level. We have a constant stream of global data about air and land and water temperature, air pressure, cloud cover, wildfires, volcanoes, wind and ocean currents, glacier size and thickness, ice mass and ocean ice cover. The data being collected is immense, and it is not flawed. We have a very accurate picture of what is going on-- that's not up for debate, and no well-intentioned scientifically-minded climate skeptic mentions those issues anymore. To further address the heat island effect, if you filter out urban stations and use only isolated rural weather stations, the temperature trends remain unchanged. Also interesting to note that the areas of the globe that have experienced the most warming (according to weather stations) are in Alaska, Greenland, and Russia, where there is essentially no urbanization-- meaning the claim that "warming is an illusion caused by urban data" doesn't make sense. A note on this topic about taxes: The climate change discussion has nothing to do with taxes.... You can't argue that AGW isn't real because if it is, we might have another tax to deal with. There is a two step process here: 1) Decide whether AGW is real 2) Decide what to do about it. It seems you might be conflating the two issues, which you have to watch out for. You are very welcome to argue about the merits of the different approaches for #2 (eg voluntary compliance vs carbon tax), but that is independent of #1. The statement "AGW can't be real, because if it is those damn governments will charge another tax!" is not a valid line of reasoning. Regarding "the perfect temperature": The issue is not the final temperature itself, but the rate of change. Plants and species and humans can easily adapt to a 2C change over a 10,000 year period, similar to the historical cases that you mention: past ice ages and the like. That is not a problem at all. Crank up the temperature of the Earth 5C-- who cares, as long as it happens very slowly. The problem is 2C in 100 years. There will be not enough time for ecosystems to adapt, nor for us humans to be able to rebuild on higher ground when the ocean levels rise, or move out of landslide areas due to increased rainfall, or migrate away from areas that turn into waterless deserts due to extended droughts similar to the type we're now seeing in California (but decades long instead of years long). The economic impact, social impact, and GDP hit of those upheavals and mass migrations and associated infrastructure rebuilding will far surpass any fractional cost added by a carbon tax. We are already seeing insurance companies (whose job it is to forsee such things, because they have 'skin in the game') ramping up to pre-empt these changes (and siding with the climate scientists almost without exception). Never in the past 3 billion years of the Earth, other than during cataclysms like a global winter caused by a supervolcano or asteroid impact, has the rate of heating we're currently experiencing ever happened, according to our best knowledge. It's unprecedented. The "it's happened before" argument fails to understand that RATE of change is the key factor and threat, not the overall change. It's also true that the models are not precise. That is because they are probabilistic, and probabilistic models are inaccurate on short time scales and do poorly in predicting individual events. Think of it this way -- I randomly select 20 cards from a pack of cards, and draw one at random. Will a computer be able to predict which suit of card you pick? Of course not. Will it be able to predict a pattern within a few different draws? Of course not. The best you can do is say there's a 1/4 chance of each suit coming up, each time. But, if you look at the past results, you'll be able to tune your model to understand the situation -- that only certain cards are present, so you can figure out the odds of each suit coming up more accurately. You still can't predict the outcome of a single draw, but over thousands or millions of observations, the model will be able to predict extremely accurately the overall pattern-- that each suit will appear in proportion to how many cards of those suit are in the subset of cards.  Climate is similar, in that you can create models that are accurate on broad scales, but do terribly at predicting individual events (eg "How many hurricanes will there be this September"). Climate is much more complex of course, but you end up with probability ranges and confidence intervals that are still very much useful. For example, in the first 1990 IPCC report, their models predicted a warming of 0.2C per decade. What did it end up being? 0.15C per decade. Not great, but not far off. For the second 1995 IPCC report, they predicted 0.14C/decade. For the 2001 IPCC report, they estimated 0.16C/decade.  It's not 100% accurate, but they are well within the confidence intervals of the predictions. Each successive report has tightened the constraints of the predictions as climate scientists have tried very hard to reduce the uncertainties in those predictions. Ironically, because of the probabilistic nature, your statement about us not understanding global effects while understanding local effects well is backwards. Weather prediction is hard: you require knowing about every single air current and layer and its temperature and humidity and pressure and wind direction to make an accurate prediction. For the whole of the Earth, things average out, making predictions and understanding it far easier. Big picture is easy; small scale is hard. Somewhat counterintuitive, but it makes sense once you understand how statistics and science and the climate works. People like me think this issue is important not because we want to feel good about doing something good, and it has f-- all to do with riding bikes. We think its important because every shred of evidence collected so far, and every scientist who is involved in the field and peripheral fields, insist on the same conclusion: that we are setting ourselves up for an economic and social situation that will be almost impossible to recover from for our children and grandchildren, and the longer we put off action, the more difficult it will be for them. If you want to accuse us of some selfish or self-serving intent, it is probably because we want to be on the right side of history, the side that saw this coming and wanted to do something about it.

The problem with climate change communication is a global "ecology" communication problem. We (like greenpeace and others) tend to present to people that ecology is about "saving baby seals in antarctica" or about "saving beautiful landscapes" like the amazon rainforest or niagara falls or whatever. Like ecology would be something that does not concern human beings or that it is just a little "extra": "if you want to keep seeing cute animals or landscapes, yeah be ecologist!". But it is just not that at all ! It diverts the attention from the real subject. Instead we need to communicate about the fact that ecology is an anthropocentric problem ! We need to clearly say that it is about saving human beings, you ! We need to say that climate change is about ourselves loosing our house, starving or missing water somehow somewhere in the future. We need to stop showing baby seals in communication campaigns ! This is really not about it ! Go hunt polar bears if you want, why would we care? We need to take ecology from an economy, pragmatic point of view and stop talking with our heart / feelings, because this is a real rational problem. Then maybe people will start understand it.

Problem: Correlation doesn't prove cause.
Problem: There is a correlation between global warming and fossil fuel emissions since about 1950.
Question: Is it natural or caused by humans? If the latter, is the correlation the cause, or may we see a backlash from the Industrial Revolution. 
Possible conclusion: If global warming is caused by human and we see a backlash from the Industrial Revolution, then we are already doomed.
Question: Can we sell it?
Answer: No. The lack of data shows no correlation, so nobody would believe it.
Possible conclusion: Global warming is a natural phenomenon.
Question: Can we sell it?
Answer: No. Although there is data to support cycles of global warming and global cooling, there is no correlation to show. Anyway, most people would find increased temperature because of natural causes a positive happening.
Possible conclusion: Global warming is caused by human activity in direct correlation to the effect.
Question: Can we sell it?
Answer: YES! We can scare the crap out of people, at least for a while. But when they get comfortable with the scare, we can increase the temperature and everything that follows it to increase the level of fright. We can definitely sell this. Most people accept correlation as proof of cause.

Problem: Scientist know correlation doesn't prove cause.

Is global warming caused by human activity? I have no idea. The data doesn't show anything but a correlation. But I find it suspicious that the correlation follows the process of global warming so perfectly, as if the data was fabricated.

Should we do anything about it? Of course! Whatever the cause, we should reduce our footprint on the world.

Will it help? Most likely not. But doing nothing won't help either. If global warming isn't caused by humans now, it may accelerate global warming in the future.
