usually in the discussions i've seen, the question about manmade climate change is related to pascals wager, where instead of saving ourselves from a vengeful god we save ourselves from irreparable environmental damage. The reluctance to act accordingly comes from the cost involved, in the case of climate change it doesn't stop at cost in time and freedom of choice, but actual monetary loss, or, if money is the limiting factor already, a reduction in quality of life due to special taxes on co2 emissions.
an actual solution - as far as i can tell - would be the dual-fluid-reactor.org/ as its currently developed by the german institute of solid state nuclear research in berlin.
but this invokes the problem derek mentioned in the video, that we tend to focus on visible, isolated incidents (tschernobyl, fukushima) and underestimate gradual change.
the way i see it is, over the course of its lifetime, the accumulated co2 emissions of a regular coal/gas/oil power plant make it pretty much an environmental disaster, a hydro power plant is localized but very obvious impact.
this alone doesnt make nuclear power more attractive, but it should help with the realization, that our course for the future doesnt have to be perfect, less damaging than what we do right now would be a good start, which is a much easier goal.
and it also helps to know, that "nuclear power plant" obviously only refers to the kind of energy source, not the actual implementation, which in this case can vary widely.
to put it bluntly, most nuclear reactors today use cold-war-era technology and are rather factories for weapons grad nuclear material with electricity as a byproduct, which bringt with it most of the dangers, foremost the possibility of a meltdown (runaway chain reaction).
im still reading up on the details, especially the capabilities of the PPU and if it's one device capable of taking a variety of inputs, or a name for a group of devices with specialized implementations.
but from what i can tell, it seems very promising, and at least deserves a lot more publicity.

Doesn't recycling helps to limit the CO2 emissions ? Cause that paper or plastic gets recycled instead of being burnt ?
thanks for the replies

It completely depends. Some materials require less energy to recycle than to make new ones, other don't. Paper can be used as bio-fuel, for example, while it is rather expensive to recycle. If the paper comes from a sustainable source, the burning of the paper is offset by the growing of a new tree that binds the carbon.  All in all, the effects of recycling is rather negligible when it comes to CO2 emissions. Energy and transport is what really matters. When we burn oil or coal for energy and transport, that carbon we just put in the air isn't going away for thousands if not millions of years.   Not to say that recycling is unimportant, but it matters for different reasons. We have a finite amount of resources in our planet, and recycling is vital if we want a sustainable society.

It can help, but sometimes it does not. The main reason for recycling is that you don't need as much new resources, don't need as many landfills and in some cases, it's cheaper. The aluminium can is a good example. It's cheaper to melt down old cans to make new ones. The other way is to use bauxite that you, with the Bayer process, turns to aluminium oxide and then melt the aluminium oxide and with the help of electrolysis produce aluminium. If the electricity is clean (say, by hydropower) then you don't emit much greenhouse gases (even if it may be bad for the environment in other ways). "Climate in a narrow sense is usually defined as the "average weather," or more rigorously, as the statistical description in terms of the mean and variability of relevant quantities over a period of time ranging from months to thousands or millions of years. The classical period is 30 years, as defined by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). These quantities are most often surface variables such as temperature, precipitation, and wind. Climate in a wider sense is the state, including a statistical description, of the climate system." WMO 1 If you just look at the atmospheric warming the you miss the whole picture. "The climate system is the highly complex system consisting of five major components: the atmosphere, the hydrosphere, the cryosphere, the land surface and the biosphere, and the interactions between them. The climate system evolves in time under the influence of its own internal dynamics and because of external forcings such as volcanic eruptions, solar variations and human-induced forcings such as the changing composition of the atmosphere and land-use change." 2 Atmospheric warming only is only 2,3% of the climate system. This is because water have a much higher heat capacity then air. More then 800 times depending on a lot of stuff. No, that is hardly a justification for governments. The problem of "not being so good at handling long-term complex problems" applies to politicians as well. Not only that, say that there was a politician with policy A in which the long-term problems were considered, and a politician with policy B where the long-term problems were ignored. So here's my problem with climate change. Yes, I'm a doubter... I also have a BS in physics, an MS in oceanography, and half of a PhD in systems engineering (knock on wood for the timely arrival of the other half)... none of which makes me brilliant, authoritative, or even passably knowledgeable of the relevant facts, but... hear me out.

I'll grant you the basis of your belief. Fine, let's say the science is sound: and it's getting hotter and it's our fault. So... what? Yeah. That's what I said: so what? If you are shocked, this may indicate you suffer from bipolar politics disorder (don't worry, it's common), symptom: blindly assuming that politically charged issues admit of only two mutually exclusive stances. In this case: 1) believe and care, or 2) deny and not care... but - I ask - what about 3) believe and... wonder what's the big deal!

Don't get me wrong, I love polar bears, penguins, and the sight of glaciers as much as the next guy. But everybody knows that we are in an ice age... Right? OK, maybe not everybody. But the point is that it is generally and scientifically agreed that our planet - geologically speaking - is more often than not, hotter than it was today (and it is August). Our planet is bound to get hotter, whether we help it or not.

So, first point. The world isn't coming to an end, it's just getting a little hotter a little sooner. Big deal. Our planet has been there before. Many times. For millions of years at a time. With thriving biodiversity, I'm sure. So, again... What's the big deal?

Are we concerned with the loss of habitat of polar bears and penguins? I'm no ecologist, but how densely populated are the poles? Won't the polar species just migrate north (and south, respectively) as the ice recedes? (And yes, I realize there are many other species involved)

In contrast, if you want to be concerned about loss of natural habitat, take a gander at the Amazon basin. At the biodiversity there. At the biodensity there (I don't know if that's a real word... I mean the amount (kilograms let's say) of living stuff per unit volume) And look at the rate at which THAT is "receding". THAT worries me.

Which leads me to wonder... Wouldn't global warming lead to an expansion of tropical conditions? More breathing room for all those tropical species losing THEIR homes? I don't know. I'm just asking. Because nobody else seems to be.

Sure the deserts will grow too, but last time I saw Planet Earth (the BBC series which my wife gave me for my birthday and which I love to watch) they managed to persuade me that the desert was a vibrant ecosystem... probably about as densely occupied as the arctic and Antarctic... So, break even?

Finally... yeah, flooding. Loss of habitat for... um, yours truly. Sure most of our cities will be affected. We have this thing for beaches and ports. But that doesn't necessarily make it an ecological disaster... just an expensive inconvenience for us. Humans.

But, like cockroaches and lichen, we'll manage. And think about the gain in habitat for marine wildlife! Our troubled dolphins, humpbacks, and dugongs. And all those new artificial coral reefs for colorful fish to move into, where colorful people once lived in.

The Australian Carbon Tax was repealed due to it's overwhelming un-popularity with the Australian people based entirely on the way it was introduced.
The government that introduced the tax, did so straight after winning an election where they insisted in their campaign that they would do no such thing. The people who voted for them felt betrayed and the resulting voter revolt saw that government get hammered in the following election.

As a result of the reckless and self serving actions of that government, the Carbon Tax has gone from a possibility on the horizon so long as the public get behind it, to being politically toxic and unlikely to happen again in Australia for a very long time.

Well yeah, the reason climate is changing (or changing more rapidly than naturally) is that the fossil fuel emissions triumph the amount that can be stored in the present day  rainforests and oceans. If you would take away the damage done to those natural carbon regulators in the past century, wouldn't the planet be able to compensate our emissions today?

Plants also need essential nutrients and water. It is predicted that in general climate change makes already wet regions wetter while dry regions become even more drier. Thus, if there aren't enough nutrients and right amount of water, the plant productivity really doesn't increase. Cutting down the rainforests is a part of the problem as they act as carbon sinks. In the order of magnitude though the emissions from fossil fuels still triumph.

Great video. Really hit the nail on the head. The story of climate change is boring, because as a whole humanity doesn't see the full effects and consequences. A big problem though with that mentality is, once we do get to a point where we see major consequences, it'll be far too late. We're already seeing some effects already, melting glaciers, record extreme weather events on a more frequent basis, etc.

The other problem is definitely greed. The biggest, richest, heaviest polluting companies that have the most at risk just simply have not figured out how to make a profit going completely green, there's nothing in it for them, at the very least they can't make the same amount of money trying to be even slightly greener (Can you imagine BP having nothing but wind and solar farms instead of being an oil company?).

Thus, with these huge companies with a lot of investment in fossil fuels have our governments in their back pockets fighting for them to help them turn a profit.

At some point though, as weather events become more and more extreme over the years, it'll cost us more and more money to recover (look at hurricane Sandy and how it affected the major east coast cities. Those subway systems were never designed to handle that flooding, and it probably cost the city tens of millions just for that problem alone). There will be a point sometime in the future where it'll cost our country far, far to much to fix our shorelines, to move their cities further inland to habitable lands, to fight the droughts in our farmlands, to be shut down for probably months on end when near ice-age-level snows hit and bring our major cities and transportation industry to a standstill, among other things, than it would be worth it for governments to stick up for big businesses. By then though, again it'll be too late.

That is the narrative that should be spun about climate change. Not the "oh it'll be the end of the earth!" (which it won't be, the Earth can survive much more than that... It'll be the end of LIFE on Earth, especially human life, big difference). Not "your children and children's children will suffer because of it". It should be "Your governments will go broke trying to fix all these more frequent and harder hitting weather events around the world."

Money makes things happen in this world folks, as does the threat of losing that money. If we start all thinking of the financial costs of climate change, maybe that might spark our interests in actually DOING something about it.

The hole in the Ozone layer is natural. It is due to the lack of UV rays hitting the northern and southern hemispheres. It's been like that for millions (or billions?) of years until we came along and decided to measure it, then we noticed a hole in the formation process. The "hole" gets bigger and smaller based upon stratospheric weather patterns forcing higher concentrations of Ozone into the northern/southern hemispheres. Also, the word "hole" is a misnomer; It's just a lower concentration of Ozone, not a hole or gap.

With regard to Australia they were actually different governments, due to the fact we are a parliamentary system.

The previous Government brought in the greenhouse gas tax, and the then conservative Opposition used it as a leverage issue to get elected by spreading fear of the economic consequences.  And it has been proven that the typical conservative voter responds well to fear.  Again, as with the case of climate deniers,usually by making stuff up, and outspending the truth tellers.  Tell a Big Lie often enough and people will think it is true.  While they were also supported heavily (and indebted to) industries with a vested interest in not having this tax, such as the coal mining industry - which ran candidates in every election as the Climate Skeptics party which funneled votes to the major conservative party (the Liberal National Party), it was actually the fact that the Government of the time was a coalition between the Greens and Labor that meant that the LNP was going to be deathly opposed to this planned tax.  The Greens, being both originally a radically environmentally focused party and having evolved into the social justice party (mainly due to their being an incredible vacuum in Australian politics in this regard at the moment), have been a strong target of the neoconservative press for ideological reasons.

[The incredible disorganisation of the main opposition party (Labor) due to internal conflicts - plus the probably correct opinion within the now fiscally-conservative Labor party that the rise of the Greens means a corresponding loss of votes for them - meant that the previous Government was hamstrung on responding to this issue.  Meanwhile, once elected the LNP Government has since proven to have broken a large number of their election promises (yet again - their previous incarnation invented the idea of "core" and "non-core" promises in an election), and would resoundingly lose to a person off the street if an election was called today.  It's a political mess down here, with them (attempting) to take an axe to any program that doesn't fit their Christian neoconservative policies or threatens the vested interests they are obliged to support.]

Here is my unsolicited take. The unprecedented part of 400ppm of CO2 levels is based on ice cores rings from Antarctica. Which is stated to have 80,000 year record. Here is the catch, that claim is based on the notion that once ice forms down there it never ever melts or evaporates. We agree ice can evaporate right? Anyhow, more to my point, the claim of Armageddon is that the polar ice caps will melt. There are two periods where temperatures exceeded current levels and we have reasonable proof that at least the coastline of Antarctica was exposed. That proof is in the map drawn by piri Reis in 1513 ad, in which he states he used other sources to compile this map. Best guess for this time period for the coast line to have been exposed is 1400 - 600 bc. Am I saying the climate is not changing, no, that would be ridiculous. Climate is always changing. My point is, the record stating 400 ppm is unprecedented is based on an incomplete record which is the remnants of unmelted ice that survived two global periods temperature which were much greater than today.

@Somerandomdude4.2526 We are nowhere near running out of landfill space. That is just a myth started by the EPA in the early 90's that still manages to linger to this day.
@Ike Evans but recycling paper saves space from landfills

@gurkfisk89 As a general rule, this is not the case. Take paper for example. A good chunk of paper comes from wood farms where land is set aside intentionally for the purpose of timber production. Carbon from the atmosphere is taken by the trees and stored in the wood. We take this wood and make it into paper. When we throw it into the landfill, it is covered where it will store that same carbon for thousands of years. By recycling, we inhibit the growth of new timber production, which in turn slows carbon sequestration. As it sits, it is not profitable to recycle paper. But then again, it isn't really beneficial to the environment either. In other words, what works within the free markets is surprisingly also often the most environmentally effective means of taking care of the planet.

@Ike Evans I agree that it can be a good rule of thumb. But it measures profit rather than environmental damage. It can still be good for the environment even if the government take the costs instead of companies.

@iamihop There is a good rule of thumb when it comes to recycling. If governmental agencies have to subsidize the effort, then it is usually a bad idea. If recycling would occur even without help from the government (like it does with steel and aluminum) then it is good idea.

@iamihop Aluminium can go  both ways mostly depending on how you produce electricity. With coal powered electricity it's a no brainer, recycling does a lot. If the energy comes from hydropower, the effect on global warming isn't that huge. And the greenhouse gases from all the trucks that collects used cans also plays a role. I'm going to post a comment now, you may reply if you want, I won't try to stop you, and frankly I won't care too much, here it goes:
We can agree that the average mean temperature of the planet is increasing, there are signs to point it out, and theories to describe it. One such was of seeing it is to look at sea levels. Over the past 100 years, sea levels have gradually increased, and will continue to increase. Another way to see it is to look at the change in the size of glacial bodies and the ice coverage of the polar ice caps, both are declining in size.
What we cannot agree on is the extent at which humans are playing a role in this. Certainly, we are playing some role, whether that role be the impacted, or the one impacting, it is still a role.
Technology is reaching a point where we are finally able to fully monitor weather, track changes, and predict future weather events and climate patterns. What we are seeing, and what we can see from information gathered from the past, is that there has been a general increase in temperature, an increase which correlates with an increase in CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere.
Does this mean we are causing it? Not necessarily. Does it mean we should be acting as though we are causing it? Certainly. Why? Because, if we are not the ones causing this climate change, and are merely being driven by factors out of our control, should you look into the past, and investigate the effects climate change has on life in the past, our only hope is to be in control of it, else we face a mass extinction equivalent to the Permian mass extinction.
Not only this, but if we are the factor driving the change in climate, it means we have discovered a means of, well, controlling the climate of a planet. We would have the ability to cool planets, to warm them, to shape them in whatever way we deem pertinent. That, would be truly remarkable.
The argument now should not be "Is it 90% humans? Is it 10% humans? Is it 40%, 30% 60%?", no, the argument should be "How are we going to try and fix this?", because our only hope, is that we are the ones driving this change, else we will simply be another mark in the history of the planet, another fossil to dig out of the ground, another species impacted by the power of nature.

@Realthx We cannot KNOW. We can have strong theories and evidence to substantiate that claim, but until we have done this multiple times, we cannot definitively say it is because of it. @saul peña wright On Earth (not Venus), CO2 that's emitted by nature is balanced by natural absorption (ocean and plants), so it will remain at a steady state without outside influence. Humans force CO2 levels to be higher by emitting CO2 but never absorbing it. In fact, humans emit 26 billion tons of CO2 per year, and about half of that is absorbed by natural CO2 sinks (ocean and vegetation), and the other half (15 billion tons) ends up in the atmosphere. So natural absorption takes care of a lot of it but it can only absorb a fixed amount, and we don't want to find out what that limit is.

The climate has shifted from cold to warm in the past, but that happened over tens of thousands of years.  This is happening much faster. Look, the science is not controversial: CO2 traps infrared energy.  You can demonstrate this in a lab with a soda bottle. Trapped energy makes the earth warmer.  Obviously, right? CO2 in the atmosphere over the last 400,000 years varied between about 180 ppm to 280 ppm, in a cycle that took tens of thousands of years.  We know this, because we can sample air bubbles that formed in Antarctic ice, going back hundreds of thousands of years.   Now in the last few decades, atmospheric CO2 has risen faster than it ever has, to levels it has not reached in at least hundreds of thousands of years.   This rise just happens to have taken place during a period when humans were burning fossil fuels Fossil fuels definitely produce CO2 when burned. Connect the dots.  It's so easy to do.  This is why all the scientists agree about it.

There are so many factors that go into climate change - many more than extra carbon dioxide. We don't know exactly how much our emissions affect climate change. It's important to know that most of the greenhouse gasses in our atmosphere (about 95 percent) is water vapor, and Co2 makes up about three percent. There are other factors which contribute to temperature changes like the sun, the oceans, the earth's magnetic field, and probably more that we don't understand yet. What we do know is that every living thing on earth would be dead without Co2. No plant life would be able to survive without it. Co2 is not a toxic pollutant. It's the reason for life. Currently, scientists are saying "global warming is on hiatus." Why? We haven't stopped burning fuel and coal. It doesn't make sense to simply blame the entirety of what we see as climate change on a very slight rise in Co2. There is much more happening in, on, and around our planet than the presence of a little more carbon dioxide. The problem lies with people who completely blame Co2 and then close their minds to other possibilities.

It's boring because more and more proof is surfacing that anthropogenic global warming isn't actually happening.  We have actually seen cooler temperatures over the last couple years than the models once predicted, so now those that have really bought into this theory are now making new claims that this is an off cycle. http://wattsupwiththat.com/2014/06/04/the-pause-continues-still-no-global-warming-for-17-years-9-months/ (BTW, this source IS NOT PAID BY BIG ENERGY)

I'm really disappointed that a channel like this, that I enjoy for the science aspects, would swing political like this (but not surprised since he listed Obama's book as one of his favorites).  His point about the alternative viewpoints being funded solely by energy companies simply is not true.  That is a political spin that the global warming proponents like to cite.  Also, the claim that the "consensus" of scientists support anthropogenic global warming is also false.  That's why it is disappointing that Derek actually has bought into these myths.  There are plenty of peer-reviewed published papers contradicting man-made global warming despite his assertions to the contrary: http://www.populartechnology.net/2009/10/peer-reviewed-papers-supporting.html

Also, it's slightly disingenuous to criticize website funding of the opposite viewpoint when at the end of this video he claims that this very video was "sponsored by the Climate Reality Project" which is a non-profit group advocating for climate change awareness and created by Al Gore.  No offense, but that is the very definition of hypocrisy.

The main point that is at fault with the carbon emission tax is that just like recycling, it will not do anything to stop global warming, if it were true.  The reason being is that simple economics teaches us that taxing negative externalities (pigovian tax) doesn't necessarily stop consumption or use but is just a way for the government to collect more tax revenue.  For instance, gasoline tax is already the highest it has ever been and oil prices are still very high, yet consumption is still at an all time high.  Adding a new tax to carbon emissions will only drive up energy costs and actually costs for just about everything you consume from food to keeping your house cool in summer.  You think electricity rates are high now?  Wait until these pseudo-environmentalists start adding costs.  The point is that consumption will remain the same despite a new tax, therefore it is not a viable solution to the problem...even if the problem existed.

I know it's an extremely unpopular move to criticize a popular Youtube channel, especially when I've been a subscriber myself for several years now, but I can't just sit by and let someone's political bias white wash the very true opposition to this relatively new and very unproven theory of climate change.  Man-made global warming is pushed by the Democrat Party as a new form of taxation.  If Al Gore really believed in it, he would be a model example of what he preaches; instead he has been notorious for leaving one of the biggest carbon blueprints of them all.  

I'm still a subscriber and am sure to receive tons of hate for this message, but I don't care.

If climate change is real, then why has the Earth's temperature been steady since 1979, and decreasing since 1998?  Why are most of the record-high temperatures recorded before the 1970's?  Why have the vast majority of the computer models massively overestimated how high the temperatures would be by now?  Why were Australian scientists recently caught red-handed manipulating temperature data?  Why was the "hockey stick" claim foisted upon us only to be shown to be a math trick?  Why are governments desperate to show global warming and financing scientists who publish papers related to this, when they have an obvious conflict of interest because of their goal of taxing carbon?  If climate change is real, and the earth really is heating up, then why must we assume that's necessarily a bad thing?  Haven't biologists shown that warmer temperatures resulted in greater species diversity while colder temperatures are bad for life?  Aren't warmer temperatures also better for crop yields?

If climate change is NOT real, then why isn't all the extra CO2 in the atmosphere causing temperatures to rise, since we know that CO2 traps infrared energy that would otherwise go out into space?  That would be quite a puzzle.

It's irritating to think that one of the companies that is preventing climate change reform probably has the money to take a huge leap forward in something like solar, to simply convert a massive swath of their energy production to clean. +Alex Meyer I think that's a valid argument for light bulbs, but climate change isn't quite the same. Consumers can see the affect more efficient light bulbs have on their electric bill, but the only way consumers can really see benefits of using clean energy is from scientists telling them so. That's why it's harder to motivate many companies to work on renewable energy innovation. Not only are consumers less motivated to support them, but they too have to trust the scientists on the benefits. That's why we need government subsidies or another form of persuasion. And in your light bulb example, it might've been that the relative success encouraged other companies to make their own products, even if the original, government subsidized company wasn't too successful. The same effect could influence a renewable energy industry. With the Solyndra problem, it doesn't mean government sanctions are bad, it's just how the sanctions are implemented. If the government hands $500 million to a company, and just says they should use it on solar, and the CEO runs away with it, that means we just shouldn't give away money without safeguards, not that we should get rid of sanctions altogether. Also, the companies I'm talking about are the big oil, gas and coal companies. The companies working just for renewables are good, but to really change the energy picture we have to motivate the other companies, because if they're making 100 million today, they're not going to give that up for a good cause, even if they only lose 5 million. So, the only way I see to feasibly convert today's economy to renewable energy is to somehow make it more profitable than oil or gas or coal. Although I don't think our economy now can handle it, the only way I can see to do this is through government tax breaks and/or sanctions, or possibly some sort of consumer motivation, which in turn would motivate companies. So it's possible sanctions aren't the way to go, and we just have approach the problem through consumers. The thing is, to catch companies, consumers have to initially be willing to pay more, which is asking a lot for most of the population to do... It's just so hard to make anyone see the future, either money-oriented companies or money-oriented people. Again, the only way I can see is for the forward-looking people (the government) to give money to the money-oriented people (the corporations.) Of course it's a long process; I don't think we could convert dirty energy companies, but we could hopefully supersede them with sanctioned clean-energy corporations in ten years...

I think to say that solutions are obvious and that we're not taking action is an over simplistic summary of the situation. For starters: to have a solution you first need to know what the problem is... so, what's the problem? Is the problem the concentration of GHGs in the atm? Perhaps the concentrations themselves are not the problem but some of the consequences derived from this: increasing climactic variability, rising sea level, loss of human life from more extreme weather, biodiversity loss from ecosystem changes, etc. If the problem is the concentration themselves then the solutions aren't "obvious" since any solution [even the most extremely successful ones: no more meat production, no more driving!] would not have a noticeable effect for decades and in the meantime we're left with all these other issues associated with climate change to deal with. If, on the other hand, the ACTUAL problem is not the GHGs concentrations but all the consequences then the solutions are ALSO not obvious since science can't tell what is good/bad, right/wrong in these situations. Finding a solution is about risk management and that is not a scientific solution, it's a social one. That's extremely unfortunate because 1) it's makes it SO FREAKING difficult for people to agree, 2) it makes humans responsible for doing things like valuing the life of plants, animals, etc. to try to figure out how much risk is too much risk.  

I agree that just because it's a complicated situation we're not excused from inaction or ambivalence (Australia: no backsies!) but I do believe that if you're going to do an informational video then at least you should make sure that the information communicated is right: you got the science part down pat, not so much the political side of things.

The following comment is completely honest and not sarcastic, sardonic, or otherwise insincere.

With respect, from my perspective the reason climate change proponents have done a bad job convincing me personally is that they tend to be very condescending or otherwise impatient when the subject is brought up. There may be any number of reasons for this, it doesn't make them bad people, it just doesn't make them very convincing. I grew up in a "climate change skeptic" household, so I got exposed to that side of the story from an early age, including a good deal of propaganda, both obvious and subtle. As I got older, I began to warm up (harr harr) to the idea that there were two sides to this story and that I might be wrong. However, despite looking for answers and being entirely willing to be convinced, I haven't yet.

I am not a climatologist, and this means I can't use my own expertise in the are to come to a conclusion about the subject, but I should be able to use expertise in my own field as a "subject matter depth gauge" to help me avoid Dunning-Kruger, and maintain patience and respect for those who are SMEs in relevant fields. They are, after all, the ones who have something to teach me.

Even so, in searching I've heard and seen very little but "there's a scientific consensus", "anything that contradicts it is made up by big oil, etc", and similar statements that seek to shut down my investigation, instead of giving me real answers or directing me to sources that could help tip the scale. Now, there may be very good reasons for this, chief among them that climate change proponents may be just dog tired of answering the same questions over and over.

We have your video, where you provide little explanation, frame people on the street as ignorant (they may be, but doing so comes very close to mockery), and then express frustration that there's contention about the subject. That's fine, especially if you've explained yourself breathless, but whom will it convince? For me, I find it difficult to play ball with this, and much as I may want to, I can't change my mind based on it.

This isn't to say I've never seen any convincing evidence that climate change is real, this video in particular is probably the single strongest piece of evidence I've seen either way: Dan Britt - Orbits and Ice Ages: The History of Climate However, it alone isn't enough to convince me (though it's a very good start).

So that's my advice, I guess. If you want to convince those who are willing to listen, you have to come to their table and meet them on their terms. If you claim there's a consensus, demonstrate it and be ready to counter any concerns they might have (e.g., the claim that the "consensus" is made up a large number of non-SME's with irrelevant doctorates, such as MDs. Strange as it may be, and wrong as this claim may be, I've never seen it satisfactorily addressed by the other side).

Maybe I've been talking to the wrong people or looking in the wrong places. Maybe the evidence is everywhere and I am just a bizarre exception who hasn't been exposed to it. Great! I'd love to have my mind changed.

This may make me seem like one of your uninformed interviewees, but remind me why, with our data set that only goes back a couple hundred years, we're so certain, to the point of seeming frantic about it, that this is really happening, and because of our carbon emissions and not the other possibly legitimate reasons. I feel like the climate is such an overwhelmingly complex system, that caution in ascribing causes and effects is the better part of valor at this point. Don't get me wrong, I'm no fan of fossil fuels, or internal combustion engines; I'm really looking forward to - and it seems to be hustling right along - when solar panels get cheap enough that distributed rooftop solar puts electric monopolies out of business. However, the great confidence some have in the veracity of this narrative appears unseemly - especially for scientists - given the amount of knowledge we have about the climate. And if we do have really good reason for believing our carbon emissions are causing global warming, why is that a threat to the planet? Is the argument that Earth will become like Venus with it's runaway greenhouse problem? Or is it just that things will change? Because if that's the worry, it seems pretty minor to me. The earth will continue on, and so will life, and so, almost certainly, will our civilization. Isn't it true that before we had a nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere, there was a carbon dioxide-water vapor atmosphere, and it was the waste products of newly formed life that produced the oxygen in the atmosphere now? Doesn't this mean that all the things that life might do to it's environment, including us pumping trillions of tons of carbon into the atmosphere, are, by definition, "natural"?

Jeff, systems are usually very good at keeping a balance once established. So I doubt that a small increase in CO2 emissions by people would throw out the balance. The natural processes of fixing carbon would likely increase to compensate. However, if you drastically increase man-made emissions, which is what it actually sounds like, the level of compensation would not compensate to the same degree. You actually even named the principle in chemistry that gives me that impression. Le Chatelier's principle says that when a change occurs to a system in equilibrium, the systems changes to counteract the original change. It's only when you really push the system, rather than nudging it, that it really falls apart.
No. It's estimated that humans generate a few hundred times more CO2 than all the volcanos of the world put together. Source: http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/earthtalks-volcanoes-or-humans/

yes, but they don't do that every year. they do that extremely rarely. if you stretched volcanic activity across many years, by averaging them out, you would eventually find that they contribute no more than 300 million tons of CO2 gas every year. Humans, from energy production, deforesting, and a hundred other fossil fuel using things, produce 29 billion tons of CO2 per year. This doesn't even talk about methane, which is a much stronger contributor to global warming than CO2 is

@Jeff MacLeod However, humans emit far more than what volcanoes emit. Most CO2 is emitted by the oceans. CO2 emittance and absorption changes with latitude and the temperature of ocean water and currents and the amount emitted/absorbed is based on Le Chatelier's Principle and Henry's Law.

@jake rheingold This is false. The amount human emit is equal to roughly 10% of natural emissions. However, the atmosphere is increasing at a rate less than half of what humans emit. What this means is that humans are responsible for 100% of the atmospheric increase in CO2. If humans were not emitting CO2 the level would be falling and the planet would be in a century-scale cooling trend due to changing Milankovitch cycles.

"Change the story"? Not likely. "1.5-2-7 deg C" (notice no time parameter (how many years it will take) or CO2 concentration required to give to qualify his comment. (CO2 of 570 ppm will cause Temp rise of 1.2 Deg C without any forcing. Expect that in 70-80 years. If positive forcing (the theory behind the invalidated climate models) then temp will raise more in the next 70-100 years (that's the 1.5-2.7 deg C) but those theories are now disproven by failure to predict past temp changes, and failure to predict the lack of global temp change for the past 17.5 years.
More likely forcing is negative or neutral. If so then increased CO2 will produce more clouds (increasing Earth's albedo-reflecting sunlight back out into space), perhaps more rain, much more rapid plant growth and little other change. That happens to be consistent with the lack of temperature change the past 17-18 years by satellite and weather balloon sampling of the troposphere. Oh yeah, the government researchers who get paid the worse they make "Climate Change" sound will not get paid nearly as much.

Question: what are your thoughts on Bjorn Lomborg's arguments? If you're not familiar, they are, in essence:  
1) Global warming is happening;
2) We are likely too late to reverse global warming by cutting carbon emissions;
3) Instead of focusing on cutting carbon emissions, we should focus on minimizing the negative effects of global warming (e.g. refocus funds toward building levies where rising sea levels will cause harm, etc.)
4) Perhaps moreso, we should focus on greater short term problems.  For example, while global warming may cause an additional estimated 1-2 polar bear deaths per year for the next 100 years, 200-300 will be poached this year, so if you're motivated to stop global warming to save polar bears, you're efforts would be better spent on stopping poachers.
Hope I summarized his ideas well, but if you haven't you should at least watch his TED Talk: http://www.ted.com/talks/bjorn_lomborg_sets_global_priorities?language=en

@Mark C There are things that are known about the Sun and others that aren't. Forecasting what future Solar cycles are going to do hasn't been particularly accurate in the past, so I don't pay too much attention to it, other than as something to keep in mind. In terms of climate effects though, the amount of energy coming from the Sun is directly measurable, and while the surface activity changes (sunspots, etc as you mention), I haven't seen anything to suggest the overall luminosity is changing appreciably. In any case, the surface activity fluctuates over an 11 year cycle, and we clearly don't have a similar climactic cycle that follows it, so the effect of the Solar (magnetic/sunspot) cycle can't be huge. On the other hand, there's evidence that climate does follow some other Solar influences (eg: luminosity, as I mentioned), and these appear to be quite stable over the current few decades.

Alpha Radiation, is the weakest of all yet it is the most dangerous to organs. Because it's distance is on a few inches. Meaning if you have a block that is pure Alpha and it's sitting on your desk, you are getting No Radiation from it in your chair. It's when it get attached to Dust then it becomes a Inhale hazard. This is why you see the guys in Yellow Suits. But remember suits are not really for protection, they are for contaminants. So you don't spread it to other areas. Now Gamma is Natural Radiation while X-Rays are manmade. They are considered the Exact Same Radiation. They also can travel Several Hundred Meters here on Earth, yet forever in Space. And Lastly is Neutron Radiation. This is the Deadliest and it travels the Farthest. It can pass through the Entire Earth. Yet anything with a High Hydrogen Content can weaken it substantially. Think of Shielding more as a Filter than something that completely stops it. And Yes we use Lead Blankets to put on top of Hot-Spots (High Radiation Areas). Which just reduces the area to where you can work in that area for a longer time. OSHA allows you to get an exposure of 5 Rem a Year. While DOE only allows 2 Rem a Year. The Bad part of this, is that it ends on December 31st and starts new again on January 1st. Milky  I spent 4 years installing and upgrading automatic flight controls (including all weather landing systems) for a variety of jet aircraft. I also volunteered to rebuild the TF-33 turbofan engines (20,000 lbs thrust) for one month since there was insufficient staff to cover the number of 5000 hour overhauls.   I worked my own engine with no training at all except to ask the people working at the next hard stand how to do it on each step of the process.  It was easy, if boring, work. 0) Pick the engine up with the overhead crane and put it on a hard stand  1) split the engine at the N1 and N2 compressors, 2) replace the main bearings, remove the UMPA (Oil pump, fuel pump, hydraulic pump,  constant speed drive, and 50 KVA-3 phase alternator)  Inspect the fan buckets for nicks and dings (all OK)  Replace the two igniters on the two bottom can-annular combustion chambers,  removed the thrust reverser and send the hot-end turbines off for magnaflux inspection)  The rest was just re-assembly and then run the engine up to maximum thrust on a test stand and make sure the N1 and N2 RPMs, Fuel Flow, EPR (engine pressure ratio), and EGT(exhaust gas temp) was within specs. You will forgive me if I forgot a detail or two since this was back in the early 1960s. I do understand what I am talking about and the Bernoulli concept of lift is no longer  held in universal fashion, it seems Newtons third law of motion explains lift very well too.   There are still fierce arguments over this   From someone who understands "the basics" are not all that simple nor easily understood:            "Lift is the force that holds an aircraft in the air. How is lift generated? There are many explanations for the generation of lift found in encyclopedias, in basic physics textbooks, and on Web sites. Unfortunately, many of the explanations are misleading and incorrect. Theories on the generation of lift have become a source of great controversy and a topic for heated arguments for many years." You see, the basics are simple but only for the simpletons.  https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/bernnew.html "The real details of how an object generates lift are very complex and do not lend themselves to simplification. " Here is a primer  https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/nseqs.html I want you to take away from this exchange that nothing is as simple as it seems and only deep analysis and experimentation with testing of hypothesis refines a science to a "useful" (but NEVER "correct") process.

+Milky Way Laniakea Superdlusterite  Your prognosis would be troubling if it were true. The fact is that there is no truth to any of it. The fact that AGW predictions have never been correct in the past doesn't appear to trouble you at all.   Making guesses at coin tosses and then claiming that almost half of your guesses were correct doesn't mean you are onto something that converges on a usable predictive model at guessing future individual coin tosses.   Furthermore, any claim that contains words like "might, could, maybe" etc should be tossed in the wastebasket instantly because these qualifiers render any theory described by using such terms totally meaningless: this medicine "might" cure you leaves open the equally possibility that it "might" also kill you or simply "may" be entirely worthless.   The average coin toss of 100 flips might come up 49 heads and 51 tails but this does not mean that a scientific theory that coins at least partially favor tails has any credence. It only means the result lies within the sampling errors bars of 50/50 probability for the sample.   The fact that all 73 models erred on one side tells us there is an invented bias for overstating claims and legitimate science would toss all of them out as useless; this is not forgivable in the real sciences.  The UAH and RSS data sets DO NOT mimic the 100% failed models, they converge on +0.25 C over 37 years and this small amount simply cannot be attributed to any extant AGW theories, whose error bars are often larger than the predictions themselves i.e. totally useless. Legitimate science is not a "weltanshauung," or in the vernacular a "world view" Its is a method of "testing" hypotheses of natural behavior and a hypothesis that fails merely once is not useful; it is "kaput" or worthless. @awdrifter3 Given the assumption that the CO2 is the problem and every ton of CO2 makes the problem  worse, then obviously reducing the amount of CO2 we emit will reduce the problem.  A carbon tax simply collects money from those who wish to import carbon for burning.  If all of the money gained from that tax is then returned to the economy in a productive manner, the countries competitiveness is left largely unchanged.  Every dollar of increased cost due to the tax is offset by a decrease in cost elsewhere.  This makes the removal of the carbon tax purely a political decision taken rather than taking the political decision to apply the money from the tax in a productive manner. Creating a bias in the economy in favor of the desired outcome is the best way to deal with issues like global warming.  It means that all of the businesses have reasons to fund the R&D and adopt the methods that lead to the result we want.  This gets far more minds working on the problem than a typical government research program.

@Milky Way Laniakea Superclusterite How about this way of thinking about it:  The projectile has 1/2 of the energy making it go upwards and 1/2 the energy making it go forwards because it is launched at 45 degrees. The top most point in its flight is where the gravity has brought the upwards component of the motion to a stop.  This height will be the same on the moon as on the earth if the height is very small compared to the distance to the center of the body.  The 1/6 things cancel. Since we already said the launch is at 45 degrees, we know that the shapes of the paths are the same and the heights at the highest points are the same so the range is also the same. If, however, the height is large compared to the size of the body, the height will be greater on the moon.  Thus the idea seems to be able to work for trebuchets a few 1000km tall.

@Ken Smith As per usual, this makes sense *in theory* the problem with this, as it almost always is, is the externalities caused by having a carbon tax. Potential problems with any carbon tax: Production may shift to countries with no or lower carbon taxes. (so called ‘pollution havens’) The cost of administrating the tax may be quite expensive reducing its efficiency. Difficult to know the level of external cost and how much the tax should be. Possibility of tax evasion. Higher taxes may encourage firms to hide carbon emissions. If demand is price inelastic, the tax may have to be very high to reduce demand significantly. In the short term, firms may not feel they have many alternatives. Though other time, demand will become more elastic as more alternatives are generated. Consumers dislike new taxes and often don’t believe that they will be ‘revenue neutral’. This is not an economic argument, but it is a political reality and explains why it is often difficult to implement. A global carbon tax may curtail economic activity in the poor developing world because they can’t afford the small increase in energy costs, but the developed world may simply be able to pay. There may be need for a carbon tax to reflect different abilities to pay. And there certainly are more that people haven't thought of yet.

@Greg Hensley A carbon tax puts carbon based energy at an economic disadvantage.  That is all you really need to do to make the market move away from carbon based energy.  If you then spend some of the money from the carbon tax on alternatives, you increase the effect.  When you hit a tipping point the trend will accelerate because the cost of solar etc will continue to fall.  Thus step one is to put on the tax and step two is to use the money wisely.

Climate change is a huge issue, but making a carbon tax is NOT the best answer by a long shot.  There is already a plan that can be put into action for less money than Al Gore personally spends on AWARENESS alone, that can completely negate our carbon emissions.  One of the biggest problems coming at the problem from the angle that you need to stop carbon emissions, is that it can ruin economies.  The idea is called "Project Garden Hose the the Sky"- No joke.  It has been written about is books like Freakonomics.  It's a REAL solution that is CHEAP and EFFECTIVE.  The thing about regulations like carbon taxes is that it winds up causing some serious economic problems.  Think for one second about those billionaires in the mansions for a minute, and realize that their money wouldn't begin to cover how much it would cost to stop or nearly stop all human CO2 production.      There is also other really big ideas (found in a TED talk I watched recently) about how desertification is making a huge contribution to negative climate change.  It was once thought for quite a long time, in fact, that herd animals would, by the nature of them walking on grasslands, destroy the grass.  So people went out and killed thousands of elephants and the like just to realize the problem was getting even worse.  The desertification of grasslands was speeding up where they were doing this.  The solution was just the opposite of what that original common sense told them.  The herd animals somehow *create and expand* this grassland. The solution was to have the people's farm animals rotate where they would graze frequently (essentially) so now it's possible that the Sahara desert might not even be a desert after some decades (or something like that- go watch the video for yourself! It's truly fascinating!).     I really hope that people start to realize that a carbon tax isn't the best answer, nor the only answer out there.  And that it actually might be quite a bad one.  Keep in mind that most of these laws and ideas like the carbon tax come from politicians that are using the law to get *votes* NOT because it's necessarily a GOOD idea.

There are a few things that recycling properly has a big impact on CO2, namely: Aluminium. @Homer .Hiers It is a very effective greenhouse gas, indeed, but you should also mention that its life as a greenhouse gas in *very short*.  Yes it does play its role in the climate change, but unlike Carbon Dioxide, within a few days water vapor goes back to the ground, see hydrologic cycle.  Carbon Dioxide is another case, it stays in the atmosphere for a rather long time since it is controlled by the cycle of the plants, Carbon Dioxide can stay for *centuries* in our atmosphere.  This is the main reason why Carbon Dioxide is *much more alarming than water vapor*, even if water vapor has a bigger impact on a short time, a week later you can't even feel the impact anymore.  It traps the heat for a week or two, which raise Earth's temperature and afterward it is completely dissipated. Also, more water vapor = more cloud, more clouds = lower temperature since the sun can't properly enter Earth's atmosphere.  Water vapor is more like a double-edged knife, it creates a major problem and a week later it solve the problem itself.  Plus, Earth's atmosphere can only contain a certain amount of water vapor and cannot exceed that percentage, which is not the case with Carbon Dioxide. So even though the towers don't emit CO2, they are still relevant to our climate.

@Veritasium I appreciate your reply. I'll address a few of your rebuttals, and if you have time to respond to mine then great! I'm not sure that I agree with the idea that >95% of working climate scientists think that, and I'm wondering where you've read that? The meteorologists and climatologists I know are people I went to school with or met through geog-career centric networks. I attended a school that was very pro-conventional global warming theory, and the students I attended it with were taught the conventional theories as well - we have all come to be critical of the theories through our own research and contemplation, and are not part of any fringe groups which might suggest we've been conditioned to have these views. I should add that not all of these "climate scientists" share my exact views, but all feel that CO2 is being over-hyped as a cause of climate change. If you know 20 people (who you know personally and feel will give you an honest opinion) in the climate/meteorology field and 19 of them have told you they believe CO2 is responsible, then that's fine - but that's not my experience. I generally find that the majority of people in these fields who support the CO2-culprit theory are employed by organizations who have affiliations or direct interests in the carbon credit trade, or overpriced green energy technologies. An example of which would be a large wind farm which is being produced by Samsung in my local South Western Ontario. Wind is great, but these turbines cost far more than comparable European models, and are subsidized. Furthermore, the idea was promoted based on studies by "climate scientists" who were employed both by Samsung and the provincial government, and with conclusions which were unrealistically optimistic about the potential benefits. Suspicious circumstances in my opinion, and these are typically the types of studies which are cited as being the "common opinion" of "climate scientists". I don't disagree that the fossil fuel companies are paying people to say there's nothing wrong with pollution in the petroleum industry. It's definitely one of the most evil things going in this world, and I fully support your opposition to their agendas. I'm not so sure about the relative funding for non-petroleum funded scientists, because like I said above, most of the rah-rah CO2-culprit studies I see are funded by organizations who are pretty determined to get the theory out there, and I can't honestly say I feel they're any less biased than the oil companies. The funding may well not be on the same order of magnitude, but neither side ever seems to conduct studies addressing all possible variables. Milankovich cycles are responsible for temperature variation, and act as one of the few constants in atmospheric variation, but of course have no direct impact on CO2. It's true that CO2 has generally followed in sync with temperature changes, because various factors in the environment do connect CO2 with temperature, but it's a two way street. I'm not sure where the 90% of temperature rises follow CO2 rises could come from. I know there's a 400,000 year chart that is often referenced where it seems like that in some of the spikes, but there are parts of that chart where CO2 clearly leads temperature changes. More importantly, if I remember correctly the major contradiction with those charts was that there are many occasions where spikes occurred simultaneously, but then temperature dropped back down to normal levels while CO2 remained high - suggesting that CO2 alone wasn't the mechanism for high temperatures, and that spikes were likely the results of a common trigger, rather than primarily on any sort of isolated relationship between CO2 and temperature. As far as the volcanoes go, you're probably right about that. I don't have a lot of time to spare (on top of this essay, haha) but I did read through the link, as well as a few quick searches and I can't really refute that point. It was a few years ago when I read about that, and perhaps it WAS based on the idea that supervolcanic eruptions in the past have rapidly increased atmospheric CO2 levels without a corresponding rise in temperature, and not based on typical annual flows. Although now that I think about it a supervolcano would also block out a lot of energy from the sun, so that could explain a relative drop in temperature - I'm not sure, I'm gonna have to think about that one. Ocean acidification is a whole different problem in my opinion, and definitely needs to be addressed. I'm not so sure about the ocean warming part though - it's been a couple years, but the last study I read (that I felt was unbiased) found that temperature rises tended to be more regional than global, with a significant number of spots having cooled over the same time period. All the same, I'd say we have a lot more to worry about going into the ocean than CO2. In all honesty, it's been a couple years since I did any serious research into this subject, and since then my knowledge has been maintained through casual discussions and any studies I come across. It just often seems like anything I read on the topic is biased and heavily rhetorical (not including your video in particular, I should add). I'm certainly lean towards the idea that we should lessen CO2 emissions, because most bad pollutants accompany CO2, but I get frustrated by either side being so sure of their beliefs, and lambasting the other side as being paid-for. I'd really like the general public opinion to be 'We need to lower all levels of pollution, and we need to move towards clean, renewable energy. We need to make this transition in a reasonable manner, in a reasonable time frame (20 years, in the west?) in a manner which is equitable and fair for all parties involved. We should not make sweeping and sudden changes with drastic economic impacts based on studies where a clear consensus is not found.' And again, I guess it comes down to belief - but I feel like the professionals I personally know represent a reasonable sample of the climate-field's professional population, with no clear interest in promoting one side over the other - especially in private conversations with myself.
Cheers for the info man! my climate change knowledge needs updating. been a while since I've studied it in depth.

@Veritasium I always enjoy your videos, but I have to comment on this one. To give some background on myself, I spent the first two years of university studying meteorology before switching to Urban Planning. I have a strong distrust and dislike for the motives and actions of petroleum companies, as well as other public-private entities that have a vested interest in carbon emitting technologies. That being said, I have to play devils advocate, as I often hear some of the arguments made in this video and find them to be frustrating and faulty. First of all, the only people I ever hear say "most climate scientists agree" are journalists, PR reps, or people citing either of the former. I know a good number of people who are professional meteorologists or climatologists and none of them feel this issue is anywhere near settled. Of course there are many parties involved who are willing to spend millions of dollars to see that CO2 is allowed to keep flowing freely, and I'm opposed to that. What's often lesser talked about is the amount of money that can be made by private corporations (equally as selfish and untrustworthy as the oil companies) off of many of the proposed "solutions" to carbon emissions. Many of the scientific studies done which promote CO2 as being a major contributor to climate change are quite misleading, using time periods which fit the theory, but excluding time periods which do not. I don't blame people for falling into this trap. I did a quick search on google for some of these charts, and it seems like everywhere you look it's the same biased charts. Five years ago it was a lot easier to find broader and less biased data. The two major points are that a) historically atmospheric CO2 increases have FOLLOWED temperature increases, and not the other way around, and b) there have been numerous occasions throughout history where natural phenomenon such as volcanic eruptions have led to massive spikes in CO2 - far larger than anything produced by humans - with little change in global temperatures over even the short-medium term. The Earth has an amazing capacity to correct itself, and as was alluded to in previous posts H2O has a lot to do with it. The relative radiative force of H2O vs CO2 is debatable, 450x seems high, but to say that measuring it's base W/m2 is an accurate proportional account of it's impact on warming would be a bit simplified, as most of the Earth's mechanisms for self-correction are based in variations in H2O, with many layers of compounded affection. You're correct that higher temperatures will mean higher concentrations of H2O, but there is a fairly short reset period for that type of offset. For the record, I'm all for sustainable, pollutant-free living. I don't have any interest in seeing oil companies maintain their empires. What I'm against is the gung-ho attitude that many intelligent people seem to have about "global warming" or "climate change", and the immediate dismissal of dissenters as having the interests of oil corps at heart - because (ironically) I believe that feeling so strongly about CO2 being the primary problem signifies that someone has been brainwashed by a different faction of corporate interests - interests who are certainly not interested in environmentalism or sustainability. The tactics used by these factions are just as flawed and reprehensible. Claims that the poor polar bears will loose their home for example, completely unfounded and the opposite is actually true - polar bear numbers are increasing in Northern Canada. Citing "facts" like the idea that CO2 might be responsible for up to a quarter of the earth's comprehensive warming, or that the ice caps are melting for the first time in recent history is just plain wrong - examples of "facts" which are only "facts" because everyone keeps saying it, not because it's true. I'm not saying climate change isn't occurring, and it IS something we should be concerned about. We should keep pushing for clean energy, and sustainability, but CO2 in my opinion is not the culprit.

"Because of the intense heat, the water vaporizes into superheated high-pressure steam. The steam passes through a turbine (which is similar to a large propeller) connected to a generator. I agree with everything you said apart from "we know clear solutions". Well, it's not that simple, that's the 2nd biggest hurdle (apart from educating the masses that climate change is real, and we as humans are the primary cause). Some solutions (but definitely not all)

- Biofuel: Takes so much space to grow crops and doesn't output much energy in comparison to the need of energy, plus it takes away from space for growing food (even as we still have people starving) and also it doesn't reduce carbon emissions, only produces about equal to what they take in while growing.

- Nuclear fission: Very good output, takes ages to dispose of waste, thousands of years burying waste is not a very good idea. It has dangers of meltdown as has been shown and also is a target for those who wish to misuse them.

- Most 'renewable' measures, like solar, wind, tide, geothermal etc: Don't provide much energy at all, to provide more it would need a lot of room, lot of cost, and to be honest sounds worse than sticking to coal, gas and oil. Many have limitations of availability of energy like hydroelectric, others need specific climates or sun availability, the list of downsides is almost endless.

Nuclear fusion: In my opinion is the best bet, the way forward and where i think i large amount of money needs to be invested, the ITER looks promising but is still in research phase and extremely expensive and hasn't of yet been able to provide more energy than it uses. The project at the NIF is also promising but isn't there yet and needs more research, needs more money and has a lot of cost. Doesn't produce much waste, produces helium and it uses sea water and makes so much energy. (Not accurate figures but if i recall from a documentary 1 gallon of water would make enough energy as 100,000 gallons of oil).

But the best would be a combination with my personal opinion of focussing primarily on fusion. But clearly this is debated and I hope my point has been made, the solution is far from clear. All I have said doesn't take into account of poorer nations, how would they cope with their current problems as well as trying to change to this new cleaner energy etc.

Oh, one other addition I wanted to mention, one other solution is "reducing energy consumption", I agree little reduction to stop 'waste' but overall the effect of stopping the waste of energy would be little. Crashcourse uploaded a video about energy and mentioned "vast reductions of our energy usage would be a step back into the past" which I agree with on the most part. Stopping waste like leaving lights on downstairs while you're asleep, but overall we need ever-growing amounts of energy for everything, reducing overall is not an option. Even less sustainable than sticking to coal, gas and oil.

The question isn't is climate change happening, the question is natural vs man made. Natural processes have changed the Earth's climate dramatically over the last 4.6 billion years. Volcanoes, the energy output of the Sun, the tilt and orbit of the planet relative to the Sun, and the movement of the continents are some of the factors that influence the climate.
Human activities such as burning coal and driving automobiles add greenhouse gases to the ones naturally present in the atmosphere and potentially warm the atmosphere more than normal. Scientists are currently trying to predict the extent of this manmade climate change.

Oxygen levels are decreasing because as we burn fossil fuels for use in energy production and releasing carbon once in the atmosphere that carbon combines with 2 oxygen atoms and produces CO2. However this is nothing to be alarmed about. It is just more proof that increasing CO2 is a consequence of human emissions.
@Jeff MacLeod BUT we should still save energy and recycle because e have limited resources. ALSO oxygen levels are going down, so if we dont burn more stuff, we will not waste oxygen.

@Iori Kira The natural process of the planet is cyclic in that, outside of the Sun getting hotter as it ages, they go in cycles of warming and cooling. currently the majority of natural cyclic patterns are ones of cooling. Milankovitch cycles themselves have been heading toward a cooling for over 6000 years now. That is until the onset of the industrial revolution. If humans never began emitting greenhouse gases into the atmosphere we would still be in that long term cooling trend. The warming from greenhouse gases, however, has swamped that slow and steady cooling. As a consequence, even if we stopped emitting CO2 today, we would still warm for hundreds of years due to the planet attempting to reach equilibrium.
@Iori Kira Actually without human influence the planet would be cooling. The sum of climate forcings is negative before you factor in human effects.
@Craig Sommerville That would be ideal, if not, at least dwindle the numbers down to a sustainable level.

Scientists are currently trying to predict the extent of this manmade climate change. Actually they've been making predictions with 95% confidence intervals for years. The answer is that if everying doubling of CO2  there will be ~1oC of warming and then an extra 1-2oC of warming due to knock on effects (feedbacks). The final 95% confidnece interval is 1.5-4oC with a slim chance that warming could be less than 1oC or more than 6oC. What scientists are trying to determine right now is what effect this will have on various regional climates. Not whether it will happen. The real question is what we should do about it. What economic levels can we pull and what changes we need to make as a society.

Most carbon emissions are the result of generating electricity and burning fossil fuels in vehicles. You can individually help reduce your carbon footprint by using less power in your home (use energy-efficient appliances, don't leave lights on, don't overuse heating and air conditioning), installing a solar power system in your home, using public transportation instead of driving your own car, walking and biking when you need to commute within a short radius. Oh, and eat less meat. Methane is a pretty major greenhouse gas, far more effective than carbon dioxide and, well, cows generate a _lot_ of methane. Raising livestock is energy-inefficient as well so you're getting a double whammy of methane from cow farts, belches and cowshit, plus carbon dioxide from all the electricity used and gasoline burned to turn that cow into a steak.

Well, for one I would start by doing some research. Find out where the greenhouse gasses tend to come from, and how you participate in that. Then, find areas in your life you can eliminate to avoid contributing to the problem. For instance, the cattle industry produces a significant amount of GHG--between cutting down forests to provide room for cow pastures, methane produced by the cows' digestive systems, and the transportation of food to and meat from farms--to the point that it's a major contributor to the greenhouse effect (even greater than the entire transportation industry). Thus, one thing you can do is become vegetarian, to reduce demand of meat and, thus, reduce it's contributions to the greenhouse effect. This is but one example. In the end, though, it's entirely up to you what to do, and if you do the research you'll be much less susceptible to someone lying to you. I hope this helps, and I wish you luck in your search!

Here's the thing... We insist on the freedom for the population to continue expanding exponentially.  We insist on the ultra-wealthy being free to enjoy every luxury they desire.  We insist that nuclear power is too dangerous and/or expensive.  We insist on building huge cities on every coastline.  

None of these things can change, but somehow we're supposed to find some big solution to global warming before anything bad starts to happen.

That imaginary solution is not going to come.  The only solution will be global warming itself, when it finally begins to drown the coastlines, incurring emergency expenses nobody dares dream about right now.  

The rich people will go broke trying to save their coastline cities to no avail.  The population will be brought down by casualties of the flooding, and rampant disease in the aftermath of such disasters. 

A global economic depression will likely result, coupled by global famine, as it becomes more and more difficult to farm (due to both climate change and depression). And this will inevitably lead to global war.

The solutions all suck.  We need to dump money into research.  This is really the argument we should be having...  why are we working this problem on an overly expensive marginal gain basis like a carbon tax, that hurts our economy, rather than using the government to fund improvements in existing technologies to actually have a reasonably price solution?  The carbon tax as devised is still not a solution, it is, in fact, a marginal approach the government sells environmentalists to appease them and get votes.  Climate change scientists have, at least recently equivocated to some extent on the risks we face and the time table we're looking at, all important information to know what our most reasonable next steps should be.  Choking our economies is probably not the best decision, I'm for bankrolling particular projects...  The EU took up the challenge to make a fusion reactor, and this is probably the biggest task in human history.  I doubt fusion will be cheap, of course, but all green energy is really expensive and most of it destroys the environment and uses a huge amount of land as a tradeoff.  But then, because we know our fossil fuels will eventually be considered finite, not like alarmist today suggest, but actually finite...  eventually they will not be cheaper than other forms of energy.  Anyway, that makes the use of fusion power a no brainer to research.  I also don't see a solution if we don't put money into coal research, otherwise, we'll just be chasing our tails as developing economies choose coal for cost reasons and we are unable to come up with any solutions to deal with that.  I would say, as far as scientists are concern, they may not disagree about the existence of climate change as much as they disagree about how to approach the problems of today's world.  There was, and might well still be a high profile standoff between the Coppenhagen project and environmentalists in this regard.  I think Coppenhagen makes the better case, and many or strongly consider leaving the country.

@TheAlexagius That's rather cynical and also untrue. Most poor and lower-class people care deeply what happens to other people. Poor people are also far more likely to part with a significant percentage of their own resources to help other people who are struggling worse than they are, even when that sacrifice would directly cause themselves harm or suffering. Wealthy people, on the other hand, part with far less of a percentage (if they even bother at all) and it's not even close to enough for them to actually feel the loss. If I were to give a homeless person $100, I would feel it. I might not be able to pay my bills or buy enough food for the month. The homeless person might be able to buy a few hot meals and go to the laundrymat to wash their clothes, maybe get something little to make them smile for a bit. It would certainly help them feel better, but it wouldn't really improve their situation directly. If a millionaire gave that same homeless person $10,000, the millionaire would barely notice--hell, he probably has suits that cost more than that--and yet the homeless person would have been given a direct and powerful second chance at life. Yet millionaires never do this. It's completely unheard-of. And countless people with very little money and resources will consistently give to charitable causes even when the giving is painful for them. This is a result of the "inverse asshole law."

OK, to everyone bitching about how "people are in denial" and are "skeptical about facts", here is a question: How do I know if something someone says is a fact or not? I am going to say that a sky is red. What do you do? You look out the window and say "Yeah, it's bullshit, the sky is blue". So what If I said that I did an extensive research and found that there are actually tiny people living on atoms, which developed a far more advanced technology than ours? You wouldn't believe me? Why, because I am a random person on the internet? What if I named myself a professor of physics? Then added tens of photoshopped images to an article and presented a long list of other professors and doctors who I say also worked on this project? Research by NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies (GISS) has identified CO2 as “The Thermostat That Controls Earth’s Temperature.” A science brief by NASA scientist Andrew Lacis emphasizes that, while both water and CO2 are greenhouse gases, they provide different functions in the maintenance of the greenhouse effect. Water vapor condenses, whereas CO2, methane, ozone, and the other trace gases are non-condensing. Lacis writes: Water vapor accounts for about 50% of the Earth’s greenhouse effect, with clouds contributing 25%, carbon dioxide 20%, and the minor greenhouse gases (GHGs) and aerosols accounting for the remaining 5%… Thus, while the non-condensing greenhouse gases account for only 25% of the total greenhouse effect, it is these non-condensing GHGs that actually control the strength of the terrestrial greenhouse effect since the water vapor and cloud feedback contributions are not self-sustaining and as such, only provide amplification. Because carbon dioxide accounts for 80% of the non-condensing GHG forcing in the current climate atmosphere, atmospheric carbon dioxide therefore qualifies as the principal control knob that governs the temperature of Earth.
