@Robert Hamman It doesn't work like that. You can only get electricity out of a process that goes from higher potential energy to lower potential energy. This reduction in potential energy is what becomes electricity that we use. This means chemical reactions producing heat, things falling down (e.g. water falls), fluids moving from high to low pressure areas (e.g. wind, tides), as examples. Endothermic reactions absorbs heat, which means we have to work TO it, which means we can't get any work OUT of it.

@Robert Hamman I don't think the exothermic nature of fossil fuel combustion is significant compared to the effects of greenhouse gasses.  It would be neat to know how those two effects compare though. Edit: I had said something incorrect about solar power.  It does use heat and light (which could be turned to heat) and turns it into electricity... but damned thermodynamics means that it will be turned into heat again when the energy is used.

@kikones34 I agree that it's important to learn one, but I don't think it's gone about the right way. And I agree with the sentiment that different languages can express different concepts. However, to get to those concepts, you must learn vocabulary and grammar and you must practice (through extensive reading, listening to comprehensible speech, etc.) not to mention, a lot of those concepts are revealed as you're learning vocabulary (one of the first things one should learn when studying a language is that direct translations often don't exist outside of nouns and basic verbs). As for Spanish and English being similar, I'd say that's only because of the culture and extreme French (and classical) influences in today's Modern English. Even Middle English is nearly unrecognizable to native English speakers (especially in text...), and Old English is a Germanic language that must be studied almost from the ground up. All three are rightly considered different languages (and that doesn't even get into dialects). Just my opinion on that, I feel similarly about Japanese after spending so much time with it (once you've been around something long enough the similarities are as obvious as the differences, if not more so).

@amarokorama In a few months, I learned two years worth of Japanese, according to the curricula of notable schools, such as Clemson University and MIT; I also compared it to my experience with mandatory Spanish classes in school. It doesn't take much of a foray into learning theory or comparisons between different learning techniques to see that they are structured the same as most other classes in mandatory schooling levels: catering to the lowest common denominator in order to pad test averages and ensure that the average student becomes the average worker with average knowledge. This is not a conspiracy theory, it's the inevitable conclusion to mass-produced education; but even for these standards, foreign language is handled poorly (else so many people wouldn't fail it). EDIT: Oh, and might I mention that content from an introductory psych course will give you enough to know that school isn't optimized for learning, but to pump out identical drones. As for math and other subjects; I was quite satisfied with the progress once I made it out of highschool; what would've taken two years or so in highschool took only a semester at my college. I don't know what country you're from, but here, math is taught poorly as well (though now they expect most students to have studied basic trigonometry before college; doesn't mean they expect you to know it though). However, most people can fly through math class in primary and secondary schooling, so the pace serves it's purpose. To touch on the problem of schools padding test averages; I know for a fact that this is a thing, because the principal of my elementary school (public school, good standing) flat out told my parents that my performance was the only reason they didn't expel me for my behavior (I'm bipolar and was unable to control myself well as a child). They kept a problem child *because I made them look good*. That's the main thing the school administration cares about; the teachers and staff are the only ones who might give a damn about the students actual knowledge (I had several teachers that went out of their way to teach us something extra that would actually be useful as opposed to just following the base curriculum).

It's always good to learn other languages, they open your mind a bit. Languages are not only about words and grammatical rules, they also have concepts in them, concepts that capture the reality in different ways, and that allow you to express your thoughts in different ways. I'm a native Spanish speaker, and after learning a decent amount of English, when I think inside my mind I do it with both Spanish and English concepts. Sometimes I can express them in using just Spanish words, but other times I really don't know how to do it, because some English concepts are not in the Spanish language (and vice versa). But really, at the end of the day, English and Spanish have a lot in common. If you start looking at some oriental languages like Chinese or Japanese, you realize how different they express themselves, and how different are some of the concepts they usually use. So, learning different languages changes the way you think, and opens you new possibilities to express yourself. And that's why I consider it important to learn at least another language apart from your native one.

@jempeterson Is he literate? Serious question, since it's important in a business setting. Unless he was at an excellent school that went above and beyond standard curriculum for Japanese language courses, he probably could have achieved the same amount in only half a year or so of dedicated study; languages classes are generally poorly paced, due to the massive amount of content one needs to digest, regular students (ones without real interest in the language) just wouldn't be able to keep up. I will say, though, that having an actual class gives far better opportunity to practice actual speaking than self-study (though there are many ways around this problem for learners that can talk to practice partners or tutors over the internet). I've been studying Japanese for four or five years now; most of my focus is on literacy and I have achieved a level at which I can understand most structures and can read various written works intended for various audiences with an expected curve in difficulty as the content strays from my vocabulary. However, this has been at the almost complete neglect of aural comprehension as well as spoken (I only learned proper pronunciation) and written production; I can only form basic sentences, and that takes far longer than it needs to, because I haven't practiced; instead, I worked on something I wanted above all else: to be able to read. The thing about language classes is, the vocabulary necessary to consistently understand the majority of words in any medium, genre, or topic is far too large to cram into someone in such a slow paced course, especially since they expect you to use the worst memorization technique: rote memorization. Grammar is a beast that is easier or harder depending on what language(s) you know, what language you're learning, and how much experience you have learning grammar, so I won't even get into that topic. I know I've been particularly indirect, so I'll just clarify to any who've read this far: language classes do nothing for anyone who doesn't care to learn on their own as well. If you don't study on your own and explore the language outside of the classroom, you will not learn it; you might remember a few phrases that might save you from peeing yourself (「トイレはどこですか」) and such, but that's about it. Thus, I think mandatory foreign language classes are stupid (maybe with the exception of English). I'm all for language classes being available though, I sure wish I had the chance to take a Japanese class at school (I might be able to speak a bit more); unfortunately, even in college, very few schools in my area offer it (they teach German, but not Japanese... this is the US! Unless I'm getting a music degree, I can't see any need for them to prefer German to Japanese!) and it's just not in my budget to pay for classes that don't count towards my degree.

I honestly think, that if we spent four years teaching computer languages (you wouldn't need four years to become proficient, the rest could be science,) it would be worth more, in more jobs, than any foreign language could be. Of course, there is tremendous merit in learning other languages, but _every_ high school student committing to three to four years to it is just ridiculous in today's world. Computer languages are more universal, easier to learn, and more applicable to a wider range  of jobs.
